HzVqQhZhMjqcl53haINl0Q.text: Ooooh this place was so good! I love how simple the menu was. Easy and fast ordering. We sat on the bar where you can see the cooks making yummy ramen. I loved the energy in this place it was awesome. I ordered a mild miso ramen. Loved the spice of the miso broth & the noodles were the star of the dish. From the front of the restaurant you can see the noodles actually being made! You will like this place if you want a good hardy bowl of ramen.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso ramen with mild spicy

qOfLTFFkXXImmhzXF84p_g.text: I really wanted to love this place, especially since it's literally down the road from my house. The broth just isn't as flavorful as other ramen places. The noodles are just alright. Nothing really caught my attention. Perhaps on my next visit I shall try other items on the menu.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu Ramen, one with egg. Slightly lacking in depth of flavor.

zkrdwMKQlFW5dM9mRBAOlA.text: Omg fresh noodles being made as you walk in the door. Small place just like it's sister restaurant Monta. Nice people and service. Really nice interior. Will report back after I eat.

XaEjh5wZRM-N2QYtiN8HLg.text: Line out the door worthy food. Family friendly. Amazing food as expected! Slightly updated menu. Fantastic food. Same set up as their other location "Monta". Friendly, helpful staff. The cool addition is fresh noodles behind glass so you get to see them make it! Fun for kids during the wait :)

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kimchi Fried rice! Fantastic as is!
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu ramen (chicken broth) no red chili add corn. Fantastic! I added more garlic from the table condiments, mmmm!

qMqYyL1z21P0n90OBWtcnw.text: As other reviews say, it definitely has room for improvement.   Our server, Camille, didn't seem like she knew the menu fully, despite the fact that they only have few items on their menu. We had to repeat our orders several times, but without us having to actually point at the menu, she didn't seem to understand us. However, since it's a newly opened restaurant, that was not a big deal.   The stars are for their food. Their broth is full of oil and fat. There is rarely any flavor a ramen eater would expect from it. Just refer to most of the other reviews, and trust me, they are not exaggerating.   There are so many other choices in Vegas for ramen. I am just disappointed that the only ramen location in Southwest area is a place that I will probably never return to.

uafz93DXX4ma86hs5X-z3g.text: I'm a huge fan of both Monta Ramen locations, so I had very high expectations to try their new restaurant.  After trying it though, I would say don't waste your time.  The ramen is decent, but it is nowhere near the level of quality I expect from the Monta family. The worst offense is the broth.  Whether it's tonkotsu, shoyu, or miso, they all have little floating bits of pork/chicken fat swimming in the bowl that are nauseating to say the least.  At Monta, you can tell they take the time to prepare the broth by boiling the bone marrow, which results in a creamy and consistent texture and flavor.  I feel like Ramen Kobo is simply cutting corners by adding extra fat to an otherwise unexceptional broth. I give it two stars because the noodles and toppings were all great, but the broth ruined it for me and my girlfriend.  tl;dr Go to Monta or Monta Chaya instead!  They're much better!

jhTOGIZybuyv8ZFujhtm7w.text: Place is kind of small, only have five tables on your left side, right side are rows of bar stools, on your right side when you walk in, there's a small room you can see the guy making noodles, we got the miso ramen, noodles are thin and chewy, soup base is light and tasty, service is on par... if you want light and tasty lunch, this is the place..

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. miso ramen original

pxFUrAcmV1j-_KLlA7Mbcg.text: This has got to be the best ramen place in Vegas! The noodles here are hand pulled and fresh. The broth is flavorful and the added veggies are perfect with the soup. This is the only place that has the word "spicy" done right. We are always in search for really spicy ramen, but the other ramen places that claim their noodles are spicy just have like chili flakes for you to add on. Not ramen kobo; their "fire" spicy level is no joke, especially for the shoyu ramen. I like that although it is extremely spicy, the spiciness is not too overwhelming that you can't taste the flavor! Beware when you order the spicy level! If you're unsure whether you can handle the spiciness, you can always ask them to have the spice on the side so you can slowly add it in. All in all, my bf and I have been coming here at least once a week for the past half year and we will continue to go here to get our weekly fix of authentic spicy ramen!

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu ramen (spicy level: fire) eat at your own risk!!

3WqD-vPerLWlrnebEOCZsA.text: The restaurant is very small. We are a family of five and had to squeeze into a table that was only made to seat 4. This was to avoid having to wait longer and the hostess was kind enough to ask first if it would be ok (2 adults 3 kids). With that being said, the menu is very straight forward and service is fairly quick which helps minimize the wait time for other parties.   As for the food, I've tried the Tonkotsu and the Miso. Both were flavorful and in my opinion, was served with a good ratio of broth to noodles. The noodles are made fresh of which you have the opportunity to watch as they are being made while you wait to be seated. The meat portion is rather small and have to pay more if you would like to add extra toppings. This will bump up the base price of the ramen another $1.50 to $2.50 for each item you add on.  Overall Ramen KoBo is very good with friendly and fast service. I will definitely return especially now that winter is right around the corner.

1nnxPfE1nGmeA2JOScTnWA.text: This place was amazing warning it is crowded . I got the chicken broth but I added black garlic oil soooo good !! I can't wait to go back

eO3X91cJ0Wge15jMrWFB_A.text: Noodle factory ! Check out their fresh made noodles . Noodle lovers must try this place ! I had the ramen w/ shoyu broth medium spicy . The broth is delicious, pork , n ingredients tasted fresh. The menu doesn't offer a big variety but I do appreciate a restaurant that focuses on quality of each dish . I'll definitely be back. I would highly recommend this place for the following reasons ; good noodles, reasonable price, trendy atmosphere.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States

3sXsDM-NNhWUM59aY4AV-g.text: This restaurant was on the small side as there wasn't a big waiting area. I decided to order take out as there were 6 parties in front of me. When I took the ramen home I was pleasantly surprised with the Tonkatsu ramen. It was flavorful but a bit short on the fixings. The flavor of the soup was good.  I really liked the man taking my order. He gave me a good recommendation of the vegetarian ramen.  I would like to try the restaurant again before giving a mediocre rating.

SDrWa9t0qH8LgX07cdrtzQ.text: Came in to get a quick bite after the gym, before running some errands. I got seated fairly quick and the server waisted no time getting my drink order, and since its scorching I appreciated that. My server name was Ryan and he was very helpful. Since I was looking to get something quick, I ordered the pork belly rice bowl. It's cheap and delicious, will be coming back for ramen soon   Came here for my second time with a friend and this blonde Asian chick greeted me. This lady is extremely rude as far as giving service. I asked if I can order ahead for a friend and she insisted no.. I'm like my buddy is going to be here in 2 mins can I just order.. than she started comparing what others have done saying their friends will be coming in 5 mins and show up 10-20 mins later. Seriously?? Maybe your friends not mine. I looked at the name tag and her name is Rachel

Uq-bCsplYSycU3iosz19ig.text: The food is amazing and the service is super quick. My only minor complaint would be that the music gets loud, but I think I'm just old, lol. Other than that the place is phenomenal.

ei-10e8JsLUBt9JZkW4dzw.text: Convenient location with ample parking space! Definitely a plus when compared to Monta on Spring Mountain. :)  I went around lunch on opening day, so there was no wait and we were seated right away. The place is nice and small, like a lot of ramen places in town. You are greeted by everyone once you walk in, and to the right, you can see the workers making fresh noodles! Since this restaurant faces West, I'd hate to be making noodles with the sun blazing in my eyes.  We were asked what we wanted to drink shortly after sitting down (Got our usual water with lemon). The waiter had to check if they had lemon slices. xD I don't blame them, since it IS their opening day, and still pretty early on, so I'm guessing they are still trying to figure things out. They didn't have any :( But hopefully they will in the future.  We had a party of 4, and I had the original shoyu ramen (no spicy) with nitamago. Each both of ramen (minus the vege ramen) comes with chashu pork, fried garlic, kikurage black mushrooms, bamboo shoots, fresh green chives, ground pork, sesame oil, and shredded red pepper. The broth was fatty and flavorful; a perfect five stars. The fresh homemade ramen - that's what makes this review a 4 star. It's not that the ramen was bad, it's just not really to my liking. I'm more of a fan of the thick noodles from Monta, which has a completely different texture. Also, even after soaking the noodles in the broth for a while, it still tasted a bit bland. On the other hand, the chashu pork had a great fat to meat ratio, and they actually had a whole clove of fried garlic in my broth. Yum. =] Also, the nitamago was cooked to soft-boiled perfection. Gotta love that runny yolk! The black mushrooms, bamboo shoots, fresh green chives, ground pork, etc are as expected. No complaints there.  I also got to try the broth of the Miso ramen with Hot spicy (level three spicy of four). There was a kick to it, but it faded quickly and didn't linger like a lot of other spicy foods. So even if you can't handle spicy like me, you should be okay with a level one or two spicy.  I'll be back to try the other broths as well as the rice. Keep it up!

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Original Shoyu Ramen with Nitamago.
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Menu.

REhyIDT51bFNzN1E-ng4OQ.text: One of my favorite Ramen places in Vegas. Great food, fast and friendly service, but the eating area is pretty small so rush hour has a bit of a wait. Over all I would with out a doubt recommend this to anyone as It is in a convenient area of Summerlin and good price.

wCrEafj_KfaCzKXOd66Jmw.text: The ramen had good broth. Their bamboo shoots are really small but extra corn for 1 dollar is a lot ( I love corn ). The noodle is kind of hard but I think that's how it's supposed to be so it's ok.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States

RDybCo-AmCtAxSoolsRZ6A.text: I absolutely love the Monta on Spring Mountain. I won't be back to the one on Durango. My Tonkotsu Ramen was so bland I honestly think it was likely water I received for some reason. I wasn't checked on until someone brought a check. The employees sure were having a good time.

QPVAj-v63qa9XyZDZhKIww.text: This is probably the only Ramen place here in the Valley that I keep coming back to. Their ramen is fantastic and the broth is always rich in flavor. I am knocking one star due to some missing toppings that, for me, completes a Ramen (their ramen has no soft boiled egg, you have to pay for it as an addon for example). Try their pork belly bowl also.

oWeViJaKYAhABUL82xcKgg.text: Holy yum!! I love ramen and went to Vegas to visit my sister (also a ramen fanatic). She took me here and right away I loved the atmosphere and direct view of their house made noodle set up! It's small but trust me, you want to wait. I ordered the spicy broth (hot) and should have done the hottest one because I love spice. The broth was so good and flavorful. In addition they had options for additions and side sauces like minced garlic, pickled ginger (my sisters favorite), and chili oil. You can do so much with their options and the soft boiled egg is always an excellent addition. Their noodles were the perfect texture. Overall this is definitely a must-eat-eatery.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Extra mushroom and soft boiled egg. Spicy.

LpmHzPRvpcul2QcxQvSu3g.text: The absolute best ramen in the southwest area of Las Vegas!!! My boyfriend and I are ramen fiends, we have tried over 10 different restaurants and can state ramen Kobo is the best ramen! The fact that they make their own noodles makes them the best. I don't know how to describe the difference in the noodles but this one factor makes a huge difference in the ramen outcome. The broth is also very tastey. I am a miso type of girl so I've been able to compare broths from different restaurants. This is the best spot for ramen! Cute quaint little spot in the same shopping center of EOS. A must try if you're in the area!!

JOzHd8LczWKlO0xGfPIGMA.text: This was my first ramen experience here in Las Vegas. It's pretty close spaced inside with a single walk through between a row of table seatings on the left and bar seating on the right. The menu is simple. Service is brief & straightforward yet accommodating. Not the friendliest crew I've seen yet not hostile either. Our server was attentive despite the busy hours.   Itadakimasu!! (..did i spell that right?!) My tonkatsu ramen on medium spice which I ordered with corn, egg, and butter was delicious. Reasonably spicy. Their kimchi fried rice wasn't that spicy and it had a dried fish flavor to it rather than kimchi. I did like it. At the end we all left with satisfied stomachs. I recommend.   Just don't be offended if the servers don't smile at you.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkatsu ramen with butter, corn, and egg
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States

5vxdUHoxhSX59veYFCzxBg.text: Absolutely the best Ramen I have ever had!! When it is made on site, it can't get any better! This is the place for Ramen!

be25-9TuNl0Ht6tMXo53Pw.text: A very small restaurant but it makes the best ramen that I've ever had! It doesn't matter what you order...it's all great! If you don't like soups that are spicy stick to the original. Great place!

XePpl0kQkMiO6DN_7g01-A.text: Love this place! It's is on point! Only downside is the place is always full & crowded...they need to expand the place.

uxG-nqPiQFZyaCTAr7Wv6A.text: Love this place! The black garlic oil is a must with any of the bases. The staff is always pleasant and the service is quick which is great since there's usually always people waiting. I would also recommend their pork chashu buns! So simple but so much flavor.

Y4038zKQ6cvyiycx8MeHuw.text: Ramen was very fresh, as expected since you can see them make it, plus the soup was very clear, not overly seasoned. You must try the fried rice, seasoning was very tasty!  I will be coming back then next time I'm back in Vegas.

Tjz3eleIFckVUBwNYVO2KQ.text: Probably OVERALL the BEST Ramen place in town. Noodles have great flavor and the choices are perfect with sides to compliment your ramen.  Basic Tonkatsu extra noodles is simple yet satisfying enough to make you want more the next week.  We still enjoy other places (Jinya, Sora, Fukumimi, Tatsu, Monta, Kokoro, Moko) but this is the one I would recommend to anyone wanting or even craving a solid bowl of tasty Ramen being their first or hundred time. Service is second to non, food and sides come out like there's no tomorrow, fast and hot! Very courteous and a sense of urgency every time we come here.  Workers set the standard for service for me and the only drawback is the hit and miss waiting time, but that's always a good thing because everyone knows this is the Best Ramen on the whole west side of Vegas.

xjvq693UIxqIX8MOn7rYbA.text: Out of all the ramen places I've tried, this one has got to be one of my least favorite. I gave this place a try twice and just came out disappointed in both occasions. I ordered the regular tonkotsu and the soup is just so bland for me. One thing I love about this place though is their fried rice. I've ordered those on both times I went and I have nothing but praise for it. It's very fresh and the rice isn't hard or too sticky, just perfect. It's a little unfortunate that I didn't care much for their ramen because their customer service here is fantastic.

qRTwTj2pQY3dKwau7aBtqg.text: Hand made noodles on the west side!! I want to come back during the day as you can see right into the kitchen where they make the noodles. Simple menu and limited offerings are off set by speed and tastiness. Decor is very fitting and the 28 seats seem limited until you realize the turn time is about 20 minutes. Tried miso spicy with spinach and soy soy cured egg add-on's and a vegetable ramen with black garlic oil. Both were very flavorful and the medium spicy was just enough to get your nose running by the end of it. Service was very fast and courteous. For $8.95 a medium sized bowl of tasty ramen is a great deal. Definitely coming back.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States

Mb-54FcK7AukpE96RaDovg.text: good pork soup alike original Ramen in japan. I love the vegetable which is grilled. lucky me that no long queue on weekday at 12noon.  small and chill place for small group

2CrCSnZUBZiPhMOXwuO_Tw.text: Went here two days back-to-back. The first time was for a late-night dinner and the second time was right before dinner rush. Both times had excellent flavor of ramen. Well-seasoned, miso and tonkatsu broth soups was extremely flavorful! Noodles were thin and it was the perfect portion.   Service was attentive. Food came out fairly quick. The only couple things that stops me giving this 4 stars is the fact that my bowl came out lukewarm to barely warm. My extra chashu was also cold in my soup. I'm talking like freshly sliced and pulled from the fridge type of cold. I figured whatever, it's still freaking delicious, it's also really, really busy on a weekend an hour before closing.   The next day, I'm still craving ramen, so my friend and I go in and we order. I get a miso broth with mild spiciness, extra chashu, and nori. Same thing happens, chashu is less cold (still feels it was refrigerated) this time and ramen broth is still just warm, not hot. Like it's been sitting out for a while.   Both times, the pork chashu was just so-so, kind of flavorless. I'm not going to get a third time. Soft boiled eggs I had in my ramen both times were good, flavorful, perfectly made.   I know I could have said something, but I didn't want to be known as "that person". I'm not a picky eater by any means either. The ramen is still amazing, service was fantastic, but I can't really overlook the  barely warm ramen. I don't need it scalding hot, just maybe a bit hotter like ramen should be. I'm still definitely coming back, and maybe I caught them on another off night. Or maybe a customer complained that the ramen was too hot before? I still recommend this place as a good casual eat, but I don't know about taking someone that's a bit more pickier than I am.  EDIT: Glad I'm not the only one that thinks the same thing about the cold chashu and broth.

wIGRVfKEpnFlx_0djVmZow.text: Great ramen place, one of the more authentic feeling ones I've been to. The shop is tiny, and coming for lunch can be a gamble, as lines grow quickly. Fortunately, my two person party was seated immediately as a two person table had just opened up. The menu is simple, much like other ramen restaurants. The only options are shoyu, miso, tonkotsu, and veggie. The thing this ramen-ya prioritizes is spice, and the spice range goes from none to extreme. I got the least spicy of the spicy ramens, but it was still plenty hot. Also, the ramen bowls come with some toppings, but things some people consider commonplace like nori and egg are add-ons. The service is quick and prompt, as they have lots of people to feed. Once you get your food, you chow down immediately so all the people waiting can eat too. The noodles, which were made there, were  (exquisite). The spice that they added was obviously oily, as it separated from the miso broth I got. This meant you had to stir a lot. Still, this place gave some very tasty, spicy, and addictive ramen. I will probably be back when it isn't as crowded.

1oCe38R6QimsJdk-1T7YCA.text: Most Vegas residents aren't familiar with the Japanese chain known as Tenkaippin Ramen, but if you are, Ramen Kobo's tonkotsu broth is practically a dead ringer.  They totally nailed the unique, thick, gravy-like pork broth that made me feel I could've been at one.  There are a ton of people that love this, but I am not one of them.  Despite the noodles being decent and that one meager slice of pork chashu (don't bother with the chashu chicken) tasting good, this simply did not give me the "kimochi" I was looking for.      For those that dislike the amount of sodium usually associated with Japanese ramen, both the tonkotsu and the light shoyu broth should please.  That 5000 mg aftertaste many experience often won't happen here.  I felt obligated to add spice, since it was something they push here, but it didn't improve much for me.  Order it on the side and do what your heart tells you.  Mine told me not to use it.    It was strange that gyoza wasn't on the menu.  I asked and also overheard two of the neighboring tables ask as well.  Why not just give the people what they want?  In the end, it's better than Omoide, but not as good as Sora or Jinya.  One and done.      2.984743874 stars

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu

cHQ2GzLVxYqARj_sHM7V1g.text: Noodle making factory drew my attention.   Super cute spot, not very big but loved the counter top seating. Front row to see how all the yumminess is created. All ramen used is made in house so its fresh for each order.   Miso ramen spice hot added soft boiled egg, seaweed and bamboo shots. Ramen was really good, broth was full of flavor.  Chashu bowl was really good too..large peices of pork, scallions and shredded nori over rice. Extremely tasty. Pork belly bowl was ok, nothing too special.  I love that so many ramen places are popping up around my house!

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso ramen
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chashu bowl
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork belly bowl

wJWLGd7Lz7SX6gj_T_PQJw.text: BEST RAMEN PLACE I HAVE BEEN TO! I really have no complaints about this place and on top of that, they have chicken here so I am not stuck with pork (I don't eat pork). They have levels of spice to their broth starting from no spicy to FIRE. I stick with the "medium" level and that is already pretty spicy to me. From hearing other people order and hearing my friends order, a lot of people get "mild" spice so I would start with that level first. Their broth is so tasty and their noodles are good as well. They actually hand make their noodles so maybe that plays a role as to why it's so good haha. Their service is also good, the waiters are always so nice and on top of that it's quick. It's also not too expensive, it's probably around the same price as other ramen places so if you want good quality ramen, please try this place!

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu ramen-Added with ground chicken, soft boiled egg, and corn.
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Menu

LwhMyx_N1cIJU0P98VfuZg.text: There phone doesn't allow anyone to be placed on hold. As soon as you can call them, it just gots to busy dial while they are on the phone with another customer.   Finally got thorough after several calls. Went in to pay hopefully have my food ready but that wasn't the case. Took me 30 mins to get there and still didn't have my food ready. Waited another 20 mins and still wasn't ready. I got people ordering there and they got theirs before mine. My order was nothing but two orders of ramen and a fried rice.   They are fast when you dine in but take off is the worst.   Employees need to focus on the customers who were waiting the longest.   Never ordering here again.

rvLxD5L7UETjV55Ggp-Ngg.text: It is located right in front of EOS Gym (the temptations!!!) next to Subway and Cafe Rio.   It's owned by Monta but Kobo's ramen is a little different. It has bar seating and also a good amount of tables. I have never had to wait for seating so far. It has all the basic broths; miso, shoyu, tonkatsu and vegetarian. Then you are able to pick your spice levels and extra toppings. I always order the miso ramen anywhere I go and add the boiled egg. So good!  Now the miso ramen here comes with charsu pork slices AND some form of ground meat. Not sure if it's ground chicken or pork. Either way it's good lol. The broth has been a little too watery for my taste so I find myself adding A LOT of that orange ramen seasoning (which I still don't know the name of) and sesame seeds.   Although I still like Monta just a taaad bit more, I like how this is super close to me and I can get my ramen fix without having to suffer going all the way to Chinatown :D

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso ramen medium spice with egg. Egg is separate ($1.50) Ramen comes with 2 slices of pork and some ground pork mixed in there.

xsF4-r6KxiI6gO_B409iiQ.text: Yep still 5 stars.  I had the Tonkotsu Ramen this trip which was amazing!  The pork broth was delicious and had a slight creaminess to it. I enjoyed the roasted garlic cloves, kikurage mushrooms, and green onions.    I also tried the fried rice this trip which was also very delicious. Great ingredient ratios and fantastic flavors.   Next time ...Pork Belly bowl!

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu Ramen [pork broth]

cz5yqgeJTF-OdzcwE11T-Q.text: Excellent ramen!! Great fast service!! Highly recommend the miso!!!! So filling and delicious!! Opens 11:30am until 2:00am!!

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States

ASAk20GYA2BFZlGynn4RIQ.text: Amazing place ! Always get great service and the ramen tastes amazing . Not too many items for selection for appetizers, but it's all about the ramen ! Definitely recommend !!

VHmXs5D6mO0fAcvfRVHhhw.text: Being half Japanese and eating soba for years, I find this place to be just like the ones I ate at in Japan except the only thing is their portions are way to small and they only use pork belly.  To enhance the flavor adding chili to the dashi is not the way to go but they do it a lot and they only have four (4) different types of ramen.  We call this type of soup in Hawaii saimin which means noodle dish and this place doesn't even compare.  They need more variety in their dishes and cut out the chili by making the dashi (soup base) more presentable.  Will I go back...don't think so.

N7a-wAchmiFDFgY8SpR8NQ.text: Ramen Kobo has become a ritual for all my visitors and guests.  I absolutely adore the staff and the Miso Ramen.  Noodles are made fresh and if you're lucky you will be able to watch them make the noodles in front of you.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States

wwQ45tYRP4OE0glOw4oOYA.text: Small and amazing ramen shop! I sat at the bar and ordered the Miso ramen with chashu pork and it was everything my heart desired. The staff was friendly and the service was fast. I haven't had this good a ramen house experience since I lived in San Francisco.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso ramen with chashu pork

Ni4krnmtQIPt22rSoscktw.text: Had a late dinner here tonight. Ordered a vege ramen and a shoyu ramen with extra chashu pork. Both had the mild spice level. We thought the ramen was very very good. Nice flavorful broth. Spicy level was just right, and could taste the food (unlike some, where it's so spicy, that's all you notice). Some people might think the shoyu ramen looks a bit oily, but I thought it was ok. (Maybe if you let it go cold, you could see the grease more - no chance of that for me - my bowl was gone like that!) I was a bit disappointed with the lack of hot tea (warming up canned tea doesn't count). I would recommend this place though, and am looking forward to trying some of the other ramen dishes.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu ramen with extra chashu pork, mild spice level. Very flavorful!
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Verge ramen with mild spice level
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Menu

Vwj4zVIWGjA5Vzo_BoG0jw.text: Friendly staffs, fast service, affordable and the food is pretty nice. They also open till late so it's a good place to go at late night.

kk2VUlbPYTqs_jOuMW8P8A.text: Visiting Las Vegas with family. We had 4 adults and 5 kids (ages 3 to 11). I'm  from California and had traditional Japanese ramen. This is not traditional but I don't  think this was their intention. They make their noodles in house. The noodles taste good but is again not traditional ramen noodle..it is starchy. If anyone has tried Korean Chinese food, the noodles most resembles that.   One can choose from a variety of broth and they come with a little bit of toppings. I wouldn't suggest adding extras unless you want an egg. I like spicy so I had spicy miso (medium spicyness). It was good and tasted like jampong. I ordered miso broth for my kids. This is where they miss the mark. Because the noodles were starchy,  their soup became thick and starchy. This least resembles Japnese ramen broth which is light in texture and flavorful.   I also ordered a small wgg roe rice (see pic) which I enjoyed but also not traditionally Japanese. The egg roe they use is is a Korean egg roe which is salty. I still liked it. The rice with pork was a good optiom for kids.  The place is small. They had to split us.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States

5zg7NLTjLV0GE-EcTrlhNA.text: Ramen close to Summerlin, yay!  This is basically Monta with an option for spice.  It's been awhile since I've been to Monta, but the noodles here are fresh made and are definitely al dente when they arrive.  The noodles remind me of a compromise between the thin and wavy noodles at Monta.  Broth is similar to Monta tonkatsu broth and very thick and rich.  The pork seems the same, extremely fatty and tender.  The unfortunate part is this place is just as tiny as the Chinatown Monta =(  I think they should expand, so the customers don't have to wait forever for a table on cold wintery nights =)

RNYaDuVvo0YQOPY8ivQ5hA.text: New favorite! The place is very tiny so come early. We were a party of 6 and they offered us a table for 4. We were so hungry that we didn't mind squishing. They have different levels of spiciness to choose from. I got the  "mild" but in my opinion that could have been labeled "medium", so they run spicy.  The broth was really good and didn't have that "lard" after taste. Their chasu or pork was really good as well.  I definitely will be coming back!

9hvyur2MBwyA67Xcoj8_Xw.text: Love the soup.base, noodles,  freshness,  quick service,  customer service! Love how they are consistent and toppings are yummy! I like the pork chasu,  egg, butter,  and extra noodles!

-FNOPRS0JaSKjNrn3A462g.text: I've been here two or three time on separate Vegas excursions. Great food! Definitely worth the wait. I highly recommend adding the black oil to your ramen. It's amazing and really changes the experience. A+!

VZI-hFQxPrPtsL8KHE4n6w.text: I will never be back. Busy and small environment but that is the least of my worries here. Let me at least tell you the good things:  1) Noodles - Handmade right there and quite delicious. Great texture.  2) Ground Pork - Flavorful and tasty.  3) Mushrooms - Good texture.   Now, this all sounds great to start but we are missing one vital component to ramen: THE BROTH. The broth had absolutely ZERO flavor. There was no salt on the table for me to add. As I started looking around I could see that everyone was adding everything they could to this broth. You need chili paste, garlic, soy sauce, etc. It is simply not worth it. It was very disappointing and turned me off to the ramen craze everyone is so gung ho about these days. I will try another place and see if I can be swayed in a more positive direction. I see a lot of people giving this place a positive review so maybe I am crazy but neither myself or the people I was with enjoyed it.

3JG1CzgLu7PbgVmUTiVYJw.text: If you love ramen this is the place to come to! Awesome and friendly staff and excellent service . I'm forsure coming back to place again! They make their own noodles and the soup is just phenomenal! Well done you guys well defiantly see me again

3lqLqI_YGCSirGuV4_fEHQ.text: So yummy! Big serving size, choose your spice level, and noodles are made in house. Like any other ramen place, it is a small area, so beware of a wait if you come for dinner. Great spot!

RG2T8SVsVo1BomdyGdRewg.text: Came here with my husband over the weekend on our short trip to Vegas.  We were excited to find out Monta opened a Spicy concept restaurant, and I loooovvvveee spicy ramen!!!!  When we arrived, they were making hand made noodles inside the store, which was cool to watch. Fresh and firm noodles are the best.  I wish we had a spicy concept ramen joint in Orange County too...  Thank you Ramen Kobo!

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Nama-men

Ywp6BRLDmRPUqhUYUuh-PA.text: Favorite ramen place ever! Their noodles are the best I've ever had. If you really pay attention to all the noodles at ramen places, then come here, you will definitely notice a difference! Their noodles are basically perfect and their broth is delicious! The staff is very friendly and their environment is so upbeat and positive! I love coming here :))

1JH91QTOGO-n4i9zTCU8_A.text: Delicious!! Kimchi fried rice is awesome too. We got our ramen at medium heat with extra pork - it was perfect. Will def be back! Happy this place is close to the house!!!

_vdBPsWscAkuIGBZJRngQQ.text: Went here last night for the first time with my husband, my best friend & her husband. Pretty cool place! Although the place was small, I was quite impressed with how well the staff was at handling the seating situation. I've never seen anyone wait longer than ten minutes!  Right when you walk in and get seated, the server says something in Japanese... not sure what, I'm assuming it's along the lines of "New meat coming thru.." lol or more like "Welcome our guests.." and then the entire staff responds back in Japanese with a welcome! I'm not sure, but it's pretty cool. So you order a ramen bowl by the broth & all the bowls come with the same things. You can take things out & then add things for an additional price. They also have a spiciness level... so if you're not into spice at all I would stick to original.  Our friends ordered their favorite shoyu ramen bowl & added a few things. My husband & wanted to stay close to home just ordered a pork tonkotsu (pork broth) ramen & I got the miso (pork & chicken broth) ramen. They also got their own pork belly bowls, but hubby & I decided to share.  I have to say the broth was rich, the noodles were fresh (they make them in-house), & it was pretty delicious. I loved the pork belly bowl though because it was super fatty & the taste was light but extremely yummy.... the fatty goodness from the fried pork belly soaked thru the rice & mmmm, it was delicious.  Not a ramen person, more of a pho lover but I would come back here every so often just for something different.

dNIVvTZJ6Uw_2sBe61LfLQ.text: Fast service and delicious ramen! I ate at this place 3 times in one week!! That's how much I love it here!

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States

BJ2YE4E8TDjJEfAKQPOp0g.text: Probably more of a 3.5 star rating, I'm a fan of Kobo's noodles and broths, but the sometimes cold (and stingy) chashu and nitamago can really dampen the experience.  My understanding is that Ramen Kobo is somehow affiliated with Monta Ramen, being opened by the same team of people.  Although Monta was one of the original ramen spots in Vegas, I stopped going because I wasn't a fan of their thin noodles or their super salty broths.  Both of those things are fixed for me at Ramen Kobo, where you can see them make their thick, chewy noodles and add in some spice to your tonkotsu, shoyu, miso, or vege broths.  My favorite has been the miso ramen with mild spicyness, which seems to prove that I'm a big wuss when it comes to spice...anything higher than mild and I'm quite sure I won't be enjoying my ramen.  The few things that I'm not a fan of are sort of big things when it comes to a good bowl of ramen.  By default, a bowl only comes with one slice of chashu.  You can add more for $2.50, but then that turns your $8.95 bowl of ramen into an $11.45 bowl of ramen.  Also by default, your bowl does not come with any egg, but you can add one nitamago for $1.50, turning your already $11.45 bowl of ramen into a $12.95 bowl of ramen.  These things might seem nitpicky because I'm choosing to add these ingredients, but other shops in town offer these things for $7-$10 by default, no need to add them.  There have also been several times where the added chashu and egg are cold, as if they came straight from the refrigerator and were tossed on top of my ramen right before being served; no bueno.  Overall an upgrade from the original Monta Ramen, as well as a decent ramen spot in a part of town that didn't have any ramen spots before.

f3YbNkA0svh21auaqZih3A.text: DISGUSTING!   I'm not a big pork Lover, they squeezed the pig guts right into their broth if you ask me !the soup was warm not hot! The meat was undercooked especially the ground pork they add into the soup ! Just nasty

1xX8f1oux-xZcIH3LbuLkg.text: i'm not usually one to write bad reviews however, this experience left a bad taste in my mouth and a damper on my evening. my boyfriend & i had been planning to get ramen here because it's always amazing. we haven't been here for a while so we assumed it would be business as usual. we get there and it seemed pretty busy, which was understandable. we had gotten a seat at the bar because it was the first available. we ordered with the server a veggie ramen, tonkatsu ramen bowl, and 2 chasu pork bowls with mild spice. we got our ramen pretty fast, before our chasu bowls. we tasted the ramen first and it was definitely not mild. it may have just been us but every time we get mild spice it's super flavorful without bringing too much heat... this wasn't the case for that. however the biggest qualm i have is when we received 2 chasu pork buns from our server, Marielos. we had to get her attention before she left and advise that we did not order the buns but the bowls instead. Marielos gave us a stale look and stated "i thought you said buns." we advised again that we said bowls and she had the rudest attitude in getting our order correct. she quickly, without much table manners and even giving us an annoyed look (she probably didn't think we saw it), grabbed the chasu buns and proceeded to tell the chef it wasn't the correct order. she was very offsetting about the whole ordeal which left my boyfriend and i thinking it was somehow a bigger issue than we had thought. after the chef was able to get our order, Marielos again quickly placed the plates onto our table... and by quickly, i mean not nicely. it was very very rude. Marielos only checked on us once during our whole meal and we were already finished. yet would go around to our other bar mates and tables behind us and constantly interact with them. The other server, with pink hair, had asked if we were doing okay and wanted boxes before our actual server asked us. We don't like to not tip, as my boyfriend and i have had our fair share in the food industry, but her attitude and customer service was very unsatisfactory. we simply got an order wrong, which we were fine with waiting, yet her attitude ruined the entire experience for us. My boyfriend and I were so upset and disappointed in the service, we advise to beware of the customer service.

UMndjnQ5hc5HTAHuAsGpeg.text: This place is bomb.com the soup from the ramen is amazing and it's alway busy here which of course is a good thing tell you that this place is good.

OJp-2uHKg45AA2KM2BMByw.text: Out of the Ramon places I've been, this has been the best one. The service was amazing and the food came out super quick. The noodles auuuhhmazing! Most definitely coming back here

gPWAKpLgbAp7S5YTDrsTJA.text: Hands down best Ramen in Vegas! I come here every so often. I would go a lot more if they were open during the day! Tried many other places, always disappointed that I "should've just gone to Kobo"

1mwQC_fgppjkR45-tzUr5w.text: Super sweet staff, but the place is extremely small and the ramen is okay. Nothing memorable, but I do like the open kitchen cooking.

oYUN9GnKIRqOG2FrJaSK_g.text: We come here once or twice a week. Nice and clean.  We love the staff. Very friendly and funny.  We bring in different people with us every time we come here.  Menu is good and simple.

rt7HwtgmIwsEaeJobUNzjA.text: I have to say you must try this place, the best noodles I've had, they make everything from scratch and super fresh. It is just a small restaurant so the wait time could go over 20 minutes depending on how busy they are, but it is worth it, they serve you freshly cooked dishes and they are full of flavors. Tried the fried rice with no pork and it came out just perfect!!! Very fast at serving your food, so you'll be out of there in less than an hour!! I will definitely go back there for more noodles

Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso noodles (delicious!!!!)
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Fried rice with no pork

h5Q_NFzYLY5ofD7_LPx9Xg.text: Goods 1. Ramen with various levels of spice 2. Other offerings including: Japanese friend rice/Cha-Han and Gyoza 3. They make their own noodles here and you can watch the noodles being made (see photo) 4. Various broths to choose from: shio, miso, shoyu (see menu photo)  Ambiance: 1. Small, a little cramped (in the spirit of traditional Tokyo style ramen houses) 2. Wait time may add up depending on peak times, don't forget to write your name on the waiting list/seating when you go in 3. Half booths and chairs 4. I like that you can watch the noodles being made, you know they are not using some freeze dried noodles etc.  Service 1. Efficient and friendly 2. I have been here twice, I have never had a problem 3. Server is also cashier  Mojo: 1. Ramen is pretty good here, I do think I prefer ramen elsewhere.  Spice level goes nothing to mild, medium, hot.  I'd say mild can be pretty spicy, they were very friendly and offered to include it on the side which is nice. 2. Cha-Han, fried rice, was good.  Very umami.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Plenty of customizations - I added butter yum
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Ramen making machine - you can watch from the window
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Cha han - Japanese ramen house fried rice its good

42eXUjwCHFDQCAoUja1b4A.text: This is an update.  I was there with my girlfriend and this time i ordered the tonkatsu ramen with ground chicken spice level eight with extra chili oil and extra noodle.  She had the pork belly rice and kimchee fried rice and I was blown away.  We both agreed that jinya ramen has their ramen beat just by a little but I will say that it is still a five.  The ramen was nice and hot and with the extra ramen noodles I was still able to make a small bowl for her too.  Kimchee fried rice was almost on par as Komex kimchee fried rice but it was still really good.  The porkbelly bowl with rice was the best i have tasted in the valley.  If you are in the area I suggest to stop by.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkatsu ramen with ground chicken spice level eight with extra chilli oil on the side, kimchee fried rice, extra noodle, pork belly rice.

6osl86YXNV7WYhS0n_pl2Q.text: I really like this ramen place. Although the prices are slightly higher than chinatown, this place has rich broth, thick noodles and enough meat to satisfy me.   I ordered the tonkotsu ramen and really liked the flavor of the broth and texture of the noodles.  Finishing the bowl made me pretty full.   If you don't know if you like spicy ramen or not you can always order the hot sauce on the side.

76qOAlDnybX06jQfBclV0Q.text: Hands down my favorite ramen in town!!! Noodles are made in house which is always fresh. The menu is small and simple which is another great thing that I love about this place. I do appreciate a large menu sometimes as there's a wide variety although I feel the food is a lot more fresh when there's only a few things they have to offer vs. storing up the freezer with everything else that's on the menu not being sold. I get the Miso ramen and the mild option which is the perfect spice for me! Not a vegetarian but their veggie ramen is also really good and a vegetarian option! Chasu bowl & kimchi fried rice are a hit for me as well. Good customer service and always leaves me satisfied!

aLj0oVSh_eJlAciGCsWsHA.text: How can people give this place a decent rating? I was craving for some late night ramen since it was very cold outside. I came across this ramen joint on yelp. I was very surprise on how they make their noodles hand made at the restaurant. I only ordered to go, the order was fast and simple through the phone.   The lady was very nice to me and took my order very professionally. I came in about 15 minutes and it was already ready like they said. We ordered the Tonkatsu and Miso ramen. Both broth was very tasteful and i enjoyed it so much. I really want to come back and dine in next time. I think this will be my new spot for some mouth watering ramen for every night.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. To go orders. Good portions.

rWc8h1j059rm5rTZ6HLVpg.text: This place is super delicious, and I would recommend it. I ordered the miso ramen and added an egg and nori to it. I wish it showed the Bonito flakes on the menu instead of a separate advertisement or I would have added that too.   My friend and I were a bit confused from the placement of the bean sprouts. It took us almost the entire meal to figure out that the bean sprouts are actually placed beneath the noodles. The spice levels are indeed True to their description. We were here in the late afternoon for an early dinner. We were attended to quickly and we had a very kind server. When asked to split the check, even though I forgot to ask at the beginning, he helped us very quickly. I believe we were in and out in half an hour. This is a great fast casual establishment. I would definitely come here again!

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Yummy ramen. Just because you don&#39;t see the bean sprouts, doesn&#39;t mean they aren&#39;t there. Delicious!
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Mmmmm pork. Yummy! I don&#39;t usually like iceberg lettuce. But it was perfect for this

ITU4zCAz32R8aQspQZbLeg.text: Still love their ramen here!  But since the new location opened the service here is not so great.  I mean everyone is nice, just lots of new faces training.  The last 4-5 times here, they always mess up on our order.  Leaving out add-ons or messing up on the chashu buns orders.  It's not the kitchen staff messing up, it's the server not entering it in right.  They always always repeat right after each order, just not enter it in.  I believe next time, I'll be that person to double check the order before the server walks off.  I want my mild and black garlic oil, god damnit! Lol

mAjuZDEYBepv7KCa4HthuA.text: This is my favorite ramen joint in town. The only downside is that there is sometimes a wait to grab a seat considering it's smaller and very popular.   Even still, I salivate just thinking about the medium spicy miso ramen.  Whether you order takeout or dining in, the food is made very quickly once ordered.   The broth and noodles (which you can watch being made through a looking glass) keep me coming back for more.

GDgwmrTXNEWs3H4EaCXqbw.text: I really love the simplicity of their menu, its so approachable! Perfect for Ramen Newbies. The step by step process takes the guessing out of the equation and ultimately leads to you getting your food faster and their tables turning. Win-win.   I dragged my guy over from cafe rio and into Kobo because a little birdie told me that they make their own noodles! The quality really shines.  We started with chicken steam buns, I could eat 10 of them they were so tasty! Perfect bun, crispy chicken light dressing.  For the ramen I opted for the vegetarian option while hubby went with pork and added ground chicken. Even at opposite ends of the spectrum these bowls were equally balanced, savory and most importantly everything was fresh. Next time I think I'll add black garlic.   Mild is medium here so start at a lower level- you can always add more spice!   5 stars for quality, freshness, ambience and customer service. I'll be back.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States

6f138K6xN0w8RWFbgl5-bA.text: I was surprised at how much I enjoyed this place!  The Ramen I got was delicious, reasonably priced, and serving size was perfect for me.  The restaurant is SUPER tiny tho, so expect to wait a bit to be seated.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States

3czLbTpr1SIGBVKD6xbDBw.text: Haven't been here for awhile since it opened. We ordered Shoyu ramen with chasu pork and their fried rice. Fried rice was good as before. Quite disappointed with the ramen bowl. Noodle for me was over cooked. The texture was too soft. There was no green garnish, egg in the bowl, bean sprouts that would traditionally come with a ramen bowl. Not sure if my expectations are high as I am comparing them to neighboring ramen restaurants. We felt rush. Server kept reaching over then asking if we were done. I am pretty sure he was turning tables as dinner rush came in but literally we sat for 30 minutes couldn't even relax after eating. That's what happens when they have such a small restaurant.

vm9eba6e4rKSssdcEDiNTQ.text: Sat at the bar. Ordered two ramen and two orders of small rice. I had the shoyu ramen and my wife had the tonkotsu. Both with nitamago and served at the same time along side the fried rice. The porkbelly bowl came a lot later.   My shoyu turned way better than my wife's tonkotsu. I was able to just order my ramen with mild spice so it wouldn't be too spicy. Fried rice was your typical egg and pork fried rice. But the porkbelly, perfectly seasoned and they wasn't light with the sesame oil.   Our server was really nice, polite. Food 5/5. Coming back for sure.

dc8nEbmy7UvilkhyVICYaA.text: I like Ramen Kobo. The fact that I don't have to drive another 10 minutes to get decent ramen is also a bonus. Parking can be iffy, but it was well worth it to me. I've been able to eat there and order take out. For the most part everything is good, sometimes the broth is bland but other than that I do enjoy it.  I also like that that there is ground pork and not just the fatty pork slices. Adding spice is definitely another plus...but you know this girl can't handle too spicy anyways. Most of my friends are able to handle the spicy though and it definitely looks spicy! I definitely think the pork belly is a dish to get though. I enjoy that more than the ramen sometimes and I always order it. Overall, I'm glad that it's opened near me and the bathroom is pretty nifty.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork belly bowl....delish!!
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu ramen to go
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu ramen

8hp6KZHRJpDPM3ReHcsJcA.text: I've been here several times now, so I feel like it's time to review it. I love that they are open a little later than other restaurants in the area and honestly being down the street from me helps. If this place was 10 minutes further away would I have gone so often? Honestly no. The noodles and broth are above average but not amazing. I love spicy food, but "fire" varies each time I go. For example, I've had it where I would rate it a medium all the way to fire. I thought that it was just me, but another party asked the same thing one night. They were told that it depends on the peppers. All of the staff is very friendly. I love the concentrated menu, but not serving gyoza is odd to me. (Not that I'm a ramen expert, but it seems to be standard at most other places.)  My biggest concern right now is that they don't seem to balance to go orders and in house orders well. Today, I got there during a to go rush, so I waited 25 minutes for my soup. Most of the time it is around 10-15 minutes. My guest said that it may have been the time of day, but I watched 13 to go soups go in a row before ours was made. After I heard to go orders asking if theirs was done yet because it was past their quoted time. They had been working on in house orders to catch up. Now, they are much busier. I am curious if they will keep up with the demand.

fFRwhv3fzyT0qIlBaQ4IZw.text: I came here with my friends super excited to show them this restaurant.. But unfortunately when we were done eating we were rudely told we had to leave, and mind you this is RIGHT after we paid, i couldn't even finish my conversation at dinner with my friends before we had to leave. Service there pissed me off and ever since i will NOT go back nor do i suggest this place until they hire new workers.

KwRJV4ndV_t8FuqYlgQwkA.text: Super tasty ramen.  Comes in several spice levels mild to fire.  I got hot and that was just about right.  Add egg & extras for a cost.  Very small dining area so be sure to come on off hours.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States

D7_oQ1aTkTvSwddSWqHaLQ.text: BEST PLACE EVER! Such a great experience. You can watch the ramen noodles being made, the ramen soup all around is amazing! Perfect amounts of everything in your soup. I will definitely be going out of my way for this ramen. I'm obsessed!

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. HOT Miso Ramen

cbDyPyEmpGrPbTUk8cdyBw.text: Finally got to check out Ramen Kobo. The service is excellent, they're friendly and quick. Was a little surprised that they didn't have any appetizers on their menu. Usually Gyoza is a staple at ramen restaurants even in Japan. It's always nice to munch on Gyoza while you wait for your ramen. Luckily, the wait for ramen was really short. The ramen came out quickly and piping hot. I ordered the Tonkotsu ramen with soft boiled egg. The broth in itself was very flavorful though a little too thick in consistency for my liking. They only give one piece of chashu which was a little odd because most ramen restaurants give you a couple slices at least. The noodles were very good. They weren't too soft nor too hard. Love that they make them fresh in house. I also ordered a side of kimchi and it's the kind of Japanese style kimchi that I love so I gobbled that all up. They put on their menu that they include bamboo shoots in their ramen but they're very thinly sliced and sparse. I usually like the thick slices bamboo shoots in my ramen.   Overall, Ramen Kobo wasn't bad. The service was very good and it's a good place to grab a quick bite to eat. Was the ramen my favorite? No, but I will bring my mom in when she comes to town to give it a try and see what she thinks. I just like the fact that they make the noodles in house, can't find that everywhere.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu ramen original style
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu ramen mild spice level
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States

1Cn25hdn22T6ZYwaJbAqUA.text: I have been coming to this place since they opened their doors a few years ago and have not been disappointed yet.  I have a few spots I go to but this one is definitely on my list as a go to spot!  The noodles are made fresh and typically you will see them making them in the front.  The staff is always friendly and happy to help you.  This place is a very traditional Ramen house, small, small menu and inviting. If you are looking for a large menu traditional Ramen houses aren't for you. The default bowl you get comes with just about everything you want, I myself like egg and nori which are extra here and its no big deal.  The portion sizes are generous and typically I don't finish the whole bowl. I will also spend the extra 1.00 to get extra noodles for my left over broth and have another meal later.  The flavors are well put together and I like this place because they give you a choice in spice level where some places don't...I love there medium but I like spicy and I have tried their hot once and yes...its hot.    Check them out great food great staff and great atmosphere!

sOcFxQSeDQtfkCgOsFlC_g.text: This place is awesome! Very small menu selection but everything was amazing! I love that all the noodles are fresh too. It kind of sucks because all the toppings are extra money... Their chashu isn't very good.. It's literally a piece of fat. The egg and nori however is amazing!  I also ordered the kimchi rice which was super delicious! One bowl of ramen was perfect for me and my friend to split and be full.   The inside is super small, kind of like monta ramen. The staff are extremely friendly and attentive. They also kept my water full constantly which is a plus.  Great service and great ramen! :)

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States

XgEDesKwApK6XbJXULv3XA.text: Introducing a brand new west side ramen house are the creators of Monta Ramen. Monta being the last review I wrote I was a bit excited, sort of, to see if this would be any different. To my satisfaction it truly was a delightful experience. It's in a plaza off of Durango not very far from the brand new Ikea store that was built. True to form , it was busy with people waiting, and a list for you to put your name on, but that's pretty standard in every Ramen House; at least any worth dining at.  An Original side note from anywhere else; they are also a noodle-making factory. As you wait in the front when you sign in, you can look through the glass and watch the gentleman/his machine and lots of fresh noodles. The restaurant was very clean, with everything open on display, so you'd be able to tell exactly how organized and clean they really are. Even the bathrooms, that's right,  it gets five stars across the board. As always I ordered a medium Spicy Miso Ramen with nothing extra so I could give you a review on exactly how it tasted as it came. All I can tell you in one word is DELICIOUS!!!! I enjoyed the broth much more than I did before and the fusion of flavors was very palatable. Just like Monta I love their Kimchi Fried Rice , but it was much milder than I expected.   My boyfriend and I shared the pork bowl which is always a favorite for us. Kobo's pork belly was lighter is color, just like if you were to prepare it at home. Where as what I'm used to, it is darker brown like a barbecue type pork, regardless it was very very good. Ramen Kobo is definitely not bland in flavor, as all of their spices mesh into a delightful symphony in your mouth. Begging you to sing another song. It's a very Quaint restaurant, though I've never been to a large one. Size didn't take away from their character, as all of their friendly staff, made it so pleasant to dine there. I truly enjoyed the food and they experience and I would definitely rate it higher than Monta Ramen.  I vote five stars for Ramen Kobo and thank them for such a wonderful dining experience. It's my pleasure to recommend Kobo's to anyone on the west side and even if you're not, you won't be disappointed....

_TYp5cNjiFbCQmvsr6fpww.text: Being a Monta ramen maven, I had to check out the newest offering from what's a supposedly related ramen stop.    The place is newer and more modern looking than what I'm used to at Monta and there was even a noodle flattening and cutting machine in operation.  Kinda cool!  Like a field eating trip all in one!    In taking to the waiter, the place is a totally different ramen style than Monta.  Not sure why he was emphasizing it is so different but it was tasty.  Had the "standard" and "mild" tonkotsu pork broth.  Really rich flavor but there is a difference between the standard and "mild-medium-hot-fiery".  For one, the taste is not just spicier but the flavor is different too.  Also the broth is a red color not the dark eggshell color.    I liked them both and the fried rice is the same goodness.  Kind of a lot of starch for one sitting but hard to pick which bite to take next!  The other thing that was pretty cool was their electronic menu at the front counter.  Cool gadget and would be cooler if you could place your orders that way too.  Mostly locals here and prices were reasonable.  And lastly, in the dead heat of summer, this place dies have waiting room seats for six and ample room for another four comfortably near the noodle factory room window area :)  It's worth checking out for something new and different!

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Here&#39;s the mild tonkotsu with extra nori, corn and some oil - I forget after a late night yesterday...
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Noodle making machine!  A first for me :)  and order your ramen with &#34;extras&#34;!

cVAj7Est2cwOhSKyoWN54g.text: Some of the best Ramen in Vegas. Can get busy at peak times, so get here early. Parking in front can be a challenge, but plenty available behind the building.

0CCLibdZbZLqET0gqDSKiQ.text: This is a cute little ramen shop in the Southwest Part of town. It's very small, always packed and not enough parking outside. As you walk in to the right is a glass room where fresh ramen is being made, though that was pretty awesome. This is one of the best ramen spots around town, I love the flavors they offer and you don't have to add extra flavors. I like to get the miso and medium. As an appetizer they offer a small and regular sized pork belly bowl which is my favorite thing on the menu. The size of the pork belly is perfect on top of a bed of rice and topped off with chopped green onions. I always fall in my order because it's always busy!

TadJVQrxAcDUBZgN1KJkSg.text: "Why didn't you stop me?" pants Midwest poker bud.  "You said, when it's hot outside, you need to eat hot, spicy food so you sweat and..." I trail off poorly holding back smug laughter.  Ramen KoBo, the newest offshoot of Monta Ramen.  Same great broths, same great noodles, same great toppings.  The  key difference, spicing up your ramen is encouraged.  Oh and noodles are made by machine, on site.  It has no bearing on the quality of the finished product.  Note:  this location is small owing to the walled off "fish bowl" where you can watch ramen being made.  Expect a wait.  Ordering is simple: choose a broth, pick a spice level, add extra toppings (bowls already have a single piece of chashu, seasoned mushrooms, bamboo shoots, and chives).  As with all Monta's, solid broths.  The tonkotsu stands out for their excellent extraction of in your pork flavor balanced with dashi and garlic, finishing with umame notes.  Gelatinous and palate coating.  Seriously, leave this alone.  The miso on the other hand is perfect for spicing up.  All broths contain MSG.    Heat is achieved through chili oil and ground chilies.  The spice, even at fire, doesn't drown but compliments the flavor of the broth by adding a chili sweetness and aroma.  Thai food lovers, fire = level three of five.   As already mentioned, solid noodles, cooked toothsome (unless you specify otherwise).  Tender and flavorful chashu with minimal fat.  Though pricier than Monta, a basic bowl is $9, with added chashu and nitamago (soft boiled seasoned egg), $13.  Still a good value.

hMLBv-5c3HIvaZRiicWWUQ.text: I feel like I'm a broth girl. I'm very big on broth. And lucky for Ramen Kobo, I was impressed with their regular miso soup ramen. The noodles were thick and delicious. Even the pork was good and I feel like I'm picky when it comes to liking any kind of pork found in ramen.  I just feel like the temperature of the food could have been a tad bit hotter upon first taste. I would much rather have my food burning hot and wait for it to cool down than to receive it luke warm.  I'm willing to give this place another shot since it's so close to my house and I have an obsession with noodles and soup.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkatsu mild with added egg

GoQJWmbnMdSIE184lQmPsg.text: I've come to Kobo for a while now, and sadly, today they broke the Japanese rule of taking the dishes away and dropping the bill.  They took my bowl away without asking when I wasn't finished.  They dropped the bill when my friend wasn't even halfway finished with his ramen.  Makes me sad. The food was good until then.

9AQmeLM6q6oGhILqgnw75A.text: If I can give this place a zero star, I so would. I got off my job a little early because I knew they were closing soon.  I ordered my food (to-go) paid and tipped Joshua. Ordered a ramen NO SPICE and NO ONIONS. Got home to find out it's SPICY as hell and smothered in onions. Now my sick fiance has to suffer a little more thanks to these guys. NEVER COMING HERE AGAIN.

wlPzfXeRNopW_A7BMHyVrQ.text: Being a sister shop to Monta Ramen, I honestly came here with low expectations the first time I visited. Boy, was I so glad to be wrong!  Location: This is located in the southwest part of town next to Cafe Rio. When entering, you are able to see workers making fresh batches of noodles. However, the shop is very small. Aside from around 10 seats at the bar, there are only around 5 other tables in the rest of the shop. It is very tight with not much room to move around. They only seat full parties so be wary if you are bringing a big group. It will take a while to finally be seated. There is almost always a wait during peak hours, but I have never waited more than 20 minutes for a party of 2-3 because of how fast everything is.  Menu: The menu is short and sweet. You just choose your broth, spice level, and extra toppings you may want to add. All bowls of ramen come with Chashu pork, Kikurage black mushrooms, bamboo shoots, green chives, ground pork, sesame oil, and shredded red pepper. There are also other dishes to eat like the pork belly bowl and kimchi fried rice.  Food: Be careful about the spice! The mild spice already has some kick to it, so be wary of the spice level you choose. Broth is rich and has a lot of flavor, but is not nauseatingly fatty. The noodles are very thick and capture the taste of the broth very well. There is also a decent amount of ground pork and a huge slab of chashu. There is enough where you have some with almost every bite, but does not overpower the dish itself. The portions are very big for a price of around $10 without any add-ins. Thankfully, adding additional ingredients are for a reasonable price & I always leave the shop feeling very satisfied and full. I've been dying to try their non-ramen dishes, but I always end up opting for ramen last minute. Hopefully soon, I could break this curse and finally give them a try!  Service: Workers are very nice, prompt and accommodating. Food comes out fast and I don't think they have ever gotten my order wrong from the many times I've visited. I never felt rushed or pressured to leave, though they do a great job at ensuring wait times are not horrendous.  The quality of the ramen and the genuinely kind workers are what convince me to frequently make the 30 minute drive from where I live to eat at Ramen Kobo. This establishment deserves more attention than it is currently getting. I truly believe this is one of the best ramen shops in town!

N_h8ITLpKQLHc06UjS2o4Q.text: I can't get enough of this ramen! Noodles are made onsite.  Spicy level is perfect!  Staff is friendly and efficient.

Eg4Bl-8z3ZX8LN1ZFYDFZA.text: I fucking love this place. The service is great and the food is alwaysss amazing! My partner and I usually order vegan ramen and fried rice to share. Never disappointed with Kobo!

NFyXhYhDP2K-9xZ70XuQkw.text: Pros: Place was ok.  The soups are consistent.   Cons: -The staff always look so frazzled. -Very tight -There's always a line because the restaurant can only accommodate no more than 20 people inside at a time (6 on countertop, 14 in dining floor). -Menu is limited to mostly PORK. -Because staff works hard to turn table around fast, the tables are often grossly sticky. -If you happen to be seated towards the back, you can smell the bathroom.  The place is decent but I wouldn't hold my breath just to get a table. I prefer to go to Ohjah noodle house just a block away.

erpFAoFs3EuHQnrlVFN6ww.text: An authentic local ramen bar I can rely on for all my ramen needs! Being my 5th visit, I thought it was due time for one of these. I usually get the Tonkotsu mild, or medium - spicy (depending on how daring I am that day), kimchi rice and Asahi.   Each time I visit I feel welcomed and never rushed. Service is prompt and dishes come out in a timely manner. Most ramen bars I've been to, servers are either new and can't handle stress very well... or aren't new and could care less about hitting the bare minimum of service. I feel like this spot hits all their points making it a pleasant experience.  I give it 4 stars only because I prefer having freshly boiled and yolk-y egg, but it's always cold in my ramen each time I go.. Anyway, try it yourself!

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. 2 Mild Tonkotsu Ramen

JS9PpdRNpKcuEqDxyVlusQ.text: Great Ramen with fresh made noodles made right in house. The pork fried rice...lets just say I always order one to eat there and another one to take home, yes it's that Delicious! The only thing that was disappointing was that they don't have gyoza (potstickers) like they do at Monta (their sister restaurant) or other ramen places.   I had the Miso Ramen, medium heat level with extra chashu pork and added corn and green onion. It was so good. Their ramen comes standard with the sliced black mushrooms so I asked them to not put it in my bowl. I live across town but it was worth the drive and have gone back 3x total now.

RpDWYcFS2hFlRaZxwHxeBw.text: This is by far the BEST Ramen in Las Vegas!! Beware, it's HOT Ramen, so got easy on the spice your first visit! I crave KoBo everyday!

P23sbUuE7ibT3ipelDLD7w.text: Weve been coming here since the opening day. My wife and i always like the ramen, except for one thing. Its this one server that everybody is complaining about who has the worst costumer service of all  the entire staff here. Shes loud and doesnt let you finish when ordering your food. Its like she will finish your order for you. What happen to listening to costumer 1st before you open your mouth. We love their ramen but we just have to deal with her everytime. Well i just hope that the management will sit down and talk to her or train her the proper way of serving costumers.

7N-8dlkUA87gECc9pF2QDw.text: Good ramen, place is always packed though. Every time I go, there's always a wait. But worth it. I like the pork belly bowl and tonkutso ramen.

Lhy9D9YbVWVnkD2gkczs9A.text: I'm a total fan of this place. We came here on a Tuesday night before watching a movie. The restaurant is a bit small so make sure you don't come during peak hours. There wasn't a wait when we got there right when it opened at 5 pm, but when we left there were people outside patiently waiting for their table. The food here was delicious, which is what I expected since they're part of the Monta Ramen group! I would definitely come back for the Ramen.   FOOD: We had the Tonkatsu Ramen, which was phenomenal! The noodles were perfect. The soup was tasty and not too salty. I picked a medium spice level, so make The Chashu Pork was soft, tender and fatty.   We also got the Kim Chi fried rice that was also yummy. I read other reviews saying it was a must-try, but I wouldn't consider this the highlight of the restaurant. I believe this place deserves a bravo for their Ramen!   PRICE: Everything was less than $10. The bill for three of us was $40. It's a great value for delicious food.   SERVICE: The service was great. Everyone was efficient and fast! When we asked the server for her opinion of the food, she recommended yummy dishes and was honest about the items she didn't recommend. The food arrived within a timely manner as well.   Overall, it was a great experience and I rate this place 4 out of 5 stars. I would come back here to try the other ramen soups!   Happy Dining,   J Tran
