wTvjrSbH-kgKlSmZg8zv9Q.text: Great small ramen place. Service was super quick. There was a bit of a wait when we got there  (a couple parties ahead of us) but they get service done so quickly that you really don't have to wait long. We also enjoyed watching the man make the ramen noodles.  Oh! Also the buns were amazing!!

kLcs-EPXNsccwBip43beug.text: Ramen Kobo is one of my favorites if not my favorite place to eat Ramen in Las Vegas. Mainly due to the fact that their noodles are made fresh in house daily. I generally sit at the bar where I can watch the cooks whip up Fresh batch for me. They do serve beer too. No complaints !

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States

B_Q3bVdH9RX1t8YU-Xa0ZA.text: I ordered the Shoyu Ramen in chicken broth, mild but surprised to see the soup reddish and had chili flakes Tasting just the soup, I would say it's more of a medium than mild which I don't mind but I intended to share with someone who does not like spicy food. The basic toppings consist of chashu pork, 1 whole clove fried garlic, kikurage black mushrooms, bamboo shoots, green chives, moyashi (bean sprouts), ground pork and shredded red pepper (thats where the chili flakes came from). Other choices are Tonkatsu Ramen (pork broth), Miso Ramen (pork & chicken broth) and Vege Ramen in vegetable broth/toppings.   The toppings, ramen noodle and the reddish colored soup all tasted awesome. Full of flavor but not salty. The noodle is how I expected a homemade noddle would be. I would definitely come back and try the other toppings and soup types.   After looking at the photo of the menu more carefully, it looks like there are 5 choices (original, mild, medium, hot & fire) not 4 as I originally thought  I should've ordered the original.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu ramen togo without the broth.
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu mild broth for n togo container.
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. My Shoyu ramen togo. Expecting more broth than noodle, I ordered two &#34;extra noodles&#34; for $1.50 each.

qe7180oG291pYcLtw_j2rg.text: Before this I used to go to Monta Ramen when visiting family in LV.  The only type of ramen I eat is Tonkotsu broth based. This place now ranks right under my #1 ramen spot which is tied between the Ajisen Ramen chain (because of the Ajisen Special ramen with spice bow) and Tampopo Ramen in Tempe, AZ.  First of all, they make their noodles in-house just like at Tampopo, and have one of the limited number of noodle making machines in the USA as well, I have only seen 3, Tampopo in Tempe AZ, Underground Ramen in SF, and this one, so it's always exciting. As expected, the noodles were top notch, and the broth was only below the best by the slightest of margins.  The thing that put this place at 5 stars for me was the fried pork belly that I ordered with my side of fried rice, O.M.G!!! That was soooooo good.  I requested that it's be crispy and it did not disappoint. Order fried rice with a  side of crispy pork belly when you go.  In conclusion, I love this place and will not be going back to Monta when I am in LV, just because Ramen KoBo is now on my list of not only faves in LV but top in my list overall.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Crispy Pork Belly was the star and everything else was excellent

_Cs_LLemxff5z8LsSgsb8g.text: Absolutely delicious! The best ramen house that I've been too. Everyone was very nice and fast service. And they make their noodles in house, definitely can taste the difference.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States

sWl85ywoDdlhWGoM0sQsqA.text: Not bad , first time eating here and if your feeling under the weather perfect spot for freshly made ramen. And the make it there. Definitely recommend this place . I travel allot and sample everything at least once .

AdbmWDaLnsnbC2qRSnd8Cg.text: Best ramen in town! Everything is fresh! Not like the other places I have tried where it tastes commercial. They make the noodles in the restaurant! Fried rice is on point! Can't go wrong here!

Q2D3OPEykrjPeoqXKq8inw.text: My first time eating ramen and I was definitely not disappointed, Super cheap and the staff is really friendly.

IvWMwO-6OMWSZcUN2JUBkw.text: We love this place!  Fresh and yummy!! My only complaint is the "hot tea" comes in a "hot aluminum can" which I don't think is safe for health reasons.  I would prefer to drink out of glass water glasses not plastic.  And have a tea pot with tea bags. Plastic, styrofoam, hot aluminum is alllll super toxic people and when heated leeches chemicals into your food.

10REfhFE7C1pKpUnHqYGEw.text: I love the miso (pork/chicken broth combo)! I order this without spice because I like the pure taste of the broth. The noodles are delicious so **TIP** request extra noodle if you're extra hungry. It's only $1.50! Additional add-ins can get pricey, but I suggest adding nori and corn.  The seating area is small with a few tables and bar-like seating along the kitchen. I would only recommend groups of 2-4 to dine here.

9D70SLWLy_BNBK33cCoNWw.text: My favorite ramen shop! Wonderful food and inexpensive. The noodles are bouncy and delicious paired with the flavorful broth is absolute perfection. Their pork belly bowl and pork fried rice are also my top picks along with the miso ramen medium is the perfect meal for me. Sometimes I also get the iced green tea which pairs perfectly with the food. I highly recommend this place! Also, their customer service is always on point!

19V2Z4wtFOc8pacN2kbg5w.text: This ramen shop definitely surprised me after reading and viewing all the reviews on here.  The broth is not exactly like Monta but good enough.  They do provide one slice of chasu BUT there is ground/minced pork(spicy) in the shoyu and tonkatsu options.  It is conveniently located in the south west of town which is great when I am craving a ramen fix and can't go all the way to Monta.     The  Mentaiko bowl is a great side dish for a change of pallet.  How is your slurp game?!?

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Mentaiko bowl

Muj1Qv8S-mnxpOWX2L2SrA.text: As a lover of Monta, their sister ramen spot in the Southwest side of town didn't disappoint. Similar to Monta, it's fairly small without a ton of seating (4-5 tables to sit families of 4, and bar seating), and I've only had to wait at most maybe 30 minutes.   Friendly customer service. 4 different soup bases: shoyu (chicken), tonkotsu (pork), miso (chicken + pork), and a vegetarian bowl. They all come with a decent amount of toppings, and you can also ask for extra toppings. You can pick how spicy you want your broth: not spicy, mild, medium, and hot. As for their extra dishes, I've only had their Pork Belly Bowl so far, and it was amazing! Delicious, salty pork belly on top of garlic rice.   I've come here twice already, and I'm glad to have a good ramen spot so close to my house.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork belly bowl
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Mild miso with corn

e3Lmh0M3WZqRhH7EQ72NoQ.text: I returned to my quest to find the greatest ramen in Las Vegas this week. The specialty that I noticed at Ramen KoBo was the spice level. I love spicy so I naturally had to go fire for the level. I then went with my go to tonkatsu and added some spicy roe as I'd never seen that as a topping option.   Price is the same as anywhere else in Vegas. I feel that the chefs have all just called each other up and set a price to $9 with additional topping prices varying.   The soup itself was the spiciest broth I have ever had - fantastic. My eyes and nose were running which is what I hope for when ordering top spice level. The noodles weren't that great compared to other ramen spots and the chasu, though good, was portioned very small. The roe were quite a nice addition so I'm glad I added that in. It gave the dish a nice extra layer. This ramen also included some ground prom which I didn't notice at first but was good since it made me feel less ripped off meatwise by the lack of chasu. This ramen was smaller than most with less noodles as your typical Vegas ramen front. I actually like that better because it seems that most places waste the entire bowl on noodles and less on extras whereas KoBo puts more spirit into the variety of toppings.   KoBo is the best spot in town for a spicy broth. It will fill you up but won't get you bloated. They have salmon roe which I liked but the noodles weren't the greatest. Overall it filled my ramen craving and would be my #1 destination if I'm looking to burn my stomach on tonkatsu ramen.

fTshYcNjoRXsEZomqxn20A.text: 1. The noodles taste like no other noodles in this town. It was awesome trying something new. 2. I got the fire spicy and it was really spicy. I would have to say it beat the level of spicy ness out of all the ramen places I've tried except Ramen Sora. 3. The broth is rich, which I loved. 4. The boiled eggs are perfect.  The presentation is not as fancy as some other places, but the flavor definitely beats most Ramen places I've tried.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States

YHRkjcI4SQgzWLQF70zv-w.text: New fave ramen spot! The spice is what makes it really yummy. I will say Monta Chaya has better fried rice but this place has the better ramen. I love that they hand-make their noodles!

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States

rha-wZRXjz5vPLk5f4SU2w.text: Awesome ramen place on the west side!! I went here on a Friday night around 6:30 & it was packed. I don't think you can make reservations, or at least you can't through Open Table, I didn't call and ask but I'm assuming not. So get there early or at least be prepared to wait a bit.   While your waiting you do get to watch the noodles being made which is really cool.   It didn't take long to get a spot at the bar since there were just two of us. The ramen was amazing, we both ordered Veggie Ramen and added egg, mushroom & bean sprouts. Our order came very quickly & it was soooo good! Perfect for a chilly windy Vegas night.   The ambiance is exactly what you would expect from a ramen spot, clean, light & minimal decor. It was super busy so it was a bit noisy, but not annoyingly so. Our server was great & super friendly.   Can't wait to go back

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States

B3G9XeprYjd0uukiHnX_Mg.text: First time trying this place out. Mainly because of their homemade ramen. Which turned out to be delicious and was definitely a hit with the kids as well!  Though the soup of my original Tonkatsu Ramen was a bit salty for my taste buds, I still finished my bowl, while hubby enjoyed his Tonkatsu Ramen Mild Spice level. As for the Pork Belly Bowl, hubby and I enjoyed the pork belly meat, but the kids didn't seem to like the rice. Perhaps next time we'll ask for the sesame oil sauce on the side (if that's possible).

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkatsu Ramen (Mild Spice)
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkatsu Ramen (Original)
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork Belly Bowl

9pC2UZxoArdNwHc_NxdzBQ.text: Ramen is 7/10 Consistent most of the time, broth is lighter when it's busy on the weekend.  Pork belly in rice is good as well  Get there when it's not so busy. Wait times can be a minute.   Order in if your hungry when it's busy. Wouldn't have to wait so long

63EOx47QK5vY5uzMuPfvMA.text: VEGAN RAMEN option for the win!! We came one night around 9 and It seemed a little busy and... intimate. It isn't a huge restaurant and the seating was limited, but very comfortable. The hostess was friendly and sat us right away.   They have a small beer menu, no wine though. We ordered our ramen with all the fun fixes! It came out Fresh, hot, and spicy! Did I mention they make their own noodles?! The portions are big! We had plenty of left overs which tasted great the next day! The price is fair and I will definitely be returning again... especially on the bone chilling days of the coming winter :)

Df3Fae2HzA5imP6VOHx-Gw.text: Ramen KoBo is a small but cozy restaurant. While I'm not entirely a fan of their Ramen, I really love their rice bowls! The pork belly bowl is my favorite. (I always get a side of an egg as well) The food always comes out fast, and the consistency is always the same. If they could add more items to their menu, such as dessert items, I think that would be interesting! Sometimes after eating, I'm craving something sweet, but they don't really have any dessert. Other than that, the fact that it's also close to home is a plus!

6h2sTvsUmWXovy7ieb1dHA.text: I have tried a lot of ramen places in Las Vegas and this one is my favorite. The service is friendly and fast. The prices are reasonable and it is so flavorful. It is tiny inside so sometimes there is a wait but it's worth it. The vegan ramen and the miso ramen are my favorite. All of their appetizers are really good.

DQ9reGwQvQlu_XzErI4e0Q.text: KoBo is my all time favorite and go to spot for ramen. I love the simple but ramen focused menu. No, there isn't gyoza but the fresh noodles, variety in soup bases and the rice bowls make up for it. The pork belly buns are great too.   I'm a big fan of the tonkatsu ramen and it's a plus to be able to have them put the spice on the side if you aren't sure about what your belly can handle. I always get a side of either kimchi fried rice or a pork belly bowl. They are must haves and also great if you're too lazy to pack a lunch for work the next day.  Everything is extremely reasonably priced and yes, sometimes you have to wait but it's totally worth every minute.  The service is great and the food is always delicious. I have turned many friends onto KoBo and many have turned it into their go-to ramen spot. Definitely a big fan of KoBo and they never disappoint!

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkatsu ramen - mild spice - extra chashu - add egg

sVPzVGyVJ81zqcFGumYT1g.text: Great food! Great Price! Excellent customer service! Parking: lots Interior: small, clean, bar is good to eat on spacious. You can watch them make fresh noodles while you wait. And they all use gloves.   You can watch them prep and cook your food in the bar area.   I try and stay way from flour, gluten, but this place is great, I had to try it!!  Thank you Mitch for a great dinner!!

Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States

XTMhLK2rp-ar63m0rV_qqA.text: This place has great ramen. It has great pork buns. The food is great. The fact that you don't have to wait 40 minutes for a seat is even better. I still think Monta has the best noodles, soup, and chashu. But I hate their parking lot and the wait.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Original tonkotsu with extra chashu.

yTyOZph_1m77SnBSCy9kzw.text: The ramen here, to me, isn't really that special or unique. I was hoping for good flavor but it was a little salty in not a good way. The noodle had a good bite (which was what I wanted), but the chashu in my soup was cold. I just wasn't a fan and really left wanting my favorite ramen spot in the Bay Area, Ramen Dojo.

nGI41A3zoYRNeJCqSP-8Qg.text: I've been to this Ramen restaurant several times, and while the food is very tasty, the wait staff was incredibly rude to my boyfriend. While he was waiting for me to park  the car in the parking lot right outside the restaurant he was told to leave the bar he had just sat down at during a time the restaurant was not busy and there was no wait.   Management needs to review this policy, as it is understandable they cannot hold seating for someone who isn't present during a time when the restaurant has a long wait, but it is just inconsiderate when the restaurant is empty.

hfQ9S-nJG44rXjW4EsIgIw.text: My cousin took me to Ramen KoBo one evening when I was in town visiting. They have both bar and table seating, but they aren't that big of a restaurant. Anyway, the night we went, we called ahead to check what time they closed, and they said they would be closing at 11 PM. It was around 9 PM when we had called. However, when we got there, they said they were about to close! They still decided to seat us, but just barely after we ordered, they were already shoving the bill at us, saying they needed to close the register. Why bother seating us then? Meanwhile, other customers that came in after us were also very confused that the staff were closing the place really early, and were given abrupt responses as well.   As for the food, they have four different broths you can choose from, which include certain toppings depending on which broth you pick. Then you can pick how spicy you want your broth, and any additional toppings you want to add.The ramen we had ordered was good, but I cannot get over the rude staff. I don't think I'll be coming here again.

CnGJXpMLlNbRxvKnN3pfNA.text: I can't say enough great things about this place.  The food is beyond amazing.  The location is small but still very worth the wait. I love that they make their own noodles from scratch and the menu has a variety of options.  Price is very reasonable.  A must try.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Back again.  Can&#39;t get enough of this place. The noodles are coming out next.

YeQuzt2F1-7AFVZhs_6uzg.text: First time here and it was pretty good. The place is always super packed but now that I've gone inside, I see why. Small space but service moves quickly. The Miso Ramen and Shoyu Ramen with mild spice was pretty yummy for a cold night indeed! I had the egg as an add on and I was not thrilled about it. Will revisit!

M1mOkLHYaYTcY1iTSG5cWA.text: I love Ramen KoBo!  I went here once to just check out a new spot and this became an instant favorite.  I want to say we come here at least twice a month.  It's so nice an delicious, especially during the cold weather.   Because this can easily become a ramble, i'll show a bunch of different points as a list. -Their noodles are so tasty and made in house.  It is such a treat if you get to see them being made.  -Their pork chashu is so good, both in the broth and in the chashu buns.  -I absolutely love the fact that I can choose how spicy you want your ramen.  Although I love the original tonkatsu, my boyfriend likes his food a little spicy so he always goes with fire. -The service is always great! I've never had a bad experience with anyone. -The only down side is it can definitely get busy, and I understand why.  I can honestly say, it is worth the wait!   Do yourself a favor and try it, at least once.  You won't regret it!

b3ZtH2V-vk-4gZCOJZkiLw.text: KoBo gets all the hype for their house made noodles. I usually say ramen joints have good ramen and better appetizers and this is that to me. Maybe I need to try the non-spicy ramen but this ramen didn't do it for me.   The ramen was good. It was a little thin and light for me. I like heavy milky ramen but that's a personal preference. I did do spicy with the ramen and it made it taste like a Coconut curry soup dish that is Thai and Laotian. The pork belly was okay and the broth itself was good.  The appetizers they offer are good to me though. My assumption with KoBo is that they are greeted towards an eat and leave type of establishment. They have a simple menu with a handful of appetizers and you just order, eat, and leave.  I give them kudos for staying open late for late diners. If I'm in the area I'll stop in for a ramen craving, but not driving across town. Solid place.

vrIGPvpiqknrtbiYsk0IEg.text: Every time I come to Vegas. I enjoy all the different Asian food. My buddy is a local and always takes me to the good spots. Vegas some of the best Chinese, Korean Vietnamese and Japanese food far away from the strip.  This Ramen place was great. I have had better tasting broths but this one is definitely tasty. I got double  order of noodles and meat. I was stuffed with the noodle portion that it came with but I definitely took it with me and ate it later.  This broth had a creamy red look to it depending how spicy. It was a little thick for me. I got hot and it was fine.   I was not too crazy about the meat (pork). I like my pork crispy/pork bellish. This was round cut slices that had a weird texture. Don't get me wrong I ate all of it.  Did I mention noodles made from scratch!  Definitely a place to try if you are in town. As always it fits my requirements, whole in the wall and lots of love in the food. Small place with an open kitchen, serving it quick.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Simple menu. Get extra

HGkmvtnQkcT60_JA7PIK1g.text: This place has the best pork belly bowl and ramen! They got fresh noods and their ramen soup i would say it's "the BOMB"!!!!!!!!!!!!!.... they're open certain times so just make sure you check their hours of operation. Their pork buns are good too 2 for $5 . Everything on the menu is a must try!

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States

37u2nbS_rezrLLJIHFxsUA.text: Dinner on opening day, Shoyu ramen times two. The first shoyu ramen ordered the original way and the second, due to dietary restrictions, side pork items only with soft boiled egg and veggie broth instead. Tasted great, but restaurant could not substitute pork for chicken for me and would charge to do so. I wasn't trying to obtain something for free but thought it would have been a compromise at least with a piece of chicken and still charge me $2.50 even if I declined the pork items ?! That did not sit well with me. This restaurant is similar to Monta entree availability. It's okay but maybe they should be more flexible w orders or have a build your own soup / noodle bowl.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Ramen Kobo menu
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Regular shoyu ramen

ZuHWBGwsJoNePzz-e7aXGg.text: It was my first time here and my experience was so-so, bordering on nice.  First, the ramen. I ordered tonkotsu ramen, with extra noodles and black garlic oil on the side. At first glance, the bowl was aesthetically pleasing, and looking at it will make you hungry. The first thing I tasted was the stock. This stock was light and on the creamier side of pork bone soup. My only gripe with this is that the stock was a bit too light. All the toppings overpowered the broth and stood out too much. Any addition of the black garlic oil along with my second round of noodles overpowered the bowl completely. The noodles, however, were great: excellent bite out of the bowl, not too tough, not too soft. The noodles made much of the ramen eating experience.  Service was pretty nice. The lady at the front guided us to our seats and a young man took our orders. Our waters were refilled at a reasonable pace, food came out quick, and the staff was friendly.  If there was a half star option I'd give this a 3.5.

xt2H3mjKiiZZhtb_UQhRgw.text: Place: nice and clean, they just opened. Service: fast and friendly, there were many workers Noodle: Just okay. Not too bad. Broth: too much fat floating, some people liked it, I don't. Maybe they can have the customer choose the level of grease besides the level of spiciness too. Price: a bit pricey for the portion size. Overall, it's an okay place

zapKXiDWpD3UQuVam8EOsw.text: Too bad this place is so far from where I live, or I would probably come here daily. I ordered a small fried rice and a bowl of tonkatsu ramen with boiled egg and spinach. Everything was to the perfection level. I've been to Jinya, Monta and Sora, which are the 3 popular places for ramen, none of them was this good. I finished everything including the broth, noodles and toppings. And on top of that I finished the fried rice as well. I'm so glad I made the decision to drive 25 miles to try this place out. So worth it!

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Wiped the bowl
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Too good to not finish

2cDw9qBS306L2IwhtK3ePg.text: I am NEVER going back to this place.  Before I start, I have a 15 months old child who has several food allergies and he had been to the ER twice for food allergic reaction.   I used to go to Ramen Kobo since they have the best ramen in town (in my opinion). And their service was not so bad. But when I went to Kobo last time with my friend and my baby son, I was very upset. My son has some severe food allergies, so I need to pack his food whenever we go out to eat. He even reacts to some of the restaurants' rice bowl.  On that day, we had great food and were all ready to leave, the manager asked us if we were Korean. We were like um yes? And she said you can't bring any food for him here except baby food. I was so shocked. Dude, the airlines don't even charge babies under 2. I was like um okay? And when I got to my car, I was SO MAD! We went to the ER twice for my son's food allergic reaction. Was she gonna pay for the ER if he reacts to their food? She wasn't even nice and didn't smile when she talked to us. I was extremely angry I swore that I would NEVER go back to Kobo.

6bXLdsWnaKzl6bjJP3dSLQ.text: This place was suggested by my sister. Since I've been to Monte Chaya and had a bad experience with Ramen in the past, I was kind of iffy about coming here. We were seated right away which I know it's probably golden because the restaurant is pretty small and narrow. I know the wait time could take a while if the line was long. Luckily, when we were seated, the place filled up not to long after.  Down to the food...I ordered the chicken broth ramen, mild with an extra egg. The broth is so delicious! I never had ramen like this! Everything about the bowl was heavenly. From the daily made scratch noodles, the meat, the bamboo shoots, just everything together gave the soup the perfect bite and flavor. I never cleaned my bowl like that, not even when I eat pho! Even my 5 year old who is a picky eater had a small bowl of the soup and dived right into it.  As far as the service....they are fast, friendly and attentive. They are quick to refill drinks and not to mention, we barely had any wait time waiting for our food to arrive.  I love everything about this place: The prices are affordable, food is exquisite and service is excellent! Great experience trying this Ramen place. I'll will be back AGAIN for sure!

v7N144hZsoc0Cz_mEAsZiw.text: My favorite ramen restaurant in the city. I come to Kobo at least once a week and the staff is always friendly and welcoming. You really can't go wrong here whether you get miso, veg or tonkatsu. Make sure to add an egg cause that's the best part. You pick your spice level or leave it plain. If you're unsure of what spice you can handle you can always ask for it on the side and adjust the spice to your liking. This isn't really a long sit-down spot, more of an on-the-go lunch spot or somewhere to stop for a quick dinner. They serve canned teas, sodas, as well as draft and I believe bottled beer. No happy hour, but prices are so reasonable there doesn't need to be.

r8CSUrhbVNYpSVR10QDfsA.text: Loved this place! I have not been impressed with the ramen places I've tried but this one knocked it out of the park!

zC4npcsI3vpm-iCO2y4kQw.text: Love this place and the flavor. Very simple menu items which is fine with me. Very small dining area but the wait isn't surprisingly long. Good staff but my only concern is that I wished they would sanitize the tables after each party leaves. I saw them just wipe it down with a wet rag which was probably used for the table prior and the table before that. Tons of bacteria on that rag probably....Yuck...other than that the food is great.

yCXrStu5-XMlSQUTA7_FFw.text: Obsessed with this place!!! So delicious!! Went with a coworker during our lunch for the first time & we keep coming back! I'm craving it right now lol. Service is quick (well during lunch- typically 12pm) so we make it back in time to work. Taking everyone I know here- every chance I get!

lgxK1AvbuV_2wNOe6Ns9ug.text: This is really great Ramen. The quality is some of the best Ive had outside of Japan. My go-to is the Tonkatsu broth with sliced pork. The consistency of the ramen leaves much to be desired. I usually go with spicy but depending on the day the amount of spice will wildly fluctuate as will the amount of sliced pork you get. I really do love this place but it is a bit expensive for ramen. Other places will give you a few add-ons as part of the price of ramen but at Kobo you pay for anything extra. A bowl of ramen with 2-4 extras will run you $14-$16. If you order your food togo its usually done in 3-5 minutes depending on how busy they are.

XMkTYv-p-pKypZwTxsCkCw.text: This place is horrible..the miso ramen tasted  like dishwashing sponge juice. The pork belly bowl was also disgusting and what a waste of money. the service was none cause the waiter was in a rush to hear or even care about the food they are serving their customers. Why is this place a 4star?!!

lUvZoGkbxU3KBggY-i7KnQ.text: This is our favorite place to when we arrive in Vegas. We love the pork belly bowls here too!! And for the Hawai'i people they have sticky white rice!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso ramen with corn and butter

olBo3jr2QxA_zsOamcca6Q.text: Our family loves this little hole in the wall place! It's pretty new to our neighborhood but it definitely became one of our favorite places to go to grab a bite.  It's inexpensive. Cozy. Menu is simple but delicious!  My son devours their fried rice and I'm in love with their soups with homemade noodles (you can see how they make them, by the way. Their noodle making part of the kitchen is right by the entrance behind the glass wall. Awesome idea) You can choose how spicy you want your soup and they have great selections of add on items for it.  They won't seat you unless you have the whole party present, but it's due to very limited sitting.  Highly recommend it!

fyGbpZhhO962SDJFt6O9cw.text: Favorite ramen spot! Beats jinya for sure! They greet you when you walk in and the best part is the house made noodles and you can see them making them as you walk in! The offer a basic variety of vegetarian, chicken, and pork broths. The add-ins are awesome! I always get chicken broth with extra mushroom, butter, and can't forget the egg. Medium spicy is perfect for me. Definitely my go-to!

HrRTqVwA2KMrR2zLITO1Gg.text: Walked in on a busy Friday night. Opted to order to go. They have a tablet set up for take out orders which made it very quick and convenient. Ramen was delish.   Place is small, but very clean. No frills, straight to the point ramen joint. Will be returning again in hopes of dining in.

zYpQpD9kqrTyAYj5Yh3PNQ.text: I didn't like this place to much as a ramen place... I liked the fried rice and that's it.

dtYKyAYj20DTSyPMNds9aQ.text: The food was amazing, but the lady was not accommodating to our needs. We asked for a booth and they sat us at the bar, which we were okay but not once she offered to give us a booth when one is available. She simple said booths are no option, and the restaurant was not even full on a Sunday night.

W4OfjG7jEocWSXq9OvhK7g.text: Amazing vegan ramen. I loved the chili sauce and that they offer to put it on the side. Loads of great extras. Noodles are made in house and they are delicious. Service was Great and atmosphere was lovely. Can't wait to make another trip.

LmeplvynspeZl0hcr2cZwQ.text: Noodles are freshly made, delicious, & you definitely can taste the difference. Portions are a lot smaller than other ramen spots in town. So if you're starving I suggest adding extra meat, veggies, & noodles. The broth tastes amazing, just the right amount of thickness, not too salty, just perfect. This place is SUPER tiny (just like the portions, haha). Everyone is smushed together, but hey, try make friends! Definitely not a place for big groups or gatherings to go, but definitely a place to try!o

6www-Z_gQX6AYnHN-7klNQ.text: 5 stars for service, very Friendly staff! And the experience was cool (watching them make the noodles). I also liked that we had to sit so close to the other guests because it's a tiny place. Other than not being sure how to sit on the booth side because I didn't wanna slide my butt by anyone lol, we were almost forced to talk to the other couples next to us which turned into great conversation. but the food.. why we're all here.. was just ok. My friend didn't even finish is ramen. He said he wasn't impressed (he's a chef so he's had some good stuff) so said he'd rather have something else. We got the buns, which I'd give 4 stars. But we both agreed the broth was super bland and the noodles could have been a little more cooked. The couple to my left also commented on the almost flavorless broth

PJw0rtMVAkOA1w9Y7sV3vg.text: Love Ramen Kobo, they are friendly, quick and provide affordable prices for their customers.

N1od7l9QCdMSvit2p5X1jA.text: If you love Monta then there's no way for you to not like Ramen Kobo. The place is small just like Monta so be prepared to wait. We only had to wait for 15 minutes which was not too bad. The service is little to none. They seat and take your order and they don't come back until you are ready for your check.   I ordered my favorite which is the tonkatsu with the soft boiled egg. The soup and noodles were on point like always. The broth was super flavorful and the noodles were yummy. I don't know if this is becoming a trend with noodle places but the soft boiled egg is cold and precooked before hand. Am I the only one turned off by this? I dunno, I just like how it used to be freshly made in most places. They have red ginger and garlic you can add to the ramen which makes it more flavorful.   Definitely will come back since it's so close to home. Try the ramen spicy! It tastes great both ways depending on what you're feeling.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu ramen with a cold soft boiled egg, ughhh

3kdN4TTVl6UtQ-pa7lh1NA.text: I stayed at a friend's place with a bunch of other friends for our weekend trip in Vegas, and our friend recommended this place.  The menu is very simple and straightforward so nothing confusing on there! I ordered the Tonkotsu broth (came with black mushrooms, chives, bean sprouts, ground beef, pork shashu and bamboo shoots but I omitted the bamboo) with Hot spice level.  We didn't have to wait too long for our food, maybe 15 minutes before it came out. The broth was quite creamy, and since I enjoy spicy, the Hot level had a nice kick but not anything crazy for me. My favorite part were the noodles! They were nice and thin, and I could tell they were handmade.  Overall I really enjoyed the ramen here. It wasn't amazing, but it was good to the point where I would recommend it to others if you're craving ramen in the Vegas area!

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu ramen (spice level: Hot) comes with Chashu pork, green chives, black mushrooms, ground beef, bean sprouts, with bamboo omitted

VYlc28nzC_iKww7V-WwUwA.text: I love this place the mild spice tonkatsu with extra pork has my heart the noodles are always on point. The steamed dumplings are also vert good!!

AnnsYolFbMw-6AkpNElEAA.text: Now I am no Ramen Master like my friends that travel to Japan frequently, but I know a decent bowl when presented one. This was my second trip to this location and I was happy to be back. We managed to hit it during a low time and got seated at the bar right away. I ordered the pork belly fried rice appetizer and my co-worker ordered the pork belly over rice. As other people have stated, the chow readily flows from the kitchen with great haste. Both appetizers were excellent. I could eat the fried rice everyday if given the chance. Now on to the star of the show.  My co-worker and I both ordered the medium spicy tonkatsu ramen with extra pork, extra egg, and a various assortment of veggies. The broth was the perfect level of spice and amazing creaminess. It was hot but not scorching, temperature wise. Another popular place in Vegas disappointed me with mildly tepid broth the day before. I will save that for another review. The noodles were the perfect level of chewiness and absorbed just a bit of the broth. Kobo makes their own noodles and I love them. I wish they could dry them and sell them, so I could have them at home.   We both left fat and happy. Upon my return to Vegas, this will be the first stop.

Rt_XuKZXKY0cKOJKrcMZ5Q.text: Great ramen spot on the southwest side of town. Located in the same plaza as EOS fitness, Ramen Kobo is very conveniently located right off 215/Durango.  One of the unique quirks about this place is that you can see the ramen noodles being made right in front of you in the waiting area. Love that set up!  Yep, the ramen here is on point. I haven't had anything but ramen so I can't comment on the rest of the menu but I do enjoy all the ramen here. My favorite is the tonkotsu. Unlike some other ramen places, the broth is flavorful yet not too strong or heavy in the sodium taste.   Service has been great from my experiences. The restaurant is pretty small so don't feel odd if you sit close to the table next to you - it may happen especially when the place gets busy. They have a bar area available along with some tables.  One thing I do dislike about this place: add-ons prices. Most other ramen places I've been to include an egg free of charge. Here it is $1 or something. It's also $1 to add seaweed they provide one piece.   Still not too bad for a bowl of ramen. It's about $8 and change for a bowl without any additional items. I do come here frequently, mostly because of its convenient location though.

t4hZwQoPYTYAvMHM_SJL8w.text: One of my go to places for ramen.  Their broths are a nice blend of flavors without being overly salty - feel like they really play up the garlic and even have additional garlic you can add as a condiment. Watch your spice level - their mild is probably closer to medium at other place, but I feel you need at least a little spice to really enjoy it.  Noodle to soup ratio is perfect in my opinion though I wish that nitamago wasn't extra.  My ramen just isn't complete without the egg. Nice simple selection of other rice dishes, but ramen is really the Star here. Another highlight here is their recent addition of dipping noodles - Tsukemen.  Hot soup broth served as a dipping sauce for the cold noodles.  Give it a try for something different esp when the temperatures are rising outside.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork belly bowl
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chatsu pork bowl
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso ramen, mild with egg added

3jtUwnsV4tJO75OWwQrYGw.text: Not that great, but if you're in that South west area it's worth not having to drive to China Town. If you like spicy ramen, I guess this is the place for you to go. Do you know that authentic Japanese ramen is not SPICY !

PvzvTUJ2dxnV8dBzRTdYfg.text: First time at Ramen Kobo and I got the Shoyu ramen. The ramen overall was pretty tasty. However, the noodles were a bit undercooked. I think it's important to mention that their mild spicy level is pretty spicy.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu Ramen

uCjYsx8wXAwtyb4MmRB9_A.text: What a lovely little ramen shop. The decor itself feels like someone picked it up from Japan and placed it in Las Vegas. Of course at the time of my visit it was during the craze of its anniversary. They offered $3 fresh ramen bowls, something that enticed me and absolutely enticed the crowd that filled the place. I can't fault the place for that, honestly I expected that to happen. As such I had myself their ramen, the Shoyu Mild Ramen to be exact. Shoyu being the type of course and Mild the spice level they offer. The waitress was very kind to let me know that even Mild had a bit of a kick. And it sure did! The rest of the bowl was a lovingly crafted dish. The noodles, being house-made that you can actually observe were fresh and tasted fresh. The Shoyu broth was perfectly balanced with the spice. And thanks for adding corn! All in all, minus the large crowd at the time, Ramen Kobo is a great tasting little ramen shop!

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu Mild Ramen with Added Corn Price: $8.95 + $1 for Corn as of 07/31/18

8wAtQEhoxAsM_WcR1PbglQ.text: Wow. Just wow.   Best ramen I've had. I got the miso with added egg and corn, hot. It was pretty spicy but delicious. My boyfriend got the spice under hot, mild I think. And it was really mild, not much heat at all. The noodles were thick with grate texture. The broth was divine.  We had the pork and chicken buns, they were mediocre. It's the sliced meat they put in the soup with some lettuce and mayo I believe.   The employees all welcome you when you enter the restaurant. Service is fast and friendly.   By far my new favorite spot.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso with added corn and egg, hot. I dream about this ramen daily.

ZEpgdA_7si7vf3jvdgvYtA.text: Food amazing . But I give it 3 stars because the Latino night shift server sucks.  I usually put up with it because the ramen so good but I won't be dining in anymore. The guy drops the food off and just leaves you unattended. No refills ever. Doesn't check up on you. I have to ask the cooks for something, they I turn tell him to ring it up. I guess my last straw was me waiting about 15 min after I finished my meal to get my check but the guy was just chatting up a storm with coworkers.Anyways it was fun while it lasted

NBK_XyWQeNPRL6AujsVFAg.text: I thought it was just alright.  Ordered shoyu original, and I found the broth to be super oily. The noodles were just right; chewy and cooked al dente. It came with a lot of toppings (chashu pork, fried garlic, kikurage black mushrooms, bamboo shoots, green chives, bean sprouts, ground pork, shredded red pepper). I found the chashu pork to also be super fatty and the flavor was very porky (not fresh). There was barely any meat and that wasn't flavorful at all.   I didn't get any of the rice bowls, but maybe those are good.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu original

zR7lHvQhDkC1hriNpJAdgg.text: I'll start with what I liked: I got there at 11:25am and found out that they didn't open until 11:30.  There was already a group of customers waiting outside.  When they opened (exactly at 11:30), the 8 of us waiting were seated promptly and efficiently.  Water was served, orders were taken, and everyone had food at 11:45.  Talk about fast!   I also really liked their pork chashu - it was really delicious.   That's about all that I liked.   So the pork chashu must have been sliced by a skilled chef, it is surprisingly thin and you only get one slice with your order.  I had the miso ramen with mild (lowest) level spicy.  My order was doused in red pepper and was very spicy.  I didn't taste much of the broth because the heat overwhelmed all other flavors.  The toppings were also sparse, so it was like having noodles in a spicy soup and not much else.  I can't say I enjoyed the ramen here, which is like 90% of the entire menu.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso Ramen
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The menu

20hJkkpITn0pXOabN6hO7Q.text: I like this place very much. We came at the lunch rush, and had to wait 15 minutes.But it was worth it. Homemade noodles, delicious gyoza, and great customer service. Definitely will be back!

o3Nz8Agn_vxyW6Xne_FDJQ.text: Fantastic food! Stellar flavor, and BE WARNED...they don't play with spice here. I LOOOOVVVEEEEE spicy stuff and their Hot is not playing around

N9HWxIpzu6CcBH8XMjM4QQ.text: Amazing ramen place that handmakes their own noodles right in front of you! Just be careful trying to take a picture of them running the noodles through the machine - it can get a little awkward when they see you taking photos of the employees.  I got the miso ramen. The broth was very flavorful and full bodied, the noodles were perfectly chewy and al dente, and all the toppings were delicious. One thing that I missed though was a lack of vegetables and more toppings. You can add extra toppings, but they were a little pricey and I expected a little more to come with my bowl, especially for the price.   I ended up getting the original spice level because I can't take spicy food, but my friends got medium-hot level and they were all suffering greatly. If you're a spicy noodle lover, this is a good place for you, but be careful of what level you choose as they can make it really hot!

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso ramen

mVVk12fUSGfnhAAn-AyH_Q.text: Depending how you enjoy your ramen, this place has a spice level added to it, but can also order original, to get the taste of the soup base. Visited Ramen Kobo on a Saturday evening around 6:30 and there was no wait at the time, but as it started to get busy right after we ordered, so be cause to come early if you can. There are bar seating and table seating. Bar is good as you can watch the chef cook. We ordered a chicken soup based and a pork soup based Ramen, with a medium spice level to both and a Pork belly rice bowl. All were very delicious and everything comes out super hot! I would have liked to taste the original just to taste the flavors of the soup without any spices added.... Great food and definitely coming back next time! RAMEN IS GREAT!!!

XKSOtKk9nsJ7hJ7Br_Qs2Q.text: I had came here on Friday evening with my friends with a short wait. Service was nice, but the ramen I ordered tasted mediocre to me.  I ordered a mild tonkotsu ramen. The broth was too bland and filled with the chili oil.  I prefer thin noodles and was disappointed to find out that it came in the wavy type noodle only.  This place has about 4-6 tables and bar seating.  I don't think I would come back again, favorites are still Monta and Ramen Sora, especially for the prices too! If I do have to eat at a ramen place nearby, I'd rather go to Ohjah Noodle House that is literally down the street.

UHHfjDZh2JjrP_oebSqhIQ.text: The pork broth ramen was good.  Very similar to other pork broth ramen I have had.   Menu is very basic. Ramen, fried rice and 2 other things. Wanted appetizers but none were offered on the menu. Would have given 4 stars if there were appetizers.  Also they have some beer but no other alcohol.  Very small but came late so no wait.

ErGNMtk2IZVYh-2BXwKbJw.text: Food: The broth from kobo ramen still can't compare to Sora Ramen, for a Ramen it's ok. The Side dishes though were really good, I would recommend getting the pork belly bowl with pickled green onions, the pork belly were stir fried with salt and some sesame oil, this combination in my subjective opinion was great flavor wise.  Ambiance: The decor is the typical ramen setting small dining area with a bar and an added bonus of seeing how the ramen is made. Adds to the experience of Ramen eating.  Service: Service was good, the waitresses were attentive to our needs especially with the kids.   Overall: It's ok for a ramen and would be good to view how ramen is made first hand. I would recommend getting the side dishes in addition to the ramen.

kJSACQkTdHXsnct2SxFQSg.text: One of my favorite places for ramen in Vegas! Definitely go here if you like some spice! I always go with mild miso ramen with a side of kimchi~ Even mild has some kick to it! Kinda on the small side space wise but so are the rest of the ramen places. Usually not too busy either which is nice! Definitely try this place out if you haven't already!

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Mild miso ramen with kimchi~

38vEYpCYYxHd6cfDy4N_Eg.text: Great !! Open till 11 pm ! Today I had tonkotsu ramen and it was delicious!! Before ramen was too salty but today was just perfect

C0ToAnxRls2hvt-XO5qFRQ.text: This is one of my favorite ramen places now besides Monta Chaya. But I probably love this place more because there's not a long wait time and they have spicy levels!  As someone who loves spicy food, I eat my ramen with the level fire all the time. If you can handle really spicy food then fire will be nothing to you. I also love how flavorful and fresh their ramen is. Every time it comes out, it's always super hot and fresh, never lukewarm or anything like that.   Service is also very nice. The place can get busy but even then, the servers try their best to check up on you, refill your water, etc.  The only problem with this place is that you can not substitute what you take out from your ramen for more of something else. You can only add extra which will cost about an extra $2 for each topping. I don't like bean sprouts or ground beef in my ramen so I always sub it for an egg and more chashu since you only get one piece. My bowl ends up being around $14.   However, since their ramen is so delicious and their wait time is never over 15 min or so, I will always come back to this place. Especially in winter!

440H3jlyjLkfk2X4WvAqPg.text: The broth, the noodles and most of all, the excellent customer service and friendly atmosphere. They deserve all 5 stars. This has quickly become a go to place for me and my family. Although at times, the wait could be a bit longer due to the size of the place (it is a Ramen house - so don't expect it be large in size), the wait is definitely worth it!  The depth of the flavor in their soup is well defined and their Ramen is all made in house - perfectly cooked! If you are a spicy soup enthusiasts, you will want to try the "hot" level. Many toppings to choose from as well!

Fux9cvhqExp_HZd9iAlUvg.text: Deliciousness! Probably the best ramen I have ever eatten......................................... .

F8MyiL3m6L-MJURfU1zaEw.text: My first time here with a group of seven and we came in about an hour and a half before they closed. I felt like one of the waitresses were rushing us while she was taking our order, which might've caused her to switch some orders and get orders completely wrong.  The presentation of the food was great, but the broth was pretty salty and my pork was very fatty. Just thinking of my order as I write this review makes me sick.  The service wasn't great either. They can't keep track of what everyone ordered. And when they brought out the check they kept pestering my boyfriend about how many Cokes we had ordered, which was only one. They still kept asking like we were hiding another can of Coke somewhere.  I would not bring my business back to this place. If i'm ever on that side of town again with an empty stomach, I'll just go to IKEA and get some Swedish meatballs.

tcUXEr0hrAc_e2k_XZWeug.text: Like every local, I was ecstatic to hear that Monta Ramen would be opening another location in the Southwest which is rapidly growing with great restaurants. When Omoide opened, they lived up to the hype. After all, it was one of the first ramen spots to open in Southwest. And so when word came on the street that Monta (who made it on Travel Channel) decided to expand its location, it was over. My life was complete.  And how disappointed I was. Came here twice, about 3 weeks apart which was enough to say that I would not be coming back. Actually, should not have even come the second time.  On a non-busy weekday, I stood by the seating area for 10 minutes. Tables and bar area non filled. Host/Server did not actually even acknowledge me and had her head working on some check by the computer. It was not until 2 guys walked in that she looked up and saw us and thought we were together as one party.   I ordered the Tonkotsu Shoyu Ramen. This time, I thought, I would be smart and just order extra Chashu since the first time there was only one fatty piece. Kobo is smart. Since they want you to pay for additional toppings, my logic was that if I paid for extra chashu- perhaps there would be more chance of better chashu. I paid $2.50 for 4 pieces of fat, essentially.  How is it that the SAME ramen restaurant can have two completely different chashus? Did not particularly favor the tiny portion of ground beef inside either.  Given, the noodles are made freshly in-house. Other than that, the ramen is terrible.   I will make that drive to Jinya or Monta Ramen on the other side of town.  But Ramen Kobo, I will pass.

bVSLgD25Y8kbbvqr-DaMdQ.text: I had better ramen from Other places! The broth was not tasty at all and the noodles are overlooked. What bothers me though is the cook making the fried rice and other food, which I did not orders, he was kinda heavy guys so he was sweating inside the kitchen of course because of boiling water and broth etc... He was wearing gloves but he kept Touching his face and hat with sweat then continue on cooking food. I just don't think that was very appetizing for me... I left after I ate the nitamago (eggs) lol... But no space as well... There's probably just 25-30 people capacity. So if there's a line or waiting to be seated I would leave and go somewhere not worth it for ur 2 mins waiting for a bowl of not so good ramen

5Gxkm4q5vulh1ZXxyIPpAw.text: I've been here twice now. I don't think it's all that good. Had the Tonkatsu Ramen and the broth wasn't flavorful; it was merely spicy. The fried rice came out a little cold and was just OK. There are definitely better options in Vegas.

HUPJ1pIxgoB8YbKNviB1nA.text: Oh so tasty ramen because it's freshly made. I will be a regular customer here for sure. The setting and ambiance is really just like a Japanese restaurant...very nice!

EsXWsuv8AgSNBFNcOnjnbg.text: yum ! This is medium spicy tonkatsu with nori chashu pork and soft boiled egg - the meat and egg comes cold so you do need to wait while you dip the food in the broth for it all it to consummate and get an even temp ;)

i3VMh-lqPzewigxGpYy1lg.text: Went here sooo many times & will never get tired of it. I have tried many ramen places in vegas and esp. in OC, and this place seems to be the best. The flavorings and customer service are always on point. Very consistent. The "Shoyu" has been my boyf's go to option.

60xAiF7IHmtX1U87x7XzPg.text: I love this place. Food is always so fresh and delicious. The place is a little small, so sometimes you have a long wait. However, if you have the time I thinks it's worth it. I always get miso ramen with extra pork and add in a soft boil eggs with corn. Sometime I add seaweed, but add to the side so it doesn't get soggy. It is always on point! They also make noodles in house and while waiting you can look into the noodle making room!

XrdtY1dbXG_LbdYRthaaOw.text: Best ramen place in town. Came here for the first time today cuz one of my friends recommended it. I got the tonkatsu ramen with soft spoiled egg topping. Man, it tastes so good. The broth is very thick and rich, exactly how it should be. Noodles are the skinny kind which they don't give you an option to choose though. Doesn't come with eggs if you don't pay for the extra topping which is $1.50. A little on the expensive side but totally worth it. Been to so many ramen places, even its sister place - monta, this place by far is the best.

wZSBNpqcF-r4Zg_SIQcAJg.text: When I feel the urge to slurp on hot, delicious ramen noodles this is my go-to! The soup itself is amazing and the add-ons that come free include: chashu pork, garlic, black mushrooms, chives, fresh chives, bamboo shoots, and red pepper.  The noodle is a perfect mix of chewy and soft, leaving your taste buds in heaven.  Here's a tip, if you're sensitive to spice start with mild and work your way up to a different spice level.  Sometimes their medium is a bit too much.  Also, add some spinach for a fresh greens twist.  One last tidbit, free of charge they will let you swap ground pork and chashu for chicken! You can thank me later!

ct8gUqF8KUB6P-mS_MgEzw.text: Fire Tonkotsu Ramen is on point. Noodles are handmade and its amazing! Definitely my #1 choice for ramen on the southwest side.

a8FoXbjQZ26t5BqPK6Ot7Q.text: This place is delicious. The menu is small, simple but everything is so flavorful. 2 dollar bottles of beer (not happy hour pricing ! But every day - all the time.) you can see the ramen maker when you first walk in which is super enchanting. This is my 3rd visit and it gets 4 stars because the service is kinda slow for such a small space. Everything thing else about the place 5 stars!

sF5A4ezxgvvPujfqyP4mJQ.text: I have been going to ramen kobo for almost a year now and it's the only ramen place in town that has homemade noodles and their broth is always so good especially if you like spicy  I love this place. I don't even live close to it and I go at least once or twice a month it is so good  I would recommend 10/10 especially because I've been too a lot of ramen places in Vegas and nobody tops this place

YqddYyKs6j9DYwYHR0FXbA.text: Decided to try this small ramen spot located near our massage location. Small but clean. Greeted immediately upon entering. I tried the Shoyu ramen spice level Hot and also the Kimchi fried rice. Spice level was on point. Broth was tasty. Noodle texture was good. Fried rice was okay. Overall, had a craving for noodles and this place hit the spot. Service was good, but we had to ask to refill our drinks and we got our check up front rather than them bringing it to our table. If you're in the mood for good Japanese ramen near this area, this place will satisfy.

kjAXDVWxPvN3YSrJ2cSqjQ.text: The ramen noodles here were good. Great texture. The broth however, was a bit rich, heavy, & somewhat busy. I ordered the miso broth with medium spice & added an egg & mustard greens. It was decent. My husband had the tonkatsu broth with medium spice & added Kim chi which was served on the side. This place was just ok for us. We still prefer Monta ramen over this place.

owZbkN19YdCiGLIRcbHlKA.text: Food is good comparable to Monta and Sora Ramen. Great prices great service and actually Asians cooking as well.

r1wVKXNhmau81ZLOnUqvrg.text: The restaurant is always busy so my husband and I have always called in our order for take out. It's always ready on time and packed nicely - noodles in one container and broth in another. The sides are also packed nicely in separate containers.

CSRQhxGJEJ38XkCQo8xg2w.text: First impressions: small place. The only place for me to sit was the bar. If I were with someone else, we would have had to wait. This is at 2pm, tail ending lunch. Service was quick. I ordered the chicken broth. It comes with all this stuff. Of course, step 3 is to add other stuff which I added soft boiled egg and nori. Mild spiciness. The soup looked oily when it got to me but I think that's where most of the flavor is. I had to REACH OVER this lady beside me to get chopticks and people kept bumping my back as they walked by the bar. So that was awkward. This was while I was eating. I don't think the people realized it because the space was so tight, but I definitely apologized to the lady beside me for having to reach over her for chopticks. The broth was mild, just like I had ordered, but I don't like it this oily. The FRESHLY made noodles are absolutely delicious. The oil kinda bugged me and I was wearing all white, so I was scared it would get all over my shirt. I also received my drink in a can, which I don't like. All restaurants should have their drinks on taThen at 2:25, they told me that they were doing last call. I guess they are only open til 2:30 on Wednesdays. Then reopen at 5pm to 11pm. Overall, ok service, great noodles, oily broth, but flavorful. Very squished and cramped inside. I would MAYBE go back.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chicken broth ramen with nori and soft boiled eggs.

8qT599KB28HIKnsnCZYYpg.text: I'm glad more and more ramen restaurants are opening up in the southwest. This place is great! Small, friendly staff, quick service and delicious ramen!! My husband got the level 8 (4 chilis on the menu) was super hot but very delicious and I got the mild (2 chilis) I loved it!! We will be back soon!!

7GHuT7RrMxo0ZV-avmApfw.text: This place is excellent, having just come back from living in Japan I am so happy to find a place that taste almost identical to what we had there. The homemade chili sauce is fantastic!!!

ubQ4ISYCjIWFwSd0gysc4Q.text: This place is amazing! The ramen and fried rice are on point. Probably the best bowl of ramen I've ever had. Prices are extremely fair considering the quality of food you're getting

uhtD1ocvDtffA6O_XBKHBA.text: I have eaten many Ramen soup places here in Las Vegas and though I found some that are good some that are not so good this place by far has been the best I have had yet it was absolutely delicious. They make their own noodles as well which was pretty impressive and fun to watch.

0co-3-UAXV7ttYNCux5suw.text: I ordered the kimchi fried rice to go.  The cashier advised me of my total $8.93 which was a bit high to me, but overlooked it. I took my order and left. My kimchi fried rice was good, they added my condiments of red chili oil, garlic and soy sauce , . My issue was how the cashier told me my total, including the gratuity. If I want to pay a gratuity for take out I will. When was it mandatory to pay this. I feel taken advantage of. Next time I will be aware.

uyyVa2o0JcoP87fsB8wU8w.text: Love this place! It's cool that you can see the ramen being made. Very similar to Monta. Never disappoints. Service was quick and they were very kind.

qDGRM01k8zNGxYya-mxs4A.text: This is our favorite Ramen spot in Las Vegas!! We're from LA and we tried many many ramen spots and this place would rank #2 on our list! 2 thumbs up! I'm writing this review as I'm going to to-go some right now :)

nHyhcH22SueXs7YMKjmTGQ.text: Delicious  My husband and I were pleasantly surprised when we tried this place. Even my toddler at a large portion of noodles and rice.

pXkEZlU9gkImBYR3GSukaQ.text: The fire ramen is nice for people who eat as spicy as I do. The pork belly bowl is bomb. We got it cooked crispy and I think that made it even more bomb. Lol I would definitely come back here. Super friendly staff. Thumbs up! Trust me, I'm picky about my food, this place is bomb. They also make their noodles fresh.

oiL2TAbFcMba33gEdFBvGA.text: This place is fu..ing greedy, I try to order a bowl of noodle and ask for a little bit extra soup and they have to charge me $2 extra and every little things charge extra.... $15 for a bowl of ramen probably is the most expensive I had. Arguing with me the whole 10 min it's unbelievable.

7wmMOWcxIW0jB5EaKCPWhg.text: Delicious ramen joint in the southwest part of the valley.  It's always been busy the few times we've been there.  The menu is clear and makes things easy to order if you're not a frequent ramen diner.  I like the setup and being able to sit at the bar and watch the kitchen work.  Great experience and location!

1mHsJhA_4b-0ZEMDnJKj9g.text: I really enjoyed this spot. They make their noodles fresh in house. I went with the pork broth ramen. No extras, just straight up. At first the porkiness of the broth us a little overwhelming,  but once it settles it's delicuous. All ingredients used were really good. Oh and I went with mild spicy, which just barely hits your throat here and there. Good stuff, not pricey.  But don't go, it's small, and you will just cause me to wait in line longer next time I go lol.

44A9KnKdkl-5QRNvCCGeUA.text: Decided to try this place other night and was not disappointed. Great service and good ramen. Will definitely be back. The restaurant was clean and nice inside. Comfortable to sit and enjoy a good m

pQ7QGEktbJfKWb_O-UDGBw.text: The tonkatsu ramen with your choice of spice level is delicious. On rush hours or for the most part there is always a long line and a long wait list. If you don't mind since it's a small place. They have a small menu but their ramen and rice bowls are good tasting and quality that a small menu is more than enough. I enjoy the chasu bowl, pork bowl, and Korean bowl which are all basically upscaled fried rice.

z4Gt-D-ZUXQss0PCzNSTuQ.text: First time here and it was good! Small..not good for big groups sitting is limited. But the vibe was cool and so were the staff. Will be coming back when we're on the this side of town.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States

3IJWfRHdlHWoQIlVLGXJZA.text: A friend recommended this place and it did not disappoint. There was practically no wait when we came here a little after they opened. The menu is very straight forward, you pick your broth, level of spiciness and toppings. I went for the shoyu, hot with no toppings. All the bowls are $8.95 unless you add toppings. The ramen comes out pretty quick so that's a good thing.   My friends mostly got either the mild or medium which I should have done. I can normally tolerate spicy foods but getting this ramen hot was for sure a mistake. It burns the heck out of my lips and I need at least 3 glasses of water to soothe the pain. As from the burn, I liked how light the ramen is. Most ramen places I've been too the broth is often fatty and bit more dense but this broth was quite light. I don't know if it's because I chose the shoyu where they use a chicken broth instead of the pork but it's a much cleaner tasting ramen and I like that. That way I can enjoy the whole dish instead of just the noodles and chashu. I really enjoyed the chashu, it was a nice thick cut compared to other places I've been to. I like the flavor a good deal, not a fan of the super thin slices. You can hardly taste the flavor of the pork when it's cut so thin. It doesn't retain much of the texture or fatty goodness. I thought the noodles were okay, I prefer thick noodles so I'm sad they don't have that option here.  Regardless of the noodle size, this is still a great spot for ramen. Not too crowded so you can get your food relatively quick and it's delicious.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu ramen with hot level spicy

uUYk4-FJWgTFSIS6H5VD8g.text: My fiance and I started coming to this spot because of a great friend who told us how great this place was.  We come here at least once a month or one every two months. We get these cravings for Ramen Kobo, specifically because of a few of their items.   You HAVE to try their fried rice! I don't know exactly what it is that makes it addicting, but it's such a perfect side to have before, during, or after your bowl of ramen. I once tried to make my own fried rice and it wasn't nearly as great as Ramen Kobo's. If you want a little spice to your fried rice, you can try their kimchi fried rice, which is equally as good.  Now, their ramen is to die for. They hand make their noodles. And the fact that you get to choose your own spicy level and add other items into your bowl gives it that personal touch! I just can't get over their bowls. My favorite spice level is mild and my fiance's is hot. There's something about the hot spicy level that looks aesthetically pleasing. It's a beautiful orange!  I enjoy their customer service because of every visit I have had, their service has always been keen. It's rare for me to finish my glass of water because there's always a server refilling my drink! They're coming to our table at prompt times and it's not too overbearing. I love it here! This is my #1 ramen place!

ko8GrjL9MqGPCchH9vM8WA.text: My fiance and I have a ritual of checking out ramen shops at every country we travel to. It's been years of travelling and hundreds of ramens, but Ramen Kobo still holds first place on my personal list of favourites.  The broth is robust and rich yet not fatty, it's delicate yet bursting with flavour. And the noodles are the perfect chewy texture.   Another aspect which I find amazing about this place is consistency. Every time (and, oh boy, we've been here so many times) the broth has exactly the same flavour profile, the meat is as tender as always and the noodles are exactly the same chewiness.   I also like Kobo's compact menus (it's better to do fewer things right than more things in an average way).   My usual order is Tonkotsu ramen (mild and medium spice depending on the temperature of weather) and fried rice, which has this amazing smoky taste and aroma.  Grab the seat at the bar, it's the best one as you will be able to see how's everything done.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States

HHFC6Z6QtqxGETMlasZXlw.text: Doesn't matter how name ramen noodle place we tried. This place is still the best. The broth is so creamy and tasty. It's to die for. The favor is just right. Always the same every time we come here. Food is good and customer is a

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. New

kv2XOu0RLLNqJGyAnndK3g.text: Was craving a hot bowl of ramen and this has been on my list for a while so it was time to check it off! Place was pretty busy on a Wednesday night during dinner. Since I was dining by myself I was seated quickly at the bar. I love sitting at the bar as I can see what's going on in the kitchen and how they orchestrate things. I ordered the tonkatsu in medium spicy and added egg and nori. I really enjoyed the homemade ramen and the broth was delicious! It was creamy and the medium spice was perfect for me. Spicy enough to make my nose run but not spicy to a point where I hated life. The pork was perfectly tender and was a great addition to the dish. My only complaint is that I wish the broth was hotter. It was more on the warm side to me and I'm that person who likes my soup to be screaming hot. I'm looking forward to trying their miso next time as I do have a favorite spot for my miso ramen so it'll be interesting to compare.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkatsu ramen (medium spicy)

TQPOQlbDtOWmgH9PjnxmbA.text: This is the one. No need to stop anywhere else. You just found your favorite ramen joint. The shoyu broth is in a league of its own. The fact that they have this straight chicken option (broth, "belly", and ground chicken) sets them apart from the competition in my book. As you can tell, the broth is a big pull for me!  The spice is just right and you can tell it's been cooked long and slow, and the NOODLES honey. They make them right there and they're the perfect thickness.   I found this place on a whim when I lived in the area. Now? I'm willing to make a drive even if there's another option along the way. Me and my mom just busted a mission at 10pm to get there and eat before they closed. It's THAT deep.   Service can be hit or miss but you never have to wait too long for your ramen. Yeah, it's small but I love it. It's this hidden gem you wouldn't expect to be smack dab in the middle of a sandwich shop and clinic. My order is a medium spicy all chicken bowl with egg, seaweed, and black garlic oil.

E_Lmy2svZdsG4JFeIlHlpw.text: Once you get past the wait, its totally worth it. This place is tiny! We came here on a Saturday night and of course it was packed. About a 30 minute wait until a table could be cleared. The 1st thing you see is the noodles being made in house on what appears to be a very expensive piece of specialized noodle making machinery. The menu is pretty basic. Build your own bowl and pick the heat level. 1 fumble we noticed is that the orders got screwed up. We looked past that since we were sharing. The food was delicious. Will definitely be back at a much slower time. Prices are resonable.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States

5dPgXs0e74Tnf3XSDrqBCQ.text: It was good but they didn't have tofu again. Every time I go there there out of tofu . The food is really good but if you order a Glass of water their plastic Glass cups stink !!!!! I asked for just a water and both times their water glasses stink like mackerel spoiled fish or something; which leads me to believe they're not using sanitizer in their machine so I finally ordered a sprite in a can, The fried rice is really amazing too. We'll be back just not ordering water because I don't want to get grossed out again

WiKLRry39WfSjM28CyTIlA.text: The best one was on spring mountain, but its closed now. The Durango location is good, not worth the drive from the base, but my first choice if i lived closer

4J-E_I0afhKpTh5v1Bw1wQ.text: I love me some good Japanese Ramen. It was my second visit here and it was packed so it had to be a good sign... but sometimes looks can be deceiving. Upon arrival with my friend and I we wrote down our names and proceeded to wait outside in the cold since the waiting area was full. As people were leaving my friend and I as well as others waiting saw open seats yet none of the employees tried to seat others. Finally after 30 minutes of waiting we get seated at a table that has been available for at least 10 minutes. Before I even got to sit down I was immediately asked if I was ready to order. After getting seated and asking what drinks we wanted I asked if I could get water for now with lemon on the side, but sadly they don't have lemon, no big deal. After being given some time to order I decided to go for the spicy miso ramen which has 4 spice levels: mild, medium, hot, and fire. As someone that can easily handle 8-10 Thai spice level and 6-8 Japanese spice I was very tempted to go for hot but the server suggested medium considering I haven't been to this place in ages and don't want to overwhelm myself. Safe to say, medium is a good balance for the bowl of ramen. If you enjoy thicker style ramen you will most definitely enjoy this place. Service was very lackluster but the ramen was delicious until I saw that one of my char-siu (Pork) was nearly raw and lukewarm. I always give places a second chance and this place definitely has potential, but with the lack of structure with the employees, poor service, and lukewarm meat, I know they can do better especially with such a nice location and their competitive pricing.   Pros: +Food is good +Price is cheaper than other ramen places  Cons: -If the waiting room is packed be prepared to wait outside in the cold / heat -Lack of items on the menu, would like to see more -Lack of structure -Service needs to be heavily improved on  I love ramen and definitely can see potential in this place. The pricing is very attractive and the ramen is very good aside from my lukewarm pork. If the service can get fixed and the food can remain consistent (everything in my bowl was good aside from the lukewarm pork) then they'll have a regular. It was really hard to rate this place considering the service was bad, but the ramen was the saving grace until I bit into my pork. I'll definitely be back in the future to see if things improve but for now I see this place as a solid 3 stars. Better customer service would bring it to 3.5 stars and if my bowl of ramen didn't have lukewarm pork it would've been a solid 4 stars. I'm a tough one to get 5 stars from but if this place heavily enhances their service and creates a better structure and more menu items, I can definitely see this place earning a 5 star from me.

OfraIwRusKXa2l2SNOq_vQ.text: Ramen Kobo has got to be the best Spot in town for some quick noodles and an even better one for some beer and solid good times. Service

JyPz7lA0-h9cnwKUeprPow.text: The West side finally has Vegan ramen!!   It's a small place, so your going to wait a bit at peak times. The veggie ramen was excellent and the prices are very reasonable. I ordered the "fire spicy" and it was hot! I might go down a notch on the spicy meter on my next visit.

qrBhpdKccWQNBBc85F5F9A.text: This is the best ramen place in Las Vegas that I've ever been to. I know everyone talks about Monta but I honestly think this place is so much better. You can make the ramen as spicy as you want, there are all kinds of toppings and the broth is so flavorful. The noodles were also cooked incredibly well. I got the miso ramen, medium, with black garlic oil and it was absolutely fantastic. I will definitely be back and I will tell everyone I know to check out Kobo over any other ramen place ^.^
