J04kHnvRw4JcFhC9JUnPwQ.text: This place is amazing! The staff are very friendly and the service is quick. They make the ramen noodles fresh and in-house  you choose from several choices of broths that come with standard fillings. From there, you can add many different "sides" to customize your bowl. It's well-priced and the food is absolutely delicious. My two-year-old even loved it! The only potential downfall is it's very small so big parties would be hard to accommodate, and I can see the wait would be really long in peak hours. So, my advice is to go early if you don't want to wait too long. I highly recommend Ramen Kobo!

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States

QMAC9N0Wp9IqU4VKD6UsSg.text: Easily one of our favorite places to eat in the Southwest!  Pros:  flavorful menu, reasonable prices, fast service(got our food in less than 10 minutes after ordering), noodles made in house and convenient location(just south of the 215 on Durango)  Con:  it's a small place and busy so you might have to wait a few minutes before you sit  Definitely a must try place if you like ramen.  You won't be disappointed!

XMz3daJBPB733xrmvHxfXQ.text: I'm not entirely sure what the hype is about this place. My boyfriend and I were not impressed at all. Both my boyfriend and I experienced the same problem with our bowl of ramen. The biggest problem was the broth, the heart of ramen is the broth, it was more like miso soup, it definitely lacked a real broth taste. The broth contained very little meat and was not prepared properly. Our eggs were cold, our pork slices were cold, and the fact that they add ground pork (cheapest meat you could add) which makes the dish completely undesirable. There is a ramen joint not too far from Ramen KoBo that offers 2 slices of beef, 2 slices of pork, one huge ox tail, an egg, and two seaweed wraps for less than the price we paid for at KoBo. The straw that broke the camels back was paying $3 for both of us to enjoy a cold egg (smh). This should already be included in our ramen bowls. We both definitely do not plan on ever returning. We gave it a shot and it definitely did not meet our expectations.

QZV9ICLLB6mieWH_wNJmqQ.text: Came here for lunch since it's pretty close to where I live.   It's a fairly small restaurant but has pretty awesome ambiance. You can see the chefs cook right in front of you and there are these machines that make the noodles behind a glass window.  Servers were quick and friendly. However I knocked off a star for the actual broth. I was pretty stoked to have a spiciness option for the ramen; however, the spice seems to be just an chili oil or some sort and made the broth super oily to which I couldn't really savor the flavor of it since the broth itself was no longer as creamy or thick like it should be.   But overall, not bad. The restaurant is still fairly new so 4 stars.

r3DDRY5eTX1CgkkRA34gbA.text: Wonderful staff and delicious food! First time here tonight and left full and happy! Just a bit of a wait. It's a cozy restaurant and the staff is very friendly and helpful. Noodles are soft and delish. The ramen portions are excellent, chashu pork tender and flavorful and the broth is smooth and rich. Will definitely be back again soon!

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork broth with chashu pork and soft egg

LtEq1GQq_HFZ2slfU4NlEQ.text: I was very excited to see a ramen spot open on this side of town so of course I had to try it. The small menu makes it easy to order. Their Broth is amazing - fatty and full of flavor! Their add-ons are a bit pricy but that's to be expected in this area. This has become my go-to spot

NLjj9QqdD6e-dDvUUQw_RQ.text: Best ramen in the city!!!! Super sweet set up!! They have a self service iPad fir customers and use iPads table side to order!!! Great service and amazing noodles!!!

38NdMI43doMS2mfD3HyUig.text: Excellent fresh ingredients, however small portions and an extra charge for small pieces of chicken instead of pork (their main ingredient in everything) really hurt this resturants ratings review... $50 bucks for 2 adults and 2 kids is a bit much  for ramen especially if the youngest is 7 and doesn't order a main entree. I would consider going back if the menu changed and had more none pork options without the price hike. I wouldn't mind paying for fresh ramen fully loaded for around $10. Also, The drink selection sucks and over priced. Let me know when you change this, I'll come back and change my review.

yF8q9VixWVQcFQDAHQAhZg.text: I give only 3 stars because the broth is extra fatty and the broth is very bland. Have to pay extra to add Pork to your ramen. Otherwise, place is small, service was good and fast.

91ILsPbTsnTDCtaUitx2gg.text: The broth of the Ramon is ridiculously good... But beware.. mild is spicy...but awesome...I had pork and chicken broth with added soft boiled egg...yummm

7mHASclaIzMtwnIzEccJaw.text: Their food was too over priced. And the soup was very oily. Also you can't substitute the toppings that come with the soup even if you don't want some of them, you have to pay an additional cost for the toppings you want.

rufL0Fzuz51ayUFtqJzKSA.text: Really good ramen by the same owners as Monta. Not much for appetizers but the reason for coming to a ramen bar is ramen. No fuss, delicious and quick.

kFq8golf0KA8qgEu7I9v2A.text: This placed is owned by monta so it is really damn good. I prefer this over monta because it's not as rich as the monta broth that hurts my stomach after I'm done, also monta is always packed from start to finish and is in the middle of chinatown. My only problem with this place is that its more expensive then monta. Montas ramen is about 6 or 7 dollars, this place charges 9 dollars for ramen and that's not including your extras. But it's right down the street from my job so I can't complain too much. Also you can choose your spicy level. All in all I definitely will be coming here like once a week.

7IE1W0nAy9rnnpeK6-GmBg.text: Very good. The spicy is as advertised. I loved it.  And the location is great from all directions in southwest Vegas. I will be coming back!!

YS6pFYCNkQAWWdvdVe-tcA.text: We were visiting Vegas from Houston and were pleasantly supprised at the super great bowl of noodles put in front of us. The resturant is very small and we had to wait about 20 minutes but it was worth it. The service was fast and friendly. Also, I liked the fact that you could choose the level of spiciness which for me was mild and my wife hot. I can assure you there was a difference. Next time we are in Vegas which is one or twice a year we will return.

T2cSnrldn0xZfJA-MXRfMQ.text: Just walked out of this "four-star" ramen place with my friend and are we glad we have a place to vent and will explain why here: First, the broth was okay. Noodle (whatever and however you have going on behind the window near the entrance) was nothing special. Servants are very polite to some degree some might get annoyed and call them fake. Funny to see the cooks were Hispanics and tried to greet customers in Japanese with a heavy accent (this does not factor into our rating). Hear this: our ramen soups had no eggs and only one thin piece of pork. Are you kidding us!? This is America where we are not as tiny as some of you and we don't pay adult prices to be served tiny kids meals!!! They served just about everything from chashu pork, fried garlic, black mushrooms, chives, ground pork, bamboo shoots, sesame oil, and shredded red pepper ultra small so you don't get enough and have to  pay more (close to $20 per bowl) to get more. Maybe we should be as STINGY as them but one star is the CHEAPEST I can give so there you have it. We don't see the value here at all. In fact, not even close. We have paid less and received a lot more (four ultra-thick porks and realistically maybe 20 times more than here) before. If you want the name of that restaurant, contact us and we'll gladly inform you which one it is). This restaurant is just way too STINGY and we will NO DOUBT NEVER BE BACK! Moving forward, we better turn off our phones now to save power (and money) as the lesson I learned eating at such a STINGY dining establishment. Actually, to be honest, this got to be one of the cheapest restaurants we have ever experienced.

I37hsQ-VkSxtiqvTi5GxdA.text: Love that there is a decent ramen place close to home. They have four levels of spicy or you can just got original like I do which is no spice. This last visit I went for miso broth (pork and chicken) and I also added an egg and corn. My noodles were a little under cooked on top so I just mixed them to the bottom and that finished them off. They were fairly busy so I think that's why the noodles were ready all the way through but it wasn't really a problem. Service was good when we sat but we did have to wait a while for the check even with our dishes having been cleared already.  Overall a good place for ramen on the southwest side of town.

Hfz9q2On_TQwST5AuvIQpw.text: The flavor is very good. Medium spicy is very spicy in my opinion.  The noodles and fillings were delicious. The only disappointment is the broth. It was so oily that I didn't want to drink the broth. I wanted to love it. If the oil can be toned down in the broth it would be perfect.

suI7P-knVAvOdGm0ES7z3g.text: I loved the restaurant and the friendly staff. I took my order to go. I wasn't a fan of the ramen but that may just be my palette. I ordered mild and it was a good spicy. I also put the Chatsu Chicken on it and loved it. .The fried rice is excellent.

PZarFgArgTYv4ptOlxw1QQ.text: This only being my 3rd ramen place I've ever visited, I'd have to say this is my favorite one yet at least in Vegas. I had the spicy pork and the broth was tasty. In this sense, it is better than home made stuff, and I've cooked for years so being creative is the one thing that makes a bowl of noodles for me. The convenience of its location and my attentive server, Yuri, made my experience a delight. It's my ramen place after I get off work.

a-ltkztQdP7wPly0fgzN-Q.text: I ordered the kimchi fried rice to go. The restaurant is really small, so I'm not sure if I would ever stay there to eat. I was disappointed that you cold only get pork if you wanted meat added to the rice but I dealt with it. It wasn't spicy at all and I didn't see that you could request it spicy but maybe I'm wrong. For the price I thought I would've received a bit more but I guess it was enough. I plan to go back again and try the ramen next time.

pGmLHBWEVji2TIsslsAdKw.text: This is so close to my house that I was really hoping that it would be good, but I was wrong. We love Monta but this lacks in comparison. We ordered our usual, the Miso Ramen, original. The broth was bland, no depth of flavor, other ingredients seemed off also. The service was ok but not exceptional, especially as it was not busy. They seemed more concerned that their wi-fi went out and the music was off than anything else. I know it hasn't been open for long but we will probably not take a chance on a second visit. Very disappointed!

BiBRKl5XY8hFxk8M0P0_eQ.text: Got my order to go it was still hot when I got back to my office and it was delicious. I might have to go hotter on the spice next time I played it safe. I will return for another bowl.

ObYcNC1MjJYAhJysfLybEw.text: If I could give 0 stars, I would. Normally I don't care to write a review even though I'm quite the noodle aficionado, but I was certainly compelled to as I was quite disappointed to find out your restaurant was closed when I made it a point to take time out of my day and to drive over to your location specifically to try you folks out at 3pm - just to find out you were closed. You most certainly should post your hours on Yelp so other reviewers are aware of your gap in hours, closing at 2:30pm just to reopen at 5pm. Or post it on the web since everyone has access to the Internet nowadays and that info would have been most helpful. Even though you have Monta Ramen and Monta Chaya under your belt, I would rethink the financial strength of this new business venture and the ingredients compromised if saving 2.5 hours out of your day helps your bottom line NOI. And hopefully I won't see this facility show up on Dirty Dining as well like Monta in the past. And so considering you are promoting the grand opening of your restaurant, this is certainly a easy way to lose business and to lose a client like myself.

-E6W9YYs7e5JQlj6abWaEg.text: broth is not too salty, just right! i was not a big fan of ramen but this place changed me! i crave this once a week :)

AnIZDn4BgRgEmmKtE2zdNQ.text: The service was really nice and the food were aesthetically pleasing to look at, but the taste did not match up. The food itself were a bit lack lustered in taste. Their broth were really light and overpowered by the toppings. I would rather go to Jinya, Marugame Monzo, or Ramen Sora

VYagBbvMTrqZl1ERuMqlVQ.text: Best ramen ever! I probably come here once a week at least, if not more!! The staff is super friendly and do their best to get you in as quickly as possible! Smaller venue so expect a small wait during peak hours but that's because it's so delicious!! The homemade noodles are the best I've ever had and awesome prices for the quality.

S3XY6Syn1AxqDu4WGIlbsA.text: The good : porkbelly rice was really good. Service was fast and friendly. Noodles were fresh  The Bad : Tonkotsu Ramen didn't have any pork broth flavor. You also had to pay extra to add nori and an egg to your order.

lE8-4iif_Xb_rpSXvjtX_Q.text: Fresh noodles make a difference great texture. Broth wasn't too salty and very flavorful! No heart burn, not too greaZzzzzy. Yum!

xGL5HzjSdxZIR7AAqRXCZw.text: All I can say is YUM.  Great place for a quick and delicious meal.  Service was fast and nice.  I will be coming back and you should try it.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso Raman and fried rice on the side.  So delicious.

gHynmof78ZtiLITzWJogTQ.text: Located in a strip mall on Durango, they have a good selection of Ramen.  The chicken ramen minus the ground sausage? which has no business being in there.  the staff is friendly and the service is quick. The best part in the noodles made fresh in house in the front of the restaurant, nice touch.

yxDdheoYl3UxopZdeVLhUw.text: Definite room for improvement.   As a few others have stated, I've been to, and will keep frequenting the other Monta locations but this one has to work on a few things.   In my opinion two major components in ramen make it work... Noodles and soup. Noodles here are thinner than the other two Monta shops and in my opinion not as good.  They were soft and had no texture imho. It may have been an off day but the other two Monta shops don't have off days with their noodles. Soup was decent but much less flavorful and had lots of floating fat chunks which the other two shops don't. I don't think it's a flavor thing, instead maybe rushing the process of the broth.   My mild miso came with bean sprouts which I never ordered, and after taking them out my server noticed and made a comment about me not liking them... Sorry but I didn't order bean sprouts, but was definitely charged for it. Weird. Minor mistake but left a bad taste in my mouth...could've been the chunks of fat   If you're going to mention you're a part of the Monta family, understand you'll be held to high standards. Those standards have not been met at this location just yet.

sy18eMxbJwFkurQC3rXAJg.text: Ate here with the fam after Wet n' Wild since my kids and hubby are always down for noodles. We ate the Tonkotsu Ramen with less salt and medium spiciness. (They have 5 levels - non-spicy, mild, medium, hot and fire). We are so used to Ramen houses being so salty, I specifically requested less salt and was happy to find they accommodated!   The broth was creamy, but not too thick and was delish. I ordered one non spicy for the kids and they shared a bowl (being 5 and 8) and it was perfect.  The noodles are made fresh in house and that was the next best part. They were chewy and had great texture.  Will definitely be back. Hubby has already gone back with his mountain biking buddies and they enjoyed as well!

oVnqJfmVPxTzemWBzgNoSA.text: I heard that this ramen shop was connected to monta so I had to try it.  The venue is nice and cozy. Our server was nice and she came to refill our waters without us having to ask.   My girlfriend and I both got the tonkotsu ramen with an egg. It was completely different from monta though. This bowl came with ONE piece of pork and some type of ground beef?? It was really awkward.   Probably gonna just stick with monta. Oh we both got food poisoning too. Just a heads up

KiUVDWDHg_ktqQp1isXb6g.text: Not my first time here but I must say my second time around was very disappointing.  I decided to take my family here since they love ramen and this place was really good. Walked in and got seated within 5 minutes.  We all ordered the same thing the tonkatsu ramen. When it came mine had no pork in it. I kindly asked the waiter named Rachel and she then proceeded to the kitchen. She then told her other coworker which he rolled his eyes. Hey not my mistake it was theirs. She brings it and I was kind of surprised because it was only a single thin slice. I guess I'm use to other ramen places where they put 2. My sister made a remark " oh so small". The waitress over heard and came to our table saying  " only comes with 1 piece" weird because she was eavesdropping. I also forgot to tell them no veggies in mine or my sister's. But that was my mistake. No problem so I picked them out. The same waitress proceeded to our table once again and said " next time order no veggies so you're not picking everything out" in a very rude manner.  Is she out of her mind? Talking to a customer like that. I work in customer and food. I wouldn't dare talk like that. We were all pretty taken back by her rude comments. Her and her coworker would not stop dogging our table and talking about us. Clearly In a different language (Chinese)  The whole time my family felt uncomfortable. Not to mention they never checked up on us once.  She was also arguing with the chefs in the kitchen. Not only could we hear her but other customers turned their attention to them.  Sigh, this place has really good ramen. Not sure if we'll be back though. To sum everything up  Great food, shitty service!

MPutGwLZ4Uc5_R--oZ1jgg.text: I just found my favorite ramen spot in town. Got bar seating as soon as I walked in. Service was above average. I ordered the tonkatsu ramen and pork belly bowl. The ramen was excellent. The noodles are made fresh in-house. You can actually see this in action right before you walk into the main entrance. The broth was not salty. This was very appetizing since all of the ramen spots I've tried in town are too salty to the point where I am unable to finish the soup. You can easily distinguish the fresh tasting noodles. It was very smooth and the texture was perfect. This bowl was the first ramen bowl that I have ever finished. I only got the half bowl of the pork belly. It was served over rice. The belly was sliced very thin with just the right amount of seasoning. The rice used is the sushi grade quality. Tender with a hint of sweetness. All the condiments were neatly arranged. I also like that they still have napkin dispensers at arm's reach. Prices are very reasonable. I highly recommend this place and I will definitely return when I am craving authentic Japanese ramen.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork belly bowl
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkatsu (Chicken and Pork Broth)

Xe9FEnxQDqB7ue7qdTc3IQ.text: This spot seats you quickly and has an intimate dining setup. Tables are close and the atmosphere is comfortable. Man oh man, I love the ramen here. It's the best I've tasted so far in this city! It's fresh and the spice level is great! I love the broth as well. Cheap price for good quality food. If you're in the Southwest, check this ramen spot out!

Sn_P2bGqopMjsOgg8UH8AQ.text: Visited Ramen Kobo for the first time.  I was not blown away but I was not disappointed.  I ordered the Shoyu Ramen.  Tasty and light.  Just the way I like it.  I will definitely would like to visit here again next time I'm in town.  I would skip the ground pork this time cuz I felt it overwhelmed the chicken broth flavor.  If you want fast service and good food, this is a good place.

e0a6lZ8TUCW_nNF6A3cQUw.text: Really good veggie ramen. Noodles were super chewy and delicious. Come here if you're vegetarian/vegan!

a0y6y_lryMlMmUl1-3pHBw.text: This is by far the best ramen I have had in Vegas. Yes, better than jinya. They make their noodles fresh in house and there is a glass panel where you can watch, which is a nice touch. The space is small but cute, kind of reminds me of a restaurant you'd see in New York. I don't know how to explain why it's good other than it just tastes better . My only complaint is I wish it was open later.

9ZaeXQfPx5fCy0f6dP0-qQ.text: Local, Authentic Ramen-ya in SW Vegas. We've been a few times already, and even recommended it to family that live in the area. The place is tiny, so expect a wait.  The menu isn't massive, but what they do have, they do WELL.  The Ramen is fresh, and made ON SITE. You can't go wrong with that. Broths are tasty (I've had the Miso and Shoyu) and you can get a ton of add ins for a fairly reasonable price. Definitely hope this place stays open for a long time!

qdiC4_z0DK42ccMBET8Nww.text: Best Ramen in the summerlin area. Only thing is that their restaurant is tiny and if there are a lot of people, it gets super packed. The food quality is incredible tho. I've been to Japan , in some real ramen joints, and Kobo is close! The customer service is also great. They do their best to get you seated asap.

SJDUM5TVft75kxecyQPukg.text: Not sure what is happening to this joint, but the first time we tried their ramen, it was actually bomb. However, during our recent couple visits, the food seems to be a little cold. The chashu pork was still kind of frozen, the broth was at room temperature, and my husband found a whole chunk of garlic in his ramen. The garlic stalk was still really raw. It was like chewing grass. Lol. The taste was still good, but the quality is kind of deteriorating.

RRBd5g9JFlrPEwVsiZNq9A.text: Stupid STUPID good! So fresh and spicy and delicious it's even better than jinya. YES, BETTER THAN JINYA. Why it took me so long to try kobo I do not know and regret greatly.  Best thing on the menu: miso ramen, hot, add black garlic oil, spinach, corn, egg, and extra noodles (which is an absolute MUST). Hold the scallions and bean sprouts. Thank me later. But really, killer noodles. And you can watch them being made by hand. I haven't had table service so I don't know how it is but If their to go is this good, I can't imagine how it is in house.

t2A8XcEu_mlWTPfz3BDFOg.text: Some of the best ramen in town! They make the ramen noodles in house! You can choose your level of spiciness, which I love. Great customer service too!  During the week they close in between lunch and dinner, so be sure to check their hours before you go! On Saturday and Sunday they don't close between lunch and dinner, they're open all day. Try this restaurant!

g8EXaqMTJwWNyvHU4NG_Hw.text: Food is still good, but they're getting stingy. I usually order the kiddo a side of noodles $1.50 and a side of shoyu broth $2.00 (he likes it basic) and there's no issue. Fast forward a few weeks and apparently "they can't do that". Now what they CAN do is Shoyu Ramen with no toppings, which is the same price as with ALL the toppings, which is $8.95.  It's still yummy, I just don't like the trend of price hiking once a restaurant becomes established.. Don't get me wrong, I'm not cheap, I add about $6-7 worth of upgrades to my ramen alone but come on.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States

zZy-jUiDsbXa8SFrqvDefA.text: We came to this place because it was open late in the area we live in. The guest service was ok at best. The food came out fast and exactly the way we ordered it. The full size rice order was small.  Over all, it was ok but there are better choices for Ramen in Vegas.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States

h7iXTYHPIP6PGHVgul9iKQ.text: I've been coming to this place for quite a bit now, and I have to say a little disappointed with the consistency. One day I order the same thing as always and it'll be the best bowl of ramen I've had, the next day (literally) I will order and it'll be mediocre. The staff are pleasant. Sat down to eat a few times before and was helped to find a good ramen that suited my tastes. Not much options for beverages, but good enough. Easy enough to take out order too, just a little unfortunate this is the closest ramen place to me. Sadly, nothing special, overpriced a bit and you don't really get your money's worth half the time. Wish I had better things to say about this place, really do.

noFMa8VVLOuoNUj7G90kPQ.text: Pretty good place. I'm not too familiar with food like this. So I can't just give it 1 star because I don't like the food. Overall good experience, it's kinda hard to know what to order if it's your first time. Also, it's a little pricey can't lie.   I got like noodles with some chicken in it. It was ok, nothing crazy. As I stated I'm not used to eating this type of food. I also got the hottest flavor! Bad choice wayyy to hot lol. I would check it out if you in the area.

rl4j7UdYY4av6HadBU53Fw.text: I'll make it short and not so sweet... ordered 2 ramen bowls and a belly bowl. Got belly bowl, ate it (I'll rate it 3 out of 10) and no ramen yet. Waiting for ramen.... nothing after another 15 mins. Then check came! Never in a million meals have we ever received the check without getting the whole meal! To sum it up, didn't have to pay for meal and will not be coming back.

-8cYaHdvy4E6FMCLB0guVQ.text: Mhm! This place is definitely a great addition to the Monta family. We decided to check out this restaurant based off a recommendation and were happy we did!   I ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen with medium spicy and a soft-boiled egg. The appetizer menu was fairly limited, but they did offer four different ramen broths, a huge variety of toppings ($$) and the standard pork belly and chasu bowls.  Advice: If you're a huge meat eater, order additional chasu. If you want an egg, get it. Need extra carbs? Get it! Your ramen bowl, even with the additional toppings, will still cost you less than a Bay Area ramen restaurant ;)  Pros: - Spice! Mhm. If you're looking to add a kick to your ramen, this place delivers. - Ground Pork was super flavorful. - Noodles were chewy!  - Clean restaurant  Cons: - Service was slow for a non-busy time. - Broth was a little too light for me. If I'm getting Tonkotsu, I sort of expect a super creamy and rich soup. - Only one chasu slice offered, but maybe that was a good thing. It's delicious, but super fatty!  Overall, this place was decent and I'd come again. I still prefer Monta Chaya or Monta Ramen over this place. For about two people, we paid $25ish with tip and tax.

Lnr3ipRLiqHQTLpk8HjOIQ.text: A buddy  took me here for lunch the other day and it did not disappoint, has to be one of the best ramen spots in town.  Was told that Ramen KoBo has the same owners of Monta so if your a fan of that place (which I am!) you should also like KoBo. They make their noodles in house which are nice and thick and they also offer you a spice level which you don't get that option at Monta. From the broth to the meat and fixens, it was a really good meal. Place is small but they do a great job of getting people in and out, no complaints.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Delish.

CwwCR2vFs3E4OvIwIfKeCQ.text: LOVE LOVE LOVE LOVE THIS PLACE!! Would eat this everyday if I could but my boyfriend doesn't.

n3Qem6W8vsAdiEzOMgkknQ.text: Love this place. It's very small. But the food is fantastic and fast. Fried rice is to die for. My husband loves adding the garlic paste to pretty much everything lol. Very affordable. My kids love going with there with there gf/bf and I see my cousins on fb eating here too. Good place to go on a cold day or feeling sick and need soup day.

caunNqd3-YX5JkvcVybTUw.text: I was SO excited to try their vegan ramen but sadly, it was kind of a disappointment.   We came on Saturday right when they opened and we were surprised that people were already outside the door waiting in line and thought this place must have some tasty ramen! We were seated right away and liked the design of the place - there was a ramen bar and the tables are pretty close to one another so heads up that you'll be getting comfy with other parties next to you lol.   The menu also include fried rice bowls and the various toppings you can add to your ramen. The vegan ramen sounded so promising, especially after all the great reviews but now I'm thinking maybe it's cause they just opened for the day that the broth didn't get to settle? I'm not sure but it was SO watered down, to the point that I honestly thought I was just eating ramen in hot water. I had to add more salt and some soy sauce and even hot sauce to try to make the meal more enjoyable, but nothing worked. Our friend ordered the chicken ramen and also wasn't satisfied; there was just something about our broths that made the experience an unsatisfying one.   We did enjoy the small bowl of fried rice but believe me when I say, it was definitely small lol.   Overall, I'm not sure if it was just our visit but I really wanted to like this place and sadly, that just didn't happen.

O66JDw8GcAFymxZO1_xISg.text: First time and won't be my last!!! I love homemade ingredients and this is a NOODLE MAKING FACTORY!!!  I got the miso broth with all the veggies and some ground pork. Add a little hot sauce and you got your self a great meal, especially on a chilly night   I didn't try but was eyeballing the girls bao buns next to me and look forward to trying next time

HgCrALMBSdbr5oYucoJ8Nw.text: Are you kidding me! This place is right across from my house.  The best ramen ever! So tasty, I can't eat those huge bowls this was perfect size.  I will tell all my friends and go back. I had Miso and ate every bite.  Service was excellent too!

EK4vvNnO2k8dX5xue_mbmA.text: Calling all ramen fans! This is the place you all need to be. If your looking for a ramen house that is 100% #flavortown with that authentic felling as if your in Japan come on down  I will not lie to you all my lady and could not stay away, we had ramen 4 days in a row. The staff is friendly the service is spot on. Most importantly everything is clean and open to see you can watch the cooks prepare your food!.  ...  P.S if your still not sold on this establishment they make their noodles from scratch you can watch them as it's being made.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States

3Vq-cpNVF837AhKmzg4NCA.text: I like this place. Their homemade noodles don't taste that bad actually, good with the miso ramen I ordered. On the menu however, I wished that the ingredients stated in Step 1 said that beans sprouts in the bowl, but they didn't. I'm not too big of a fan of bean sprouts, so I would've asked to hold on that. Service was okay. The older lady was a lot nicer, while the younger lady there seemed like she didn't want to be there. I would come back though as the ramen is pretty good.  UPDATE: correction it does say bean sprouts on the menu, still docking off a star for the service there precious time

9UlTaqbbed3KzjHmDsdXCA.text: Very cozy place Food came right away and no confusion with the order Since it's our 1st time here , we would give this place another try My wife ordered the spicy and not spicy tonkatsu soup The spicy noodle soup is so much better We recommend this place  We like it

q_VPpJPb54OfVDJaF18nYw.text: I was really excited when I saw this place open up! It's awesome and refreshing to see a place that makes noodles in house vs using the soulless mass produced noodles from country XXX.  I came in here one night about an hour before closing. The place was still banging and full of patrons. From the looks at the podium there was a mad wait list at one point. I was Flying solo I took a seat at the countertop. I actually enjoy sitting at the countertop as you can watch the "magic" happen. I was a little perturbed that the wait staff was more concerned about taking care of their closing tasks vs waiting on guests. I had to watch the wait staff team walk past me several times before I was able to get my order in.   The noodle making stuff had been shut down for the day so that bummed me out.. I guess it's bad luck to make noddles in the dark.   The ramen was a bit on the small side however proportionate for the price. I did feel that my original order was a little on this light side compared to my kaedama order. The first set of noodles were perfect. Just the right firmness and texture. The kaedama on the other hand was a bit overcooked and on the soggy side.   The broth was nothing fancy decent but nothing to wow about.   My visit here was a miss .. maybe it was the timing or maybe this is how it is here.. not sure.. the jury is still out..   Till then the choice is yours..

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Medium spice miso ramen with extra cha siu and butter

Y2dNOMkojfdD4QLGDSK8Kw.text: Best Ramen in Vegas.  Noodles are made fresh in house daily. Broth is on point. Just as good to dine in or carry out.

UPKs242aRQ_0Sc5RYZKRZA.text: Average, fast and good for the money. This place has an atmosphere of China Town after-party diner with EDM playing in the background, but is favored by families living in the neighborhood.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso ramen

EQxxuQR8HQ7X4yw4SfBE4A.text: Food was pretty good.  Service from the blonde young man was bad. Not a single thank you and he kept throwing menus on the table whenever new customers come in and even when he gave us the check he just kind of slammed it on the table. Maybe having a bad day or just frustrated at this job?  However, the lady server was really good. It's a shame she is getting less tips due to the other server.  Been here twice over over the years and I gotta say I could care less about this place.

k7elaVXczJobfOHTaB-I7w.text: Loooove their ramen. It was my first time there and to my surprise, the noodles are made fresh! It makes a difference in the flavor for sure. The waiting area is kinda small but once you sit down it's fine.

R4jNaBfEpw-INwr0xaETMg.text: Went here twice and we both got bad stomach 2 times. It never happened before when we ate ramen elsewhere. Will never come back.

bkxPzAHs_WArXTx71wWhJw.text: Winter is finally here in Vegas and eating ramen in the middle of the day won't make you sweat like the summer time lol. This is my go to spot since it's just across the street from my house and there's no complaints here. The staff is probably the sweetest,   most accommodating people I've encounter in an Asian restaurant ever.   I always order the original shoyu ramen (which is chicken broth) with chashu chicken, ground chicken (I opt out of anything pork in soups), mushrooms, bamboo shoots, bean sprouts, corn, nori, soft boiled egg and kimchi. The broth is the best part of it all. The right amount of saltiness with tons of chicken flavor. The noodles are a perfect mixture of firm and soft all at once. And all the fixings just make their ramen my favorite.   My son orders the chashu pork bowl with rice and shredded nori and he can put it away (like any growing boy).   Our favorite appetizer is the chashu pork baos. A little pork sandwich with mayo lettuce and chashu pork.   There are so many ramen spots to choose from in Las Vegas, but be sure to stop here when you're in the area.  They never disappoint.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu Ramen with chashu chicken, ground pork, corn, soft boiled egg, nori, bean sprouts, bamboo shoots &amp; mushrooms.
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Small Chashu Pork Bowl
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chashu pork bao

HJ-XA3iR9igROPyAJQSPmg.text: Came here on a Saturday night around 7:30pm. We were seated immediately, but the place is really small. By the time we got done there was a small wait outside.   The menu options are very straightforward. Which I don't mind because the more options I have, the more indecisive I become.   The ramen itself was pretty good. I got the Tonkatsu with medium spice level and black garlic oil. At first it looked like a crap ton of oil, but it actually wasn't. Flavors were well balanced. I can handle my fair share of heat, but even the medium seemed to have a stronger kick than I imagined (no complaints!) so I started white girl sweating

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkatsu ramen + black garlic oil + corn

qT7XZlFRdgUXDA8G4ferGg.text: This is the best place in town and I mean the whole Las Vegas area to get some mean Ramen!! Absolutely delicious!  The place is small and very busy, no complaints though. It's very good and obviously other people know it as well. It's like a Japanese, Chinese, Korean fusion and they offer things from all these cuisines. So give it a try, itll be worth it for sure. Prices are also very decent.

KVPoPkcg8L8hKPg8ze9sGg.text: Been to this ramen place several times, but it's a need when it's snowing in Vegas. We were greeted as soon as we came in but we waited 10 minutes to be seated. It's a small place with limited seating. You can either sit on the table or in the bar. We enjoyed watching the man making ramen noodles in front of us in the waiting area. My favorite here is Miso Ramen mild (sometimes medium) with Nitamago and its a perfect meal for a cold or snowy night indeed! Eggs are cooked in perfection. Ramen noodles are fresh and broth is so flavorful. $1 if you want to add extra broth. Quick and friendly service. Oh! Don't forget to try their chasu buns, they were great too.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso Ramen mild with Nitamago
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States

xciGbgCSMI4kjninslyG4w.text: The ramen here is good if you're in the area. I use to go here a lot after I gymmed at EOS, but now that I don't I wouldn't go out of my way to go to ramen kobo. Even though it still tastes good, I think there are better options out there. First off, the menu is pretty limited. I really do love how the noodles here are handmade and they let you see that. However, I prefer thick noodles and I don't have the option to do that here. I hope to see more items on the menu in the future - maybe then I'll come back! As for the broth, they don't have very much flavor if you get it no spicy, and the broth is the most important part of any soup! Not the spice. Adding the spice covers up the bland soup in my opinion. Whenever I get ramen here without spice I always have to add butter or soy sauce, especially to the veggie broth. I understand how a veggie broth is naturally more bland, but the veggie broths at Jinya taste perfectly fine by themselves. I really don't have this problem at other ramen shops. If you're a spice lover though, this place is definitely for you since a majority of the flavor is in the spice!!! I personally just don't handle spice very well but my sibling that does loves this place. The inside is very small, and there can be a long wait. It gets pretty loud inside too, so it's a little difficult to talk to the people you're with. Overall it's not a bad place though! I'll stop by if I'm in the area if I'm craving ramen, but not my first choice!

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. veggie ramen mild

3ygpG9KTpLltsA1QqOFDlQ.text: This is great ramen! I really love it. I've eaten here a bunch of times, both in house and for take out. My go-to ramen starts with tonkotsu. At Ramen KoBo I also eat the tonkotsu. I like the heat of the "mild"as it's not too hot to cover the flavor of this yummy broth. The pork is nicely fatty, which I love.  I actually add extra pork and soft boiled egg Overall this ramen is flavorful and filling.  This time I had takeout and the pork was cold, so I microwaved the broth so it was extra hot to compensate and heat through the pork.  I do wish there was more broth.   The pork belly bowl is also really tasty. I usually get the small as a side dish for sharing or if I'm feeling particularly ravenous.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The takeout ramen together in a bowl
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Small pork belly bowl
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu ramen take out with extra chashu pork

pGgvdueNoDaanTDGQOMzgg.text: This is one of my favorite ramen places to come to, and the best part is that it is close to my home!  I love how small and quaint this restaurant is, although that leads to long wait times, the experience and food is always worth it. They make their ramen there, and there is a window for you to see while you are waiting for your table!  The menu is limited, but you will not be disappointed with whatever you get. Their kimchi fried rice is so good, you must get it along with your ramen. I have never had better fried rice! You can customize your ramen bowl with many different options, I typically tend to get shoyu ramen (chick broth) with chashu chicken, nitamago (soft boiled egg... YUM), and corn. I am not big on super spicy, but my boyfriend gets the fire spice level and says it adds so much to flavor and is not so spicy that it's not enjoyable.  If you sit at the bar, you get to watch everyone make your meal. The chefs are fun and very friendly. I love this ramen spot and recommend that you give it a try! Just be prepared for a wait.

DW_Hwe2-03H2dCMIhG31DA.text: I love this place.  I appreciate that they make their own noodles right there and we can watch.  I also appreciate that they have different spice levels (but be careful even mild is pretty spicy!) as well as additions you can add to any ramen bowl you order.  I have been coming here for years and usually get take out but on occasion I have dined in.  Service is always great but the wait is some times crazy but that just means this place is great!

59HXa-bPkYWcPTpffS46jw.text: Decided to finally try this place after three years here in Las Vegas. I have a couple of go to spots but I heard a lot of the locals raving about this place and I had to totally try it.  I guess The big Lord is the front area where you can see them spinning or making their fresh noodles. Come during the day because I guess that's when they do it. At night not so much. Place is tiny like most of the Ramen places here in Vegas. Long narrow I'll away with about 12 seats at the counter and about six or seven tables. The menu is very traditional and very limited. If you're used to some of the tourist places in Chinatown this won't be for you. Handful of selections are very limited.  Started off with an order of the traditional fried rice. Decided to get it vegetarian with no meat. Decent serving size for the price. Not over cooked and well seasoned. Give this one a very hefty 4/5. Flavor profile really did it for me. Ask for extra pickle ginger.  After that decided to go with the veggie Ramen and the shoyu ramen. Both of the broths seem kind of bland. Not chock-full of flavors. You could definitely taste the freshness of the noodles but once again they were just OK. Definitely had to ask for seasoning and spices on the side. You think the prices are decent but once you chalk up some of the extras that you might get for cheap or for free at other places each ball comes out to about $20.  Portion sizes are decent. We had left over from both soups. Not sure if it was because we were full or because it just wasn't that great. Like I said, then going to a couple of the other places for a few years and noticed flavor profiles were way different. And the price point was a little disappointing. In all fairness I think before you pass judgment or you pick a favorite, try at least 3 to 5 different Ramen places to really know what you like and want. I did notice this was more of an after work style place where people came in alone sat at the counter ordered some soup eat really quickly then left. Not really a fun atmosphere to come out and hang with friends.  Staff was pretty friendly and eager to help. Place was clean. Just not my favorite.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. $20 ramen after adding a few things... wow... 3/5
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Veggie ramen was ok. 3/5
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Fried rice was good.4/5

kEZFIHhUzOveC1po6jKYHg.text: I was looking forward to trying the ramen here because: a. ramen is one of my husband's favorite foods to eat lately b. they have a vegetarian ramen option here c. it's very close to our house  Unfortunately, ordering the to-go vegetarian ramen was a supreme disappointment. Not only did it look nothing like the pictures and included varied ingredients with way too much ginger, both of our broths were spicy when we ordered mild. Further, the broth amount that they gave us was so miniscule that it barely even covered the less than one-inch height of noodle block they gave us. I ended up adding water to mine, but was so disheartened at the money I wasted on an even less than mediocre meal.

erA6W_DkBhhUI4c9TJiWug.text: All the ramen broths here taste very different but have distinct delicious flavors. So they might be hit or miss for you. I went here with my parents and the wait was a little bit long ~20 minutes on a weekday. The best thing is probably that all the broths are the same price ($8.95). I recommend little spice since medium spice can be a bit overpowering.   Not the best ramen I've had but it's not bad. Wouldn't mind coming back here but I'll probably try a different place when I'm in the area.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States

0YE6UqbCYqQFlc9SEz9EFg.text: Pork Tonkotsu WOW!! I could eat this all day!! Fresh and flavourful perfect amount of spice. Great gyosa dumplings! Love it.

-hXLOibnvVrEzx9if6N1Vg.text: This was my first time trying out this place and it wasn't too bad. We got there as soon as it opened and it was already busy for lunch and the service was good the place is just small like most ramen shops.   Food wise I would say that everything that we tried was greatly good. The gyoza there was probably my favorite one I've had at a ramen shop because it was only steamed and not fried. The ramen was good too. Not my favorite but I would definitely eat there again. It's just because of the noodles there, the broth was great and it tasted pretty similar to most places and the toppings were the same like most places. Overall it is a place I think that everyone should try.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Gyoza
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso broth ramen

nw_fIXVlL4A2f9ibL4bJyA.text: I went here twice in a week! The ramen is awesome. I love the fact that they make it FRESH, right in front of you. You can see the guy making the noodles behind a glass wall right when you come in.  The restaurant is a little small but seems like all the ramen places here is like that.    My favorite is actually the rice bowl. I get the small chashu bowl and it's plenty. I think it's a little bland so I add shoyu and the red pepper. Yumm!

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso ramen with medium spice on the side.
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chashu bowl- small

Xi4Dlo35msnEPLHIgi-Znw.text: Stopped by for lunch.. the noodles really redeemed this place. The menu is really small so for my other half who doesn't like ramen it was slightly difficult as far as options.   He ordered the chashu bowl and we asked for extra crispy but it came back burnt/ dry. The regular cooking is good but I thought it would be better with a little extra crisp.   I got tonkotsu medium and it was pretty average. There wasn't that full bodied flavor I crave but the spice they use does take it up a notch. I wish I could get all my favorite restaurants together and move around the variables haha.   I probably won't be back unless the menu gets bigger or I hear that the soup gets better.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. &#34;Extra crispy&#34; Chashu = BURNT

iJeWZy_8cMALbIBQlBhYww.text: Tiny restaurant but like that you can watch the fresh noodle-making while you wait. The menu is simple, with 4 ramen soup base types for $8.95 all with the same ingredients to which you can add more for $1-1.50 each. There are a handful of additional menu items - handmade dumplings, chasu pork baos, fried rice etc. but you really come here for the ramen. Having tried original and mild, I'd recommend mild which is a little spicy and has more of a kick than the original non-spicy soup base, but it's all good. Draft beer is only $2.95. The service is good and food comes out fast so for a tiny restaurant they turn over tables quickly.   They have a second location on Spring Mountain, maybe that one is bigger.  Nothing fancy but can totally see this becoming a regular stop.

lKP9AjcwYwVI1KtOjT7G3w.text: Literally my go-to ramen in Las Vegas. Staff is always friendly. To-go orders are always correct. Food is always amazing! I love the little piece of roasted garlic that's in the broth! Sometimes if you're lucky you end up with two, haha!  I guess the only negative would be that sometimes the spice levels vary. At times medium will be super spicy & sometimes hot will not be that spicy. This doesn't really bother me that much. Also, seating can be a little bit small.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Fried rice
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu ramen hot
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Original spice

a4APWksNVmvAp96ioK9yWA.text: Low quality of food. I had very bad food poisoning after I left from the restaurant an hour later. I used to love this place until I saw the chef clean the boiling station by using the red sanitizer bucket with the hot water. I don't think it's the right way to clean. The sanitizer bucket might has a chemical thing in the bucket you know. After that I don't really want to come back here again.

l61hm4dwQqv4vivgPlQyZQ.text: I've been coming here several times with my husband for the last couple years.  Not once have we ever been disappointed, and each visit gets better each time.  The wait can be a bit long depending on when you go, but I say it's worth it.  I always get the Tonkotsu Ramen original just because by itself is delicious and doesn't need to be altered unless you want it spicy, I usually like adding garlic paste.  I like the noodles cause it's not too soft or too firm, it's just right.  They also have red ginger and vinegar you can add to your broth.  Also the Pork Belly Bowl is to die for, they have other appetizers but we always ALWAYS get this one!  Lol.  And Rachel never ceases to amaze me with her outstanding service to us and all the customers that come in.  Her sweet charm and smile is always a pleasure to see!  I pretty much recommend anyone to come here for well-worth ramen.  If you're looking for a place to have some, this is it. =)

jhJF06ajSgUNiNKYYer-LA.text: Amazing, must try! Ordered Miso ramen, med spice, added corn, seaweed, bamboo shoots and egg!

WW_9lX4qsBPBo0Thi59tMw.text: They have a display right at the door to show that they make their noodles fresh. I think that is their selling point but I didn't taste any different except that the noodles don't stick together.  The broth is salty. The meat is thin. Compare to other ramen place, they are missing the usual toppings such as marinated bamboo and egg. To add one egg, it is $1.50 extra which bring one bowl of simple noodle to over $10. The place is small but with not too long of a wait.  This place is very average and the value is not good. I guess it is good for locals who don't like to drive far or wait too long. I will not come again because the food is very average and not competitive.

eaKyyEyPh7eAM69CJwdebw.text: Delicious ramen! hope theh just have bigger space to accommodate and not waiting that long! Love their KimiFriedRice!

1be0-GpXB7CHrtVdyDC-4Q.text: This place was fantastic! They make their own noodles and the prices are super reasonable. Also, very accommodating to vegetarian and vegan needs.

72GbshPZpsh6QYmFBZiPQg.text: First time eating ramen and it was the best place to go! The staff was super friendly and welcoming. We waited about 5 minutes to be seated but that's nothing for a Saturday at lunch hour. I probably wouldn't recommend going with more than 2 people because it's really small. Soooo happy they had vegan ramen. It was so good, I already want to go back. The prices are really good, too. Super cheap and they give you a very large portion. Super satisfied. I'll be going back again soon :)

Z_6Y77qumU-l2By5j0Qa7A.text: First off.. I really wanted to like this place. I was happy there was another ramen shop in our area of town, and couldnt wait for this place to open when I saw it was coming a few months back. When I called in I had to repeat myself about 4 times to the person taking the order. I understood though, as it was around the 6pm dinner rush. When I got there to pick up the food, there was no parking, so I had to drive around 3 times to actually get a spot. When I walked in there was no one at the hostess stand, except for a lady placing an order on an ipad. A sever came over and asked me " If I needed anything?", and I said yes, Im here to pick up an order. She walked away towards the kitchen for what I thought was my food, Even though there were 2 bags of orders on the counter directly behind her. Instead of looking for my food, she went to grab orders for people that were sat down. Someone came out of the back to the hostess stand about 2-3 minutes later and asked me what I needed... Again. I tell her, the first server came back and started to try and help me but ended up giving my food to another customer that walked in. Then she took it back and gave it to me and I paid.. The guy got upset.. even though I was there first.. and called me an a-hole as I walked out. To summarize, they are disorganized.   The food was not what I had expected. I ordered the tonkotsu Spice level 4.. broth was like salted creamy water. The chashu I ordered was almost all fat, and you have to pay extra for sprouts and egg. My wife and son ordered the shoyu ramen, they were not impressed. We also got a small order of the fried rice that everyone has reviewed so much, and spoke so highly about... It had a distinct fishy taste to it. My son is sort of a 4 year old ramen aficionado. The kid loves it and is very vocal about what he likes and doesnt like about it. I have to go with his instincts and agree this is not some place I would recommend. Maybe if we all ordered something different, or we ate there it might be better. After the first time I dont know if I care to try that out.

gaVokfhubZ06howDaxfPKQ.text: Spicy Ramen lover heaven. Flavorful and they let you choose your level spice. One of the cleanest and tidiest ramen I've seen; big plus

Dl89dRlwpDbfE8ScvjRPow.text: Perfect for this soup weather!!! Busy; 20mins in. Always a great sign of greatness!!! So yummy the fresh noodles!!!

2eOrK6xlhaNDQqUBCJdpFw.text: So glad to have a ramen place so close to home. I ordered takeout. Went to pick it up and the staff was incredibly friendly and inviting. I absolutely LOVE the fact that they make their own noodles. Got everything home and really enjoyed both bowls. Chicken broth with a few different meats. All tasted great. I will absolutely be back!

SX9UD6_VOtl18oc7ZPfbPQ.text: When you walk in, the first thing you see is a pasta machine for the noodles which is awesome because you see it being made. It's way smaller than I expected. I wanted beer but they didn't have the beers yet. Why would you open without having all of the products that are on the menu? Whatever so I had a Coke. Let's be realistic here, a can of Coke does not cost $1.25. At Monta (same owner) it's only $1. It's .25 cents more but that .25 shows a lot. Very easy menu to me so I love that. Not too many options so you're not stuck for 20 minutes trying to pick what you want which is awesome because you turn over tables faster. They don't have gyoza. This is the first ramen place that doesn't have gyoza on the menu. I got the chashu bowl and asked for it with extra sauce. The server said okay and my man ordered the pork belly bowl with extra sauce. They came back without sauce and were so dry. The pork was dry and my chashu was really delicious. Just too try. Apparently they don't come with sauce. Then don't say okay? I understand that it's their second day but that's so obnoxious. Learn the menu before opening. When he told the manager and server about the dryness, no apology, didn't comp it off, and nothing. All she said was that it's their second day. Congrats. It's a restaurant. I had eggs in my ramen but they came on the side even before the ramen???? You could've waited to put it in? I don't know. The food was fine but not to my standards.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States

EX3HNYaSeFA_R8nX1WYV6Q.text: Opening day is today. Sitting at the table waiting for the ramen. So far, the menu is nicely laid out, and easy to navigate. The place is small and thin, with the small bar counter up against the kitchen like a ramen house should be. Best ramen houses are holes in the wall. This is just a nicely interior decorated hole in the wall. Greeted at the door by multiple people. Served our drinks and waited on very quickly. It is close to closing and not packed, so I'd hope for that. But it's never guaranteed. Everybody was very nice. I started typing this review after we put in our order, and we just got the order. Fast. Ordered tonkatsu ramen with egg, medium heat. Let's see how it tastes...  Delicious. Broth is nice and thick, slightly fatty--like it should be. Pork melts in your mouth. Noodles--since they're freshly made here, they're springy and delicious. Egg is done perfectly. Everything about it is great. They use garlic chives, and didn't skimp with just green onion. The medium is quite spicy. And my husband and I both love spicy. So for the person who had mild and felt it wasn't spicy, there must be a large jump between mild and medium. But that's normal for most Asian cuisine. Portion is great.  Rachel and Maru came around multiple times to give us more of our drinks, and make sure we were happy. Highly recommend this place. First great ramen place outside of Chinatown. And it's near my house!!! Score!!!!

g1We6kKTfH65rherNOrD8g.text: Great noodles! Had one fried rice, one miso, and one with chicken. Add the egg and be prepared for spice. Even the mild is very spicy and while the flavour is phenomenal, it picks a big punch. There was a very short wait to be seated - which was indicative of how good it would be - and they pack in the people for some ramen-licious yumminess!

In9EJCzfHbsYj9NEdf1lqQ.text: A sister shop of Monta. They serve a variety of ramen (they have a noodle machine in the shop) and many other common items that you may find at a typical ramen shop such as Kimchi fry rice, pork belly bowl, etc.. The ramen is not as strong/flavorful as Monta but still very good. If you like ramen but feel Monta is too strong/oily/salty to your taste, you will most likely love this place.

PWT_n-NN9M4NFXyVaXDc8g.text: Been wanting to try this place specifically from their fresh ramen noodles.  Kind of disappointed that the noodles were not made to order.  What's the point of having the glass room with the machine but it's not being used? Lol   Luckily from the texture of the noodles, it does seem freshly made (ahead of time).  Another disappointment was the taste of the broth.  We ordered miso and tonkasu and it both fell short. Not to mention we also asked for spicy and it wasn't as spicy as we imagined 3 pepper signs to be.  First time having chives in Ramen rather than scallions??? Cha Shui was sliced super thin. Also add ons toppings were around $1-1.50, more than average ramen joints around town.  All in all, pretty disappointed.  For around the same price I prefer Monta, Sora, or Ramen Tatsu

OVz3N2z7aquu-pvy-B0QJQ.text: I've been to 3 or 4 ramen restaurants in Vegas and nothing compares to Kobo. My go-to is Miso sometimes mild sometimes medium. For the bigger appetites you can add extra noodle for a small fee (recommended). Very well priced. Lots of extras and add-ins to make it perfect for your tastes. Staff is as friendly as can be. Just go and thank me later.

zgTCccCUVI7IemxyudFXnA.text: Food/service was amazing!! By the way did you guys happen to find a debit card? It reads homar macias-duenez i think i left it.

QrcxohziTH8p3TGPrqBz3Q.text: Service was great. Ramen gave me explosive diarrhe@h. Tmi, but if you want to spare your colon the pain and suffering.. be careful.

wmX6IwRKC0vOWVudbit7qg.text: Soup is not hot. It's warm. Server Rachel didn't even bother replacing it upon request instead she's going to charge additional for a hotter broth. Bad customer service. I live in the area but won't recommend. Very bad service.

PVIsJMw8f55q6vRNBCdEKA.text: Good place for ramen house. Somewhat comparable to some Ramen noodles house in Seattle.

wBcUg1wzk1BDtH5RBF7o2A.text: Good food. Only problem is this place is soooo small and parking is limited. The wait is a while and the waiting space gets crowded that people have to go outside and wait.

KptXl5teM94nGA89ciG8nA.text: 10 STARS! Hands down my favorite spot to get ramen! Best quality for the price! It is however only meant for small parties of 4 or less. My girl and I come here very often either for take out or dine in. They are very polite and have excellent service. If you want to get full I suggest get any of the ramen choices your way and add extra noodles! Price are roughly around $10 per bowl of ramen and side dishes are around $5. Keep it up Ramen KoBo!!! We'll always be back!

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu Ramen, Medium Spicy, Extra Noodles

NK2u3aJjvCb-Rp0XhskRkQ.text: I have been wanting to try this ramen shop since it opened in my neighbourhood. Finally, I had a chance to stop by for lunch on a weekday.  I arrived around 12:30 pm and it wasn't busy inside. There were only about 10 customers inside.  The interior was nice and I took a seat at their bar.  I like to see the cook's skill in preparing the ramen.  But to my surprise all the cooks and waiter were Hispanics with the exception of the hostess who was Asian female.  Stepping into a Japanese ramen joint, I expected that the cook(s) would be Japanese.  Maybe I am just too traditional.  So, even though I was skeptical, I was interested to see how authentic they could prepare the ramen bowl.  I only order their Tonkotsu ramen as I wasn't all that hungry.  I must say that I wasn't impressed.  For $8.95 + tax, you get one small piece of char siu in the bowl and no ajitsuku tamago (egg). The broth was nothing special as it was not rich and creamy. The presentation was just meh.    I wasn't too happy that I could not pay with a credit card as I had to spend over $10 to use a credit card.  When I left, no one said one word to me.  No bye, no thank you!?! This place is so not typical of a Japanese ramen joint, where their staff are usually very polite and thankful.  My verdict, I definitely will not be going back to this place.     Click here to Reply or Forward
