Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States

U7bJ03H_-rcxHYO_5bPIyA.text: Ramen Kobo is one of our go to restaurants when my family is craving for ramen.  There are not many tables like a typical ramen house.  We try to go before 6 to avoid waiting for a table as we are a family of 5.  They make the noodles fresh in-house.  The kids enjoy watching the noodles being made as we wait for out table.  I usually order the miso ramen.  I like tonkatsu ramen at Monta but I prefer the miso at Ramen Kobo.  The fried rice is good but we like the fried rice at Monta slightly better.  It's in the southwest side of town where there are not many choices when it comes to ramen houses.    If you do not want to drive to spring mountain Chinatown area and live in the southwest side of town I recommend Ramen Kobo.

-3T9nNOF770MeLGF_y2weg.text: I'm in love with this place. The service  the price  the options  the taste  only one thing though the extra toppings were served cold with my ramen. I would've preferred to have had the heated before serving.

-qk8LaQ_ZJOS1r08YOoA7A.text: This place is definitely the best ramen joint I've visited so far and I've been to four now. I like how you can customize your entire dish. Unlike the other ones you have to pick one and edit it to what you really want.   Their broth(soup) is flavorful and the spice levels are actually actuate. Would be cool if they had a thicker noodle. But hey, at least it's made fresh and you can see it being made as you walk in to the right. Seating is kinda limited but it's still a fun place to go to get your ramen fix.   One thing keeping me from giving them a five star is the skimpy portion of the ground pork.   If you haven't been to the restaurant, you should give them a try!

33E39t0FKNCDNzA2d81DBQ.text: Junk nasty food. Little soup & noodles in bowl  They put only Chile sauce & spices for taste in hot water. Small one piece meat for pork belly. Cheap owner charge for veggies.

L8AwhKuve8DS3i8b-ZM8-A.text: Some of the best ramen I've had in Vegas!! Super fast service, servers are very nice & place is always clean!!

IFX6hlkraHK14JmYwLXyuA.text: My go to place for ramen! It's so delicious and lots of flavor. The dishes and service are consistent and fast every time I come here. Prices are favorable! My favorite is the tokontsu ramen, kimchi fried rice and pork belly/rice. I love the ginger, garlic paste and that seasoning!

yzfgmt4osWCZkBmElcBJlg.text: Found another great Ramen House this one is right up the street from where I live. House made noodles can't go wrong. The steamed pork bun was also excellent.I will definitely be returning.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States

CkWaZiq7xWHJkOGsZoADTg.text: Admittedly not the best in town but good enough to be a regular in the rotation.  The Tonkatsu is good...shoyu descent...i go with the Miso which combines both with miso paste....add egg, spinach, and extra chashu pork and it's fine substitute for Jinya.  One complaint is the ingredients (especially the chashu pork) are cold and really bring down the temperature of the dish when served.

O9ayt-3yOU53hsO4q6WAPA.text: Ramen is so great. Beware that it is a little spicy so order wisely. Also get in the mood for ramen at least once a month. Great service and food. Will always come and eat here.

Dh6vyUTsi3wogIclzhu-VA.text: While there may be some better options in Chinatown, this is one of the better choices here in the southwest. The broth is always good and the noodles are cooked well. The side dishes are all very good including the chashu bowl, fried rice, and pork belly bowl. My main complaint would be the cold chashu that is put into the ramen. It would be nice if it were warmed up prior to serving.

l_dhH0Rmw-HQR-0s6WNs0A.text: I moved out to Vegas a few months ago and have been trying different ramen restaurants. Ramen KoBo is by far the tastiest one I've been to.   FOOD:  Any place that makes their own noodles fresh in the restaurant is already ahead of the game but the broth is what actually matters. I ordered the spicy tonkatsu ramen which comes with one slice of cha shu, ground pork, mushrooms, bamboo shoots, and bean sprouts. For an extra $1.50, I added an egg, which still blows my mind that ramen places will charge extra for that (minus 1 start for that). I'm used to the egg being included. Anyway, for spicy lovers who like the kick of chili but still want their taste buds, medium is perfect. Not only did I eat all the noodles, but also drank all the broth.   QUALITY: You can't beat homemade noodles. And the broth was exactly what it needed to be. I can see how some people might complain about the saltiness but flavor of the broth is still delicious.   PRICE: It's about $9 for a bowl of ramen and extra ingredients range from $1.50 to $3.00. They also have sides for about $5-6, and beer within the $2 range (pretty affordable)!  CUSTOMER SERVICE:  Friendly staff. Two girls came to check on me periodically and refilled my water.   ENVIRONMENT: This place is somewhat tiny so I can see it getting packed during dinner hours. There is a ramen bar and dining table area.   Overall, I will come here again whenever I'm craving ramen!

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Medium spicy tonkatsu ramen with egg.

FnCuwcE9rzBqNou4kq-snQ.text: I had the veggie ramen from takeaway. It was pretty good! Nice noodle consistency and overall broth flavor. Which I had more tofu, but the amount makes sense for the dish overall. Just a preference.  I would suggest that if there are multiple items in an order for takeaway, label what's what. It caused a bit of confusion.   Otherwise, good experience.

7dmWaFIUlADNWKtYAUJGNg.text: Ramen KoBo executes ramen very well, but the lack of toppings on the preset ramen combinations prevent this place from reaching 5 stars.  The restaurant is fairly small, so don't bring giant groups to this place or else you'll have to wait awhile. Also, just a note: they only seat full parties and the waiting area is always pretty cramped. But my wait was actually fairly quick, considering we had a party of 8. Our waiter was friendly; he was also efficient as he got our waters right away and he took our orders without hesitation.   I ended up getting a mild Miso Ramen. I'll let you know right now, this was not mild. I'm usually good with spice/spices, but this place was a little too much for me. I would recommend choosing a spiciness level one below you think if you're like me and THINK you can handle spiciness. Even though the ramen was a bit too spicy, I could still taste the depth and flavor of the ramen. It was salty, smooth, and everything I could ask for in a ramen broth.   The noodles were the best part of the dish though. Handmade right in the restaurant, the noodles were long and cooked to perfection. Other places tend to overcook the noodles, making them limp and soggy, but not this place. Since they were cut bigger than usual, they had a good bite to it, and they absorbed the flavors of the broth very well.   The preset combination disappointed me though. It had the typical ingredients: chashu pork, fried garlic, black mushrooms, chives, ground pork, bamboo shoots, sesame oil, and shredded red pepper. But my problem was that it wasn't enough. And if you want to add extra ingredients, go for it! But expect to pay upwards of $15 to $20 for your ramen. That's a little steep for ramen if you ask me.  Overall, this place is great. From the fresh handmade noodles to the flavorful broth, Ramen Kobo knows ramen and knows it well. Just be warned that the ramen is SPICY and the extra ingredients will definitely rack up your bill!

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Mild Miso Ramen

Lg2e6FTbXO9RYHbszgdPQA.text: The ramen here is average.. Cool thing is the noodles are made here.. Its not in china town..so not always busy with high wait times.. Service is good.. Good parking space.. I would recommend it to try if you're looking for a new ramen spot!

Gr2xwHn0NeNjuASk5yzkXg.text: Tastes like spicy water, no concept of salt. I ordered the veggie ramen, but even my boyfriend who ordered the spicy tonkatsu was furiously disappointed. Jinya is less expensive and their quality of food is far superior. Save yourself the money and trouble, and go to Jinya..   Also, as a vegan the veg ramen at Jinya is the holy grail.

nGDnR2Vu11Q9Gc4jnLEaOw.text: I ordered the pork ramen without any add-ons. It was pretty delicious, however, you are better off ordering an additional pork slice into the ramen to give it a bigger boost of flavor. Also don't sprinkle too much of the red powder sauce into the ramen, I almost choked to death.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Interior
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork Ramen

12X7ndewNXIScjMdgE575g.text: I want this place to be 24/7 because it's the best Ramen I have ever had. Fast service, friendly staff, and a nice beer on tap. Only downfall is that it's so busy so sometimes it feels a bit rushed or you have to wait some time but it is so worth it. Very good Veggie options with very mild to super hot options. YUM!  (I live across the street and will sometimes sprint a 6 lane road for my noodles!)

q_CGq8X2rOTHAElCBubgMA.text: I enjoyed this place for Ramen and would be sure to come back. First to get the vegan review out of the way...  1.  They have a vegan ramen that the daughter states is out of this world.  I also tasted it and the broth was fantastic. I find it hard to get a really good broth for a vegan or vegetarian style ramen, however, this was excellent.  2.  Besides the vegan choice, we had a Shoyu Ramen and a tonkatsu ramen.  I had extra mustard greens with my Shoyu Ramen and also had it original.  3.  The noodles were excellent and homemade and fresh.  The broth, was very delicate with bits of oil floating from the bone broth and from the chashu pork that was in the ramen.  The pork was very tender and fall apart moist.  Loved it.  The noodles themselves were firm and had a great texture.  Perfect amount of vegetables to round out this tasty ramen.  I will be back to try more spicier versions of their dishes.  I wanted to be able to taste the broth without be hidden by the spices.  Good quick service, hot soup and tasty food.  GK says, check it out. Just be careful, it is a fairly small restaurant.

lGpAkUrhYJDvhTOK72RO4w.text: A great spot!  Tonkotsu Ramen Gyoza  Kimchi Fried Rice - my favorite  Very quick service + a 2 for $2 mochi deal. The mochi served was unlike any mochi I have tried before - was a vanilla cream flavor with ice cream that melted in your mouth and a very doughy layer.  Only complaint would be that they only serve beer for alcohol - would have ordered some wine

XKPdySlqvfnURYzcGAvTiA.text: The reviews for this place is really high so I was really anticipating a lot from this place. I had the pork broth medium spice level and my friend got the miso mild. We also order the chashu bun. For both ramen bowl the broth was underwhelming. My spice was really powerful that it overtook the whole ramen. The miso ramen was much better. The main complaint about this place is the chashu pork. Chashu is without a doubt one of the most important part of ramen. Good chashu is soft and melts in your mouth. This place pork is over cook and has a hard texture. It was like eating rubber when we were eating the chashu pork in our ramen. The pork buns were the best part of our meal, decent.  Overall food is 2/5 stars  Service was good thou

Rxk5UY1t4GTZQAL1t1XVBQ.text: While growing up, all I ever ate was ramen! It's easy, fast, and delicious to make. The best ramen I've ever had was in Japan and no other ramen shop in Vegas has come close to it except for Ramen Kobo!   First, Ramen Kobo is five minutes away from my house which is so convenient for me. Their parking space in the complex is a bit small so at times it can be annoying to find a parking spot when it's busy.  Upon walking in, you're immediately welcomed by the hostess and even the cooks with a smile!   There are so many options to chose from their menu when it comes to the toppings and special dishes. I personally do not order extra dishes just because their ramen fills me up so I had never tried any until today. My boyfriend ordered their Pork Belly Bowl and it tasted so savory with the right amount of salt and sesame oil. Perhaps, I'll order it for myself on my next visit.   My usual order is their Shoyu Ramen (the chicken broth) because it's simplicity at its best! I keep it original and add in chicken, corn, and butter. All together it tastes perfectly balanced. Their noodles are especially soft and I love how it's house-made!   I believe that Ramen Kobo was made by the same creator as Ramen Monta down at Spring Mountain. Both are similar in my opinion but Ramen Kobo offers more selections in toppings. The price of the ramen is just a couple of dollars extra than Monta. I love both ramen shops equally but bonus points for Ramen Kobo just because it's close to me!   Some do not like how small the restaurant is but I love it because in Japan that's how small ramen shops usually are. Overall, Ramen Kobo is delicious and I recommend it to anyone looking for a quick heartily meal. The service is typically fast and always friendly!

sFKuA76i_Q-aXpPxSm01OQ.text: I really love this ramen spot. The miso ramen and the tonkatsu ramen are my absolute favorite. Try it with black garlic oil !!!  I usually order my food Togo because it is small  Inside the restaurant and wait times can be long. Although for the times we do dine in the service is great and quick.   The spice levels are tricky. Some days mild is perfect and other days the mild would be a medium. I recommend to order the spice on the side so you can add to taste!

NhLHGzkiS1diBGiZpUTeYQ.text: So delicious. Food is fresh and fast. Service is excellent. I highly recommend this Ramen place if you want delicious food away from the strip or inner city.  You can literally see them making the noodles in the room next to the kitchen.

nHzLs-dIu4lsL-zvhzetAQ.text: Yummy tasting ramen spot down the street from my place! Their house made noodles keep me coming back!   I usually get the same thing, Spicy Tonkatsu Ramen w/ extra pork! If I'm feeling a bit hungrier than usual, I get some pan fried potstickers! Food comes out very quick, within minutes almost! I really enjoy how the pork melts in your mouth after letting it sit in the broth.   One of the cheaper ramen spots I've seen, that is very yummy at the same time, which is always a good thing! Waits can be quick or long depending on how many people are in front of you. It is fairly quick because usually most customers when they finish, they leave right away.   Docked a star because the actual restaurant itself as far as size could be bigger, I feel like I have to walk like a pancake in between the aisle of the bar and the tables due to being so crammed together. The tables are very close together so trying to have a conversation may not be too easy for your own ears, but nonetheless, the food will always be worth it to me.   Will definitely comeback!!

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy Tonkatsu Ramen w/ extra pork and slice of butter!

tdXsQ-wHqRwR2LsxXlLpqQ.text: All those years of living in the Seattle area and I never found a ramen place anywhere near this good. The noodles are fresh and the texture is perfect. The flavors and options are outstanding and the prices are decent. The service is fast and friendly and the restaurant is clean and comfortable. If you are obsessed with ramen or Asian soup in general, this should be on your go-to list. It doesn't hurt a bit that it's pretty near my home

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States

1GCMPxR_UdmPga19uP4N5Q.text: I'm a big fan of ramen, so when I saw this place made their own noodles in house, I had to go!  The place is small and was busy from the time we arrived to the time we left. The service was really good, but the check in made feel like I was at a Dr.'s Office. The window into the noodle making room was a nice touch.   The prices are reasonable ramen prices. What I really liked was the many add ins that were available. For example: I added black garlic oil to mine, while my brother added butter to his, and his girlfriend added corn. Another plus was the ability to select a heat level. I got medium, which was fine not too spicy, but I think the heat took away from the broth. If I went again I'd try the not spicy version. My crazy brother got the hottest they could make it and he really enjoyed it (*note: he goes out of his way to try the spiciest foods he can find. I could smell his from across the table and it knew I couldn't handle it.)  We also got the Gyoza and fried rice appetizers to share. I LOVED the steamed gyoza. Super delicious. The fried rice was also good. But the real star was the ramen. Their broth was well balanced and not too salty. The pork was cooked perfectly. I always felt like ramen could be heartier and they achieve that by doing sliced and ground pork. The smaller bits of ground pork would stick to the noodle and add these little hints of meaty goodness. Speaking of noodles, the noodles were perfect. Light and delicate, they fell apart in my mouth. It's like they were just tight enough to stand up to the broth.  I can't wait to go back!

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Medium spicy to tonkatsu ramen.
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Fried rice

xckLLhCXz4qybSem4DoWdw.text: My favorite ramen place! Thanks to my boyfriend for ordering something to go which is my new addiction! Spicy tonkatsu spice level hot! Be careful you might choke on broth lol it is so delicious! Thank goodness I work around here! I always add extra bamboo! Next time I'm going to double the bamboo!

3oTDRKRgF2d5VA37OtTHyQ.text: I personally like ramen kobo! Everything is just so simple. Not a huge selection of the menu but I always order my favorites. I get the vegetarian spicy on side with Nitamago, I always ask for vinegar and the sides of red ginger. I also love love love the mentaiko don.   Service is always consistent and fast.   The size of the restaurant is pretty small but hey I enjoy it.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Mentaiko don
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Veggie

f5mL5hLh6OL6_GPER6Golg.text: This was overall an OK ramen experience.   The place is tiny inside. Like extremely tiny. The tables are very crowded and close together. You won't have much room when it's crowded.   They have a decent menu of different ramen choices. Strangely, though, some of the traditional ramen inclusions like soft boiled eggs are an extra charge.   We tried the kimchi fried rice which was pretty good. Not too greasy and with a pleasant flavor. Slightly salty.   The ramen was overall decent with a flavorful broth and tender pork. The broth had an odd red color which might be related to the spices and seasonings they use.   Staff were friendly but seemed scripted with what seemed like memorized statements rather than genuine appreciation.   This was overall a decent ramen choice, but there are definitely better ramen choices in Vegas.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu ramen with egg
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kimchi fried rice
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States

Az1B4yIhxodxQ4Q_fMp1jQ.text: Definitely a surprise as far as flavor and price. Firstly, the place is pretty small like other ramen places, only a few tables and seats in the bar, so if you're a big party, expect a wait. Second, the menu has many options like the usual shoyu and miso but I like that there was a veggie option, so definitely vegan friendly. Their add ins are also pretty diverse so definitely a lot of options for anyone. They also have bao bun sandwiches which looked interesting but I was pretty full so I couldn't order it. I got the miso ramen with corn and soft boiled egg add ins, and the flavors were on point, well balanced and meaty and hearty. The server recommended to have the spice on the side so I can control how spicy I want it, which I thought was an amazing recommendation so it should the servers know their menu well. Definitely coming back here to try that bao bun and other things in the menu.

Jwq0nuE-Pc0JPXP7j08cKQ.text: Love the flavors! The food comes within 5 minutes. It's quite cheap since most of the sides are 1 dollar each. Definitely try this if you need a lunch spot!

xKmJSPotjllsHbv9N-fRAg.text: I come here OFTEN. Especially when I'm feeling under the weather and I'm looking for different choices of broth as well as something SPICY. I honestly haven't been disappointed when coming here. Rachel is so great honestly. She brings a life to this place.   Service is top notch. Food is fast and the cooks are awesome. Sitting at the bar it is nice to see them cook everything. It's a small place but it gives the japan feel. Honestly this place 10/10 always recommend.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Fire Shoyu Ramen with corn

_Of-p48tADgPeUHGj79IPA.text: Ramen kobo is not a bad option if you live in the southwest and do not want to go to China town. The restaurant is super small and they are also a popular location, so expect to wait to get a table. The service is fast and efficient so you can get in and out of this place.   The menu is very limited there are not a lot of options. The broth is good and had some flavor, but it was not extraordinary either. They allow you to pick from three different broths and add your spiciness level. One of my favorite things about ramen is the egg, but at kobo this is an add on. Overall, kobo ramen is not a bad option to fullfill your ramen craving.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States

RVWzWwKzkYes1V3BMLK74w.text: I live in southeast but I go here for my ramen fix. Ramen here is so good that I drive here even during the summer. (Who eats ramen in the Vegas summer? I do!!!)  Food: I always order Tonkutsu ramen (medium spice with 2x corn). It has the right amount of spice and creaminess, goes so well with the freshly made noodles. My wife gets the same ramen but with mild level of spice. Mild is still spicy, so if you don't like spicy food, you can get it with no spice.   Service: We always get great customer service here. They got friendly staff, and even if they're always busy, they never fail to check in on you and make sure everything is good. Service is quick too, so you get your order right away.   Tip: Try to go on off-peak hours. There can be a wait since the place is small (We go here for late lunch or early dinner).

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States

BTpSdEX4yD_QbzFK88RcWA.text: YES!! here is one of our favorite Ramen shop! Their Ramen is great, but Gyoza is okay because it is steamed Gyoza. All Staffs are so kind and friendly!!

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu ramen with black garlic oil! Yum!!
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kimuchi fried rice!
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu ramen with Black garlic oil:) Yum!

IEtlUhAGkAv-qPUQKnYRlg.text: I'd put this in the upper tier of ramen places in Vegas. I had the Tonkotsu, which had an appealing, fresh-tasting broth. The negative was that the chasu pork was basically tossed in at the end such that half of each piece was still cold. I rectified that but I'd have preferred if it came fully immersed. Service is your usual, fairly fast ramen experience. Prices are reasonable for what you get, and I brought home half of my dinner for a second meal. So, a good experience. Misc: You can see the preparation of the noodles while you're waiting to be seated. So, you know you're getting something fresh. That's good because you're probably going to have a wait, particularly if you are set on having a table.

IMTmo7wEgnho337Llv59VA.text: After a night of pumpkin patching in the cold weather we needed a ramen fix. We decided to try this place as it was close to where we were.   Ramen Kobo has very limited seating, a couple tables and bar seating. I wouldn't reccomend for large parties but for smaller parties yes. The wait time can be awhile. As you walk in they have on the right a window to watch the fresh noodles being made. Yummy!  The menu is limited and doesn't offer a lot but covers the basics of a ramen joint. I always like gyoza with my ramen but unfortunately this place doesn't have any. They do have fried rice, chashu bowl, pork belly bowl and some chashu buns also. The chashu and pork belly bowl come highly recommended but i have honestly had better elsewhere. The meat is more on the undercooked, rubbery side. I just prefer mines cooked more and more sauce. Not my favorite. Even the chashu in the ramen wasn't the greatest.  The staff are nice but seemed in such a rush to get orders in and orders out, as we were sat they asked if we were ready to order. I said no we just sat down and haven't looked at the menu yet. Ha!  This is not my favorite place and it was our first time as customers here but we probably won't be back. I have had better ramen and chashu elsewhere. The best thing here probably was the noodles being made fresh here but everything else was mediocre.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Original (spice level) no spice. Added extra bean sprouts $1.50 wasn&#39;t as extra as i wanted it. 2/5
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Hot (spice level)  Miso Ramen added in egg $1.50 &amp; nori $1.00. Spice level was okay. Could have been hotter.
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Fried Rice 4/5, Chashu Bowl 1/5 and side Kim Chee 3/5.

tVsJGTcrU3-6SosJNa0Umw.text: Best thing about Ramen Kobo is it's really close to home.  It is a small ramen joint nestled in a business plaza. I went in about 45 minutes before closing (first time here). Service was quick and efficient. A tad rushed toward the end, but I understand. Thankfully, we did not have to wait at all upon arriving.  The menu was very basic. 3 broth options with custom spice levels. There were also a several add-on options. I opted for the Tonkatsu Ramen with a spice level 1 and added nitamago (soft-boiled egg). Ramen Kobo is the first establishment that I have been to that does not include nitamago in the basic toppings. The tonkatsu broth was not overwhelming with flavor. I think adding a slight spice level made it a lot better. However, it was decent and overall still enjoyable.  The chashu buns were good. I wish the pieces of chashu were a little more abundant but the flavor was definitely there.  Ramen Kobo may not be my absolute favorite but for the convenience and closeness to home, I will definitely be back.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chashu buns

EQxa0WVq5TQRwZDPDpUOQg.text: Messed up my order so waited forever and on top of that sat people before me even though I was there first.  Seems like srevers dont have their own sections so pretty chaotic.  People just running around.  Im a big ramen fan, but for $8-$9 for basic ramen there is almost nothing in it.  I rather them charge me more and at least throw in an extra piece of lettuce or something. Everything you add is an extra dollar, even for some extra hot paste and scallions.  Although broth is not bad.  Seating is pretty cramped and hot as well.  Not a great experience.

ak-lsAO67PSq9r1Je74Ovw.text: Best ramen I've got ever! I usually went to 'monta' near china town which is the first ramen restaurant of the company, also known as 'Mon restaurant group' to enjoy my favorite shoyu ramen. It's another version of their ramen restaurant. Soup had very deep flavor, and the 'home made noodle' was very tasty. For this time, it seems like they are pursuing even high quality ramen. Much more outstanding than any other ramen store in town!

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu ramen with nori and ni-tamago.

ChJjXFEe5RH7o3t2M7BM1w.text: I just moved to the southwest side of town and have really been enjoying the food options over here. Okay, so I will probably be blasted for this, but I can't stand pho. Yeah, every time one of my friends hears this, they insist that I just haven't tried THEIR favorite spot. Ugh...five attempts later, I still don't like it. I was hesitant to try ramen, thinking it was just another name for pho. Besides, when I think of ramen, I think of the messy $.29 packets my kids love. However, I wasn't feeling good one day and decided I needed some soup. I looked at the menu, and it seemed like there was a chance I wouldn't hate it. Well, I found that not only do I not hate, but I actually LOVE it, and I love Ramen KoBo. I've tried the chicken and the pork and just prefer the chicken. I add egg to mine, and I love it spicy. I discovered this place a month ago, and I've been known to eat here twice a week or more. It is a small place and can get busy, so you might have to wait. However, it's really worth it! Also, they're open late, which works for me when I forget to eat dinner and suddenly find that it is after 9pm.

mxkWHeUNf-GHLIHzS30-LA.text: As a fan of Monta Chaya in Chinatown and Manta Ramen in Henderson, I was stoked when they announced another noodle house from the same company in the southwest. I'm happy to say they didn't disappoint! The layout is very similar to the other locations, though their menu is slightly different. the ramen was quite delicious and the noodles are made in house. I got the mild Tonkotsu ramen with extra noodles and a pork belly side bowl. All was wonderful! I'll be going back again very soon!

oa9PpMyYHfrexcBXAJ_Nxg.text: One of the best Ramen spots in Vegas!!! I got half pork and chicken broth with an extra egg. It was delicious. The fried rice was extremely flavorful. So worth checking this place out.

-VE7g6LxT38PfxiThsVXBA.text: straight to the point review been here maybe 4x already and was always happy upon leaving the restaurant.  **what i liked broth (very rich flavors)  noodles  portion size  charsiu pork (very tender!!!)  staff are wonderful  **what i did not like they only give you like 2 slices of charsiu pork on each order  very limited seats and place was too small  they charge a bit high for add-ons  no gyoza   ****ask for their roasted garlic condiment together with the pickled ginger

O9JoDCTN8FJMZAoT7LjHlA.text: Always hits the spot. Lucky to live so close by. Food is excellent, service is always fast and friendly.

oMdBIDQRij2VeiyzQNx74g.text: Great service!  Love the noodles made right in the shop.  Taste is delicious, and I will definitely be going back!

Q5UhUsJKbF3ecM375vYcgg.text: I'm giving them a 4 because it really is a nice place, but I'm not into spicy ramen.  So I won't be back.  That being said all the food was fresh and flavorful.  It was cool to see the broth/stock being simmered right in front of you.  Downside was my waitress was a bit flakey. When I sat down at first she asked what I wanted to drink.  In a unique restaurant I want to see if they have any unique drinks so I said I needed to take a look at the menu first.  She hovered around for an oddly long amount of time.  Then at the end I had to ask for my check twice.  And no, they weren't that busy.

0Eo1WNQEBwLkDgBjL_iVSA.text: Pretty good ramen.  I wish I left my order all original to give it a more equal comparison to other Vegas ramen. Instead I got too excited and ordered the tonkatsu with black garlic oil and spice level hot. This ramen joint is about the spice level so be a bit adventurous with your spice level. It isn't as spicy as I thought it would be but I have been told that my level of spicy is pretty much lava. Next time I will get spice level fire. Mind this, you can ask for chili on the side if you want to be cautious. The chili they use has a good kick that hits you in the back of the throat but it does go away fairly quickly. It's not smokey the way some dried chili oils are. Kobo's chili is a ground dried chili with oil rather than an oil with dried chili bits in it. This allows the chili oil to not overpower or sit on top of the broth. Normally the oil will add extra fat/heaviness to the already rich tonkatsu broth but it doesn't. I would recommend people to add on extra chashu. You only get one slice in the regular order but the extra comes with 4 slices. The noodles are a little thicker since they are homemade. It's good and you can taste the freshness BUT I am a thin ramen noodle kind of girl.  Let's compare Kobo to two other ramen places: Moko and Monta. Kobo is definitely way better than Moko. It's plain and simple that Kobo's flavor is just taste better. I have tried Moko on many occasions and it's not bad. Kobo's broth surpasses Moko's broth. Now compared to Monta, Kobo is just a step behind. Yes Kobo is the product of Monta, but the only reason for my opinion is the noodles. Like I said before, I am a thin noodle person. I prefer the snap of the thin noodles rather than the softer homemade noodles. Both broths are fantastic. The chashu is fantastic. Service is great. Just because I prefer Monta's noodles does not mean I hate Kobo. This was my first visit but not the last. Definitely my new ramen place.   Added note: the parking is soooooooooooo much better than Monta's parking lot. I have changed dinner plans before when Monta didn't have any parking in the parking lot or side streets.

iILRh-1BGNQX8yMutDqT3A.text: I recently discovered this place which is only 3 minutes away from me. Their pictures looks great, actual food not so much. Especially spicy level HOT is nothing but super greasy. My favorite ramen places are near China town, so I don't like driving there all the time. I ate at this place for 4 times. The last time I ate there, I could sense they aren't happy with me most probably because I only tip around 18% up to over 20%. If you guys eat at Japanese restaurants, you'll know they are very welcoming, and everyone greets when customers are leaving, unless it's not an open kitchen. In this case, they have open kitchen. They greet people leaving the restaurant. I was not greeted at all last time, when I was walking out, two people was at the counter, only a waiter behind me greeted me. I went there earlier tonight, I already walked up near the kitchen where all the tables are at, they aren't busy, restaurant was more than half vacant. No one greeted me and the chefs were all standing there watching me, one fat guy looked pissed off at me the entire time, one lady was emotionless, one guy kind of smiled a little bit when I did. I've been standing there like an idiot, looking back and forth at these guys made me felt very uncomfortable, especially the fat guy, like dude, seriously?! That's how a 7 years old girl would act like if you get her mad. It was too uncomfortable for the way they were judging me, so I left. On the check, it lists how much to tip for 15%, 18%, and 20%. If you give the option to tipping, and I have been tipping within the tipping range, why have to be an jerk? I never tipped under 15%, even if I have, it is an acceptable tip. I like to leave changes so my bill adds up to full dollar. Looks like to me, the servers gossips to everyone there. Most of the Japanese people I met or seen are extremely polite, however all the chefs at ramen kobo are not Japanese, not all servers are Japanese either. I've never had this kind of uncomfortable experience in my life. I wonder if any customers have watched their reactions, WOW.... I would feel embarrassed for them. All the other Japanese restaurants I go to, the service are always consistent and super friendly. I was surprised with these people. I will never ever go there again. BTW, one of their server's breath is so disgusting! When he's standing next to me, I could smell his breath! I read a three star review few comments below me, looks like this place's really got real shitty people, they are extremely rude. It's very uncommon in Japanese restaurants, it's jaw dropping for me. Very shitty place, most likely cheaper labor. What's your most expensive item? $10? LOL ramen kobo, you guys win on every level.

Keomzc5lKwghdsnKtHvCUg.text: great ramen...good staff (efficient)..only issue is figuring when to go to minimize the wait time..

rbz8PaGuTr1RvGClkn24hw.text: Nothing that I could possibly complain about this place. Love how there's a ramen place outside of spring mountain and on the southwest side of town. Super clean place. Way bigger than monta which is great. Love how there's a section where u can see them make fresh noodles. I was skeptical about the broth and taste since I would compare it to monta which is by far the best ramen in town, but actually, ramen kobo is almost at their level. Broth was good. The spicy hot broth was super good, if u like spicy. We order the tonkotsu with nori and egg like usual. We also order the pork belly bowl to share and I was also skeptical because at monta, their pork belly bowl looks different and is super bomb but kobos bowl was good too. I think it needs a little more flavor or sauce to mix with the rice though to make it . Other than that, they were able to accommodate 7 of us and the wait wasn't bad at all unlike monta where u gotta wait for a while for a big group like that.

nL3Onj6iTvGTDYCfU8CtlQ.text: I've been to a handful of ramen restaurants within the past 2 months & this place by far have been my favorite.  You can taste the difference in their noodles (probably because they make it themselves at the restaurant).  I also really like their fried rice.  I don't like spicy food but their kimchee fried rice I can handle.  It's not too spicy but still has enough kick for my hubby to enjoy also.

62Atlu2wXvCVIchNcdej8Q.text: Really good food. Fried rice and miso ramen 10/10. Only negative soda is caned so refills were not free.

bYX8A_jt2MdRmddTnL_r3g.text: One of the best ramen houses in town. In my opinion the best in the monta chain of restaurants. I frequently go to several excellent ramen places in town but kobo sets itself apart with there house made noodles and various levels of heat. Not the only ramen place I go to but one of the best.

5gNfxAugxVu7a3lccMHbCw.text: Everything was good but the noodles, they used a thick ramen noodles. Monta's noodle was better. Fried rice was great. Staff were friendly. We liked it because its about 5 min from our house. Convenient for us but if it's not something we want to keep going back to. Id drive the extra miles to go back to Monta

5Aaf4CJZKBW-4RCmBXl9hA.text: It was okay.. Def not monta.Monta is wayyyy better, We got it Togo they didn't give us 2 kimchi like I ordered & we got charged for a extra shoyu ramen that no one ate. The kimchi fried rice was okay but nothing like montas. Won't be eating here again I'd much rather drive across town to monta.

5UQHQkMy1PohJkim_3QeGw.text: Good location and the food was very good.  The broth was a bit salty but tasty.  Pricing is reasonable and large party sitting may be a problem.  Service could be better to make one feels welcome.

Dp7YI3DmX1K0IHlR4CPwgg.text: If you love Monta, you will love this one too!! Even better because they can make the soup as hot/spicy as you want. The friend rice is exactly the same. Delicious !! The location is great, right by 215 and Durango. The place is way nicer than Monta.

IRmQrs0fFd9wlFzuRF3tpg.text: Excellent traditional Japanese Ramen shop.  Had the Spicy Tonkatsu Ramen with fried rice.  The place is small, only    a few tables inside and the line can get quite long because of it. Try going at off hours and go in small 1-2 person parties to get a table faster.

18bCwEWuNjvC_Fi27YwsoA.text: Awesome little place! Great ramen if you don't wanna hull all the way over to spring mountain.

Xw3jKlTUQT4EtA30u8QZQQ.text: I had "real" ramen for the first time here and I'm glad I made the choice to come here! More recently, I came here for the second time. I actually came with one of my friends both times, who is actually a regular. He said that he came to this place so often, that one of the waitresses remember his order. I ordered the pork and chicken ramen (I don't remember the proper name) both times and I loved it equally both times. The ramen here is made fresh daily so there's definitely a difference compared to packet ramen (duh). I also love how this location is so close to home compared to the other ramen places in Las Vegas. The only factor I don't like about this place is how crowded and cramped it is, but that's not something they can really change. The food is definitely worth it, though! This place will always be my first option when it comes to ramen.

YltSs1XKCLPW8s4-xhqu-g.text: I am here waiting in line. I was here promptly at 5:00pm and placed my to go order via ipad at the restaurant. It took them 45 minutes to get me my food! Find another place to eat if you are actually hungry.

XPdXhn0UzITVafl8Lgsscw.text: I got the Vege Ramen and added chashu chicken, butter, 2 eggs and Nori. The broth was delicious. Everything was delicious actually. d9ig3BisOX9Io0g00I_WCA.text: Great place.  I eat here once a week.  Pork belly over rice is great.  Takes a while to get a table but service is fast

1G1uCcOXuFlWkNTlJA5gWQ.text: Not terrible.  Not great.  Just a big eh it was okay.  If you're nearby and bored it's fine.  Otherwise if you want an experience or good eat, you tend to critique a lot of the way things are done and made here more towards the negative side.  Go elsewhere for ramen.

v3KoMRqNzmDSP3oQ-ob-MA.text: This is hands down my favorite Ramen spot in the city. I adore their spicy tonkotsu and, although it's additional, I like that they have fresh spinach on the menu. My companion ordered the chicken ramen was just as impressed. They are, however, closed between the lunch and dinner hours so be aware prior to your arrival, call ahead if you're unsure.

j0QprAXeYbp3_siOrU7cOg.text: This place is outstanding, I eat their Vegan ramen at least once a week! They make their noodles fresh and you can taste the love in every single bite! You can say I'm obsessed but try it out and you'll see why. On a side note I was completely against ramen before this place so yea it's THAT GOOD! Also everyone that works there is super awesome and they're open late!! The place is small but that kinda makes it more special plus it's just as good Togo!  I'm writing this review to kill time before they open...

WnjaDspXYJGtWYvNar9eUQ.text: Went with some friends the last time I was in town. It is small and it is busy, but when you've got a good product it happens. I really enjoyed my spicy miso ramen and would definitely come back again. Solid ramen spot, especially for its location.

9s4ScyTeQqU1RgiYB5U1rA.text: This place just opened up close to me and it is now my new favorite ramen place in town! After my first time here, I was back the very next day.  It was that good.  The broth is very flavorful and the chashu meat is tender.  We always order the pork belly fried rice as an appetizer.  Definitely recommend it!  I only wish there were more seating as there is usually a wait with the limited seating.

U7l0cM-3rzZaMmWtxTuz7A.text: The Miso Ramen (fire hot) was kickin and delicious. The fried rice is very flavorful. The staff is very friendly and attentive. I wish I lived in town so I could eat here more often.

pQlDC1nmLGua5Ip_NnfEgQ.text: Absolutely great experience and will come back my times! The ramen was amazing. My two boys, a one year old and 12 year old loved it. We tried the Miso broth and it was great. The fried rice was so good we ordered another one to take home. The service was great (Thank you Neil!) And we didn't wait long. I'll be back with my parents and in-laws soon.

8HlxIPaGXHacFRIPuK8f3g.text: Dropped by randomly with my girlfriend checking out how this place compares to all the other ramen spots in Vegas. This place is located on Durango and warm springs infront of EOS, which is convenient because it is close to a big residential area. The shop is pretty small and I would assume on a busy night during the weekend there might be a wait. I came here pretty late on a week day, so I was seated immediately. I couldn't remember the server's name, but she was friendly and made sure we were okay throughout the entire experience. I ordered the Spicy shoyu ramen and my girlfriend got the tonkatsu ramen. The Spicy ramen had a nice kick to it and would surely get your nose running! The soup was good and I liked how the noodles were chewy. I got to try the tonkatsu ramen as well and I liked the soup base. It was thicker than the soup you get at sora, but it definitely had good flavor. Portions were good and we both left full! If you're in the area definitely try this place out.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy shoyu ramen

jXDcrfbqytm3TdrbkKHR2w.text: My wife and daughter came here on a Tuesday night.  My two year old daughter was asleep in her stroller but the staff was very accommodating by making space so we had a place to sit.  My wife had the chicken and broth bowl and she really enjoyed it.  Only thing she would do differently is order an extra pork and add an egg.  I had the pork broth super spicy and it was delicious!  I would probably add an egg as well next time.  We also shared the pork belly bowl which we highly recommend!!  Something simple yet so tasty!  Haven't really came across a bad ramen place but we'll be back for sure as it is so close to our house.

CqgFPLhbYK_j27uD9pfN6g.text: First time there today. I've been waiting for a "perfect" weather to pair with ramen so I waited for our long summer to be over. First impression was nice, clean and modern as this is a new joint but the smell was off. The smell was overwhelmingly stale and oily. My culinary "red-flag" went up right away from that point. Lunch was fairly busy but luckily we sat at the bar right away. Before I sat tho, I went to the bathroom to wash my hands. Both men and women bathroom had signs that said the bathroom is closed for some work or something. WHAT?! This is a brand new place practically. But I saw that the women's bathroom was open and no one was nearby so I quickly washed my hands (of course, with door opened with my foot propping it open. Didn't want to "scare" any female patrons there you know!) Anyway, the hallway floor was sticky which is a good sign that they don't have a good sanitary protocols. C'mon, they just opened the door like 30 mins before we were there. It shouldn't be that way. As I sat at the bar, the dirty hoods caught my eyes. Once again, this place being as new as it is, the hoods shouldn't be that dirty with oil and filth. Another sign...lack of proper sanitation and maintenance protocols.   Next thing I noticed are the workers in the kitchen making the food doesn't seem to have much culinary training.I'm accustomed to and expect to see people behind the kitchen who knows about the food and have appreciation for the food they are making. I highly doubt any of the workers have any prior training in making ramen before they start working there. Their lack of professionalism and respect for the food they are making truly showed with the body language and filthy stuffs they were saying. Especially the heavy set guy was pretty vocal and non-stop talking fairly loud while making the noodle, I so wish he stopped talking to minimize spitting into the food. For that reason alone, I would not return to this place again since I felt the food isn't being made with proper sanitary standard.   Our ramen took little longer than expected but not too bad. I ordered a medium miso and I thought it was quite spicy. My staffs agreed as one ordered hot (she normally order 8-9/10 at Thai restaurants) and the other ordered a medium miso too. Taste wise, I'd give 3 stars. The noodle, which they boast about making in-house with their own machine is nothing more than a show. Can we say Krispy Kreme??? It really didn't deliver anything extra. Portion is on the smaller size so I ordered a side of white rice. Sorry I ordered "white" rice, not stale "yellow" rice. Another let down!  The waitress was poorly trained or just don't know how to serve properly. I'd accept "unfriendly" but this older lady was on the "rude" side!   Ramen is something I appreciate quite a bit. While being a rather simple dish, it's one of those things that's not only filling but emotionally "hitting the spot" type of food. Kobo is a prime example where a business person with no culinary training and no culinary appreciation for the food they deliver turns it into a "factory" to make money, not food! Their name is quite fitting...a FACTORY! Simply a place where they make things. No thanks kobo, I'll look for a place where they take pride in food they make, not just the $$$ they make!

fE1g5xdPJdaEeDuYDPvbCw.text: Have been here a few times, and I have to say it's just good. There are better options, in my opinion, like Ramen Sora, but it's really close to home when I don't feel like driving to Chinatown.  It's a little disappointing that they don't have gyoza as an option. I ate the tonkotsu ramen medium spicy. The first time I went it was almost too spicy to finish, but the other times was just enough spice. The broth has good flavor, not too light, but almost creamy. You have to add things that come already at other places, like the egg, and it only comes with one small piece of chashu pork. The noodles are made in house, and they are probably the best thing about this place. I don't recommend taking it Togo though, it doesn't hold up as well as you'd think.  Also, on the weekdays, they have a weird break in their hours where they are closed from 2:30-5.

BVagodMPRacG8Qnl-GLg-A.text: First let me say how glad I am that a ramen joint opened up on this side of town, we've been sorely needing one! From the sound of it, this is owned by the same people as Monta and that's definitely a good thing.  Anyway, the service was great and everyone was very friendly. The menu, while small, is still good as they at least offer fried rice in place of more traditional appetizers. Usually ramen fills me up so I don't always go for appetizers anyway so its not a big deal to me. That said, I think it would be greatly appreciated if they expanded their menu a bit. Not going to knock it for lack of gyoza.  The food was great! I got the shoyu ramen as I like lighter ramen in the summer months and it really hits the spot. Very similar to Monta's style of ramen. And you can even see the noodle machine working. Freshly made noodles are always a good sign.  Not sure why so many people are complaining about the size of this place, its an average sized ramen shop, why would you bring a large party? All the decent shops in Chinatown are similar size as well.  I'm a fan and I'll definitely be coming back!

EmczelLOM634HJzC6hF8Gg.text: In case you were wondering, MILD isn't supposed to mean burn your mouth completely off, flaming hot. But here that's exactly what it means. If you normally order anything under a spice level 3-4, DO NOT get the mild spice level. Ruined my meal, couldn't eat it :(

sXraKzpAZs6a8nj4wjiPtw.text: Cleaness 5/3 , food wisely idk yet mine still on the way but i wonder what kind ramen without boil egg , $1.50 extra for egg ( over price to me ) and from my place i sit i can see man restroom open the door straight i can see ... Uugh !! Guess ... I ll be back to sora again . Staff is "pretty" nice so far ....   This is my opinion i might be wrong but u guys can try your self .  Update : food wisely 5/4  fried rice lil bit dry , miso ramen not bad at all . Staff still nice

kkE6HxA42Um4XkOyZnOUBg.text: I love this place! The broth has so many dimensions and a very deep flavor. The noodles are perfect. I love the pickled ginger available to add to your ramen or that comes standard on the fabulous fried rice. The menu is simple and all items are fresh. My only complaints are that the establishment is tiny. Either get there when they open or be prepared for a wait. And also that they close for a few hours mid-day. I understand that they must make more noodles, but twice I've neglected to look at the time and shown up while they were closed.

DqYsNhlU4OkCM_zapAqNxA.text: This place only sits near 20 so there will always be a wait! But trust me when I say that the wait is worth it. My wife and I got fried rice to share then we each got a raman bowl. Everything was well worth it. We will be back, and we will recommend this place to others!

0P59W5UzBL5dr-PUG3UOiA.text: This is the only ramen place I've been to and after eating there it will probably remain the only place I go. I absolutely love this place and go at least once a week! The shoyu hot with one egg is delicious and my usual. When I was on a vegan kick I ordered the vege ramen hot no ginger with bamboo shoots and bean sprouts and it was also delicious but very different flavor and much lighter than the shoyu. Small place but fast service and worth the wait if there ever is one. Very convenient for calling in an order to go or placing one on the iPad up front. Will be picking some up tonight!

pvwIdvovePKHPz4HGnrDUQ.text: Foods great. It didn't meet my customer service expectations. The old waitress is just rude. But is nice to others. I was just keeping quiet. Said you're welcome to other people but when I said thank you she didn't say anything and just gave a fake grin. She was smiley to my boyfriend though. But not me.

3Ru7xbBGBCfSxk0hsjRzMw.text: I have been a avid ramen-consumer around town and I love the old Monta (before the taste starting to change in recent years) and knew I had to try this place out.   The menu is pretty similar to Monta except for optional levels of spiciness, 1 piece of pork Chasu instead of 2 but we get ground pork as the other protein instead, comes with bean sprouts, and a higher price tag.   I went there the second day it opened and ordered my go-to ramen, the Tonkatsu Ramen, original level of spiciness, and I added an egg with an additional charge. The ramen turned out bland so I was disappointed and the egg was just like a tasteless hard-boiled egg. The soup base had pieces of the Tonkatsu oil-like ingredients floating around --- it looked it they did not boiled the broth enough for the ingredients to blend in.   However, I gave this place another try the week after. I ordered a Shoyu Ramen with no options added as well as the Kimchi Fried Rice. The Kimchi Fried Rice is just as good as the one in Monta and the Shoyo Ramen was delicious! I don't know if it's because they heard feedback from customers about the broth being too bland and fixed it or it's simply because it's a different ramen but it was very well done.   This is not the end of the review --- the third week, I did try the Miso Ramen and thought it didn't taste bland but it wasn't groundbreaking neither. I would go to this place just for the Shoyo Ramen and the fried rice.

cBNicg72tVFBXI01g262sg.text: I love the ramen and fried rice here!  So yummy!  Best ramen in Spring Valley, maybe in all of Las Vegas.  The noodles are made in house!  After discovering this place we came back the next day for take out.

XKYKJztpax6q4PQoaLtYAw.text: I had a tonkatsu for lunch is good...service is great...I need to try the other item on the menu....hungry for more

Zsule50Nc09ldLaMX3aDMA.text: The ramen was really tasty. I thought the broth had a lot of flavor and the noodles were perfect. The restaurant is very small, they only have 4 tables that seat 4 and a bar that seats 8 or 10. The service was great, even at the bar the waitresses tend you to you which was very nice. The menu is small as well, offering 4 flavors of ramen, and a few different side dishes like, pork belly and kimchi. Overall it was a good experience.

Pij1Scx-qJkHKKNCrW7Tdg.text: Had the Shoyu ramen with Nitamago! The ramen here is amazing and tasted great. All noodles are made in house and it's the perfect amount of food to satisfy you! They add ground beef and roasted garlic in the broth which makes it taste just that much better than local competitors! A bunch of my friends are coming into town this Friday for EDC and it looks like we found a great lunch and dinner spot to hit up! Thanks Kobo!

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu Ramen with Nitamago! Super good!!

z88LKr5N4lv3KmbgCzzpaQ.text: The food is the bomb.com, service was good they are very friendly, for sure going back to this place again.

Dl7rSWIhkgvnBWj1NhHUqw.text: This is my favorite ramen joint hands down. I freaking love this place. They make their noodles, their spice level does not let me down, and their service is amazing. I come at least once a week and it's such a nice meal to have. I always get the shoyu medium ramen and a fried rice cause their fried rice is bomb. I'm always bringing a different friend so they can experience the ramen goodness as well. If you're reading this, I'm probably there right now.

xWfjHHKam_XS2kvOkaQeLQ.text: One of my top two Ramen places. Great noodles and broth. My kids love their fried rice. A must go to if you are in LV.

r6A9jQu0Av8wdo5i5tA6pg.text: Best ramen in town  and so convenient for southwest area I love it and very fast serving

F7ookSeHXdpPOStqoph0OA.text: I love this ramen place! I got the medium spice level cause I NEVER get mild anything, but it ended up being a little too spicy for me. Still good though. Next time I came I got mild and it was prefect! Still a good amount of spice!

4fEyBPtqJh-_Z-1ZjuJVvA.text: This is definitely the best ramen I've tried in town. I have to limit myself or I would probably end up eating here multiple times a week. There isn't very much room for seating, but I've never had to wait longer than ten minutes. The broth here is perfect, the chashu pork is so tender, and it has become my ultimate comfort food. Staff is super friendly, always greets you when you walk in and thanks you when you leave. I love love love this place so much and can't say enough good things about it!

qooDYbW9sAStzKULpPGjiQ.text: This review is primarily based on the inconsistency in the food. I consider myself a regular here. They just added something new to the menu called tsukemen. I've ordered this dish about 3-4 times now and let me tell you it was nothing short of amazing. I enjoyed it so much that I even had to get one to go to eat later. Keep in mind this was made by what I think is the owner? I ordered my regular today and I didn't recognize any of the staff. I regret coming here today. It was absolutely terrible. The first taste of the sauce reminded me of spicy charcoal. Complete garbage. I am not hard to please when it comes to food but the dish was so horrendous that I had to stop eating it. I told the server how bad the dish was and all he said was "oh.. sorry.." with a smile and walked away. I hate to say it but just based off of this experience, I may not come back here.

Ik-I_WtVm4coEchXIIeCcg.text: Stopped in with my party of 4- me, my mother, my teenage son, my two year old and my baby. We were told it was a 20 min wait. The girl assumed we needed a high chair, which we didn't. Our wait time was based on my party needing a high chair. There was an open table when we got there so our 20 minute wait time was for nothing. My two year old doesn't eat ramen, so I brought him some macaroni, which the restaurant doesn't allow. I wasn't going to sit there and eat while my two year old watched us. I understand not being able to bring outside food in to their restaurant, but we were getting 5 meals plus drinks. You'd think they could make an exception for a two year old. Either way, we left and took our business elsewhere. The 2 stars were for the 20 minutes of my time that was completely wasted.

dJ-Iyogiv0euoEg3E1HhuQ.text: I am so happy a ramen placed open close to my house, and that it is from the Monta name we know and love. Kobo is different from Monta on Spring Mountain or  Eastern. This location has you choose your level of spiciness from original, to fire. It does not have the option to choose thin or thick noodles like the Spring Mountain location which is fine. They add ground beef, green onion, and a clove of garlic in their soups which the other locations do not do, I think it is a nice touch. The only reason I did not give 5 stars is due to the broth, it doesn't have as much flavor as their other locations, and there is fatty grease floating in it like the other reviewer said. I went twice since they opened first time I got the Miso ramen original, and the second time I got the Shoyu ramen mild. The shoyu ramen had a little more flavor then the miso and I think it was due to the spicy flavoring they use. I will be back and be a frequent customer. Server Ryan was very nice and introduced himself and was very welcoming, great service.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso ramen original added double egg.

omZ-ztE94ANLN1ZRzbUFnQ.text: Great food, great service, and the pork rice is bomb! The bouncy fresh noodles be popping and locking in my mouth. The spicy level is a bit intense, and I wish there were more appetizers. But I think starting with a simple menu is the way to go!

6ECpaVDl1hCJQNTAuottgA.text: My wife and I enjoy this place very much. Good service, the food is excellent and the atmosphere is nice. Some complain that the restaurant is small, but most likely their the type to spend a dinner checking their phones instead of enjoying the company they have with them.

P9-qj8plaWB5NJ9zmOd4Ug.text: Excellent tonkotsu ramen with lots of fresh, chewy noodles, ground pork, and other components that add flavor and texture.  Fried rice also a favorite!  Great flavor and texture compared to "Chinese" fried rice.  I will be back.

UrOzJRWkzjM0tLjKRVjZWg.text: Service was great, food was great, bathrooms were super clean. The waitress Angel was super nice! The whole staff is very welcoming actually. 5/5, there is a bit of a wait sometimes but that's only because the Ramen/anything in the menu IS DELICIOUS  P.S. TAIWON IS THE BEST & DESERVES SO MUCH APPRECIATION !

yrm4zJB0y4dTOJnOGypDFQ.text: I'm thrilled that all these new restaurants are opening nearby.  We ventured into this local place and thought the place was nicely decorated.  A little small but nice.   I tried the shoyu ramen.   I thought the flavor was good but they were a little light with the protein.   You have to get the extra  Protein topping for $2.50.   We've have been to a lot of ramen houses and this one was ok.

7RJrsLIRxgnlt6aohWGM9Q.text: I've been here twice and I love the food. The taste of the broths are amazing and the noodles fresh. Love it with the spicy flavor and adding the pork. I also can't get enough of their pork fried rice very flavorful. The place is very small so if it's busy you will have a bit of a wait. I have also ordered food to go and that was done super fast. Definitely a must try.

OfXG_oX0B6Zx_nkDnD7PwQ.text: Food is above average.  What I do not understand is why they can't substitute pork for chicken without charging you???  I feel like I am being double charged every time.  They need to correct this or have a signature bowl already with chicken.  I will be back when they change this....

krFk8Atjppa1LFqaJ2IM6A.text: Nice to have a ramen location at the southwest so you don't have to drive to Chinatown area.

dupc_9KoStlcyw-yyxJHMw.text: I normally like thin noodle.  Noodle at Ramen Kobo is not thin, it means not my favorite, BUT it was so yummy and I loved it!  I tried Tonkotsu Ramen and the broth was so creamy and thick. You should add egg, it's super good.

ruZwljQZ-O27_0f5vdFrpw.text: Great food and service.  Noodles made fresh in front of you.  Their mild is spicy so watch out.  It's really good but has a kick.  Hard to find seating so come early or wait.  Definitely build more of those in summerlin .  Lol

i02eDO_pmiDy1m4iRlAd0w.text: Best ramen in town. I think they are even better than monta ramen! Their pork belly bowl is to die for and also nice touch to have the spicy level. Customer service was great as well! Our server taiwon was very nice and professional! Keep up the great work guys!!! Will be back for sure

zWbM-_Nbzl-TbevZL36cXw.text: Broth needs to be strained one, it's too oily esp with the ground meat they add as a topping (on that, I'd rather rave 2 pieces of chashu than this ground meat that disappears into the broth).  Also the broth needs more salt; very under seasoned once the noodles are in. They should eat monta's and theirs side by side and do some tweaking.  Like mine was the miso one and it still lacked salt. My noodle texture was good, like the thick noodles at monta. Hope this place works out because it's so close to my house.

cdT5aHwk4u8gTqoosU-pfw.text: came in on opening day and had high expectations that were met.  I'm a big fan of the other restaurants associated with Ramen KoBo and they were met.  Loved the kim chi fried rice and the spiciness of the soup

tb6yl0T2CswvcV6tT9yDKA.text: Great Ramen made fresh every day! We go here weekly and we love everything, healthy, broth is flavorful and perfect spice level. Friendly and great take out orders too!

ABDzzFsOjXSS1ix7BicATw.text: Definitely some of the best ramen I've ever had! They are True to their heat scale, unlike a lot of Asian cuisine I've had, I ordered hot for the ramen and wow it is very hot! Lol definitely will go with the medium next time but again great ramen!! Wasn't greeted right away at the door but that's ok the food was great! Come try it out!

jT5j86byJK5UcHncayWyOw.text: Excellent quick efficient service with really good food and spicy ramen and  vegetarian ramen options. The kimchi was delicious, their beer was nice and cold.

6p2MTOZvYtKPjrU08weMhQ.text: We were excited to try a new place for ramen and it's closer to home. It's very small and crowded but we only waited a few minutes for a table. The service was average, not over attentive but my glass of water wasn't ever empty. The food was also average, the only thing different than some of the other places was the ability to pick the spicy level. The biggest issue I had and the reason that I will more than likely NOT go back there was the noise level. It's like they lined the walls with something to amplify the noise.  I'm fine with normal busy restaurant noise bit this was enough that I was ready to leave before the food came.

L1kStdIrkQKgQqILsFO-Zg.text: I had the miso ramen and it was great.  I will add this to my favorites in Vegas to visit.  The service is fast and the food is very fresh.

aNiDS4CW-GQ23kycj847iA.text: I love this place. The ramen is so delicious. Fast and super friendly service. Definitely my place to go to for ramen.

Op7RieVryPByLDSowH-BAg.text: Love the fresh handmade noodles! Quality is always best, never had something tasted that wasnt before. Theyre pretty consistent with their recipe. Place was pretty small, could be busy at times but worth the wait!  Normally i get the tonkotsu w/ garlic oil! Broth is rich and perfect with the garlic oil! Chasu isnt your typical kind in where its 80% of it was fat. This one has more meat than fat, which i prefer. Give it a try i bet you'll like it!

97GII43ibaU75EotiiEfyg.text: Tonight we decided to try ramen kobo we walked right and was promptly seated. We sat at the bar which isn't too  bad. I order the tonkotsu ramen and my fiance got the Sho yu ramen. We shared a pork belly rice bowl also. If you never had their ramen spicy order it plain. It was good but kind spicy for me. The portions were good and the taste was there but the chili kinda too spicy for me but I still ate it. I will be  back again.

AExjKJxQBHUrNi8mevPMXA.text: This reviews coming from a person who isn't a ramen connoisseur but one whom enjoys it. For $8.95 + $1.00 egg add on, I ordered the hot spicy miso ramen. Pretty pricy for just adding on type of topping. It came with chives & pork chashu already. There was barely any meat, but I personally like the broth. I can see why people think it's oily. It had some flavor, hence me sipping it out of my spoon more than chowing down the noodles. The in house noodles had a nice soft & perfectly cooked texture. Service was decent & the tight atmosphere made it all the more Japan-like feeling. Might be back!

juXvbNO_xs4h6Rqy-_yJtQ.text: Don't let the small place stop you from dining here, the flavors in the broth are amazing, the noodles are made in house! It gets busy like any other good spot but it's worth the wait!

VePAZXFrPnirdqBGDsbR0A.text: SERIOUSLY OBSESSED  . **2017 Yelp 100 Challenge LV # 9** . This place is TINY but when I see tiny it means it's a smart business plan since they are using the space to the fullest. The place is simply decorated which is good when it's small. They can maybe fit about 25 people MAX!!  . The service is always fast & quick. This place is probably not like the most romantic place, more of like a quick meal & out. . -PORK BELLY BOWL $5.95 - it's simple & plain & I love it. Thin slices of PORK just cooked & topped onto a bowl of rice w/ salt & pepper & sesame oil. Topped off w/ scallions   -SHOYU SPICY RAMEN $8.95 - there has to be a bunch of MSG in this soup base because I freaken can't stop craving the damn soup! I'm not much of a ramen person since I prefer to just make ramen at home for convenience but the soup here I just love.  -MINI MENTAIKO BOWL $3.95 - I love MENTAIKO w/ some warm rice & a whole bunch of scallions w/ thinly sliced nor I. There's also some sesame oil on the side for you to add for yourself.  -KIMCHI FRIED RICE $3.95 - I would say this is like most mild kimchi fried rice I have had yet. . All in all I love the soup & the mini bowls... nothing super exciting but it's convenient for a quick bite when you just want something simple. Plus I work close by.

ISegJW30rlieMDhHj9a1ZQ.text: The service was very unattentive here. The restaurant isn't very big and you're very close to people, but a lot of ramen places are like that. You can see them making the noodles themselves, which is something I've always liked.   My boyfriend got the kimchi fried rice and it didn't really taste like kimchi. He asked for a side of kimchi and although it would have cost extra he decided to get it, but it never came.  I opted for the tonkotsu ramen. The broth was pretty good. It had a good consistency. With all the other ramen places, I'd probably just opt for one with some better service.

lctZSGAOFI5wDvm3UDuD5Q.text: Cute little ramen spot in the busy growing Durango areas. I've been here more than a handful of times. Some visits are more busy than the others. I like how their ramen "already comes with stuff" as in ground beef, bean sprouts, etc. That black garlic oil makes everything taste better!!! Also, their pork belly bowl is to die for! Try it and thank me later.

tHQsEUDYfOfBj4ZkdEBLbQ.text: Chachu bowl and Tonkatsu ramen combination = happy tummy! Inalways see to it that I eat ramen kobo at least once a week! I don't know what ingredient are you using but I always crave for more!

nYTFMpEjYq4GVUraM5julA.text: My friend recommended this place to me saying their ramen was amazing, it certainly is. I had the chicken broth ramen with the fried rice, my husband had the pork one and both were delicious. The setting is warm and cozy, not very big. The service could have been a bit more attentive but then again we went on a busy night. I didn't finish the whole plate, it's pretty big portioned, so I took it to go. Will definitely be visiting again!

i_rSRpp_xdSj-zEdHZ0VdQ.text: Well the first thing that greets you when you walk in, besides the wait stools built for the Oompa Loompas, is the lady in the enclosed glass area making fresh ramen. This is a very authentic Japanese ramen place where the servers are Japanese and the cooks are Mexican. Of course.   But the ramen is very good. Service is prompt and the food comes out fast. So you are pretty much done before they can wish you thank you and don't let the door hit your arse on the way out, because you will always have to wait a good 15-30 min when you come eat. That's how busy they are!

Kgx46xebTdTX65xCGo09KA.text: The best ramen joint in the southwest area, probably one of the top places in the valley. I order the same thing every time I go there because I love it so much I can't give it up to try something new. Husband says it's legit Japanese style and he lived in Japan for a few years. There's usually a wait for a seat, the place is small and you will probably be bumping it elbows with the person next to you as you inhale your noodles but it's worth it. Just do it! I recommend the tonkosu shoyu and pork fried rice!

c198ImJBfNH1zJnA4RPm8A.text: For some reason I was craving ramen and what do you know, we were about to pass it by. We stopped here and luckily there was no line. It was really nice and cool inside.  I ordered the tonkatsu ramen which was with the pork broth and with a mild spicy level.    My husband ordered the miso broth one and it definitely hit the spot. The beers on draft here is cheap so we had a great dinner.  This is definitely a great spot to come to and its affordable.  The noodles were so fresh and you can tell it was homemade. This was a great first experience at this place!!!

DVco_k6yPQ5pikoLOtX5-w.text: Best ramen in town! The first day I went here I was amazed & then I came back the next 3 days in a row because I craved it. Having been to Japan, this place has very authentic Japanese service; warm welcomes, prompt service, genuine care & a sincere want for you to come back again.   I love that the ramen noodle are made fresh. You can actually watch them make the noodles through a glass window towards the front door. The bowls are huge & under $10, unless you want extra toppings but the original bowls come with a lot in them. From original to hot, the flavors are exceptional & you have to order their pork chashu buns...to die for!   Definitely try this restaurant! You won't be disappointed. Expect a little bit of a wait if you're going for dinner though but it's worth it. You
