p6DINBxiOG_URxPOmGfJiQ.text: Tried this place the other day and it was ok. The place is pretty small, a bar area with about 7-8 seats and 5-6 smaller tables against the wall. We were lucky and got a seated right away, a few minutes later people were waiting in line.   We tried the kimchi fried rice with pork belly on top and this was delicious! The fried rice was better than the ramen.   I tried the Miso ramen spicy level mild and it had a nice kick to it. What I don't like is that it does not come with egg while places like Sora include egg with the ramen. The broth was ok, I have had better broth. Another thing I don't like is that our ramen came with 1 tiny piece of Chasu, they want to charge for egg and extra Chasu while other places give you decent portion of Chasu without having to order extra! They also don't have any appetizers like gyoza, you can only get ramen and fried rice.   The restaurant is small and tight, people bumped into me while I was seated at the bar area. The parking is also pretty small, cars were waiting in line and fighting for spots. I would not mind all this if the ramen was amazing but it was not. Will go elsewhere for ramen without all the hassle.   Definitely not good for large parties, parties larger than 4 are not recommended! If you want to check out the hype then go, but if you just want good ramen so somewhere else.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kimchi fried rice with pork belly - This was very good!
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso Ramen spicy level mild
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkatsu Ramen with egg added

x4zZdu55i7-d-zl95pPUvQ.text: I would say I go into this southwest feeding ground about once (more like twice) a week. It's a small location, that usually takes awhile to be seated but is always worth the wait. Typically, there's no upside to sitting in a cramped corner, watching others get seated before you; but here they have set-up a large window to allow you to watch an adorable older woman hand make the noodles that go into every dish. They take, "The way mom use to make it." seriously here, because mom is STILL making it and you can taste her love in every bowl.  This girl version of a bachelor, really enjoys her take-out food and this place tastes just as good when you're dining in as it does in a huge bowl being eaten on my couch. My only issue is time and time again we have a disconnect in ordering and some extra topping I added is typically missing. When I'm there they are really good about bringing it out to me quickly, but when I get home there is nothing sadder than adding all your fixings and you realize that your Nitamago (soft boiled egg) is missing. The eggs aren't the only things that are extra when you go there though... Yes, I am referring to myself as extra.  Extra (definition found on Urban Dictionary)  Doing the absolute damn most, for no reason.  My order in order: 1.) Broth -Miso Ramen (pork & chicken broth) 2.) Spicy Level -Medium, even though sometimes medium feels a bit more on the hot side 3.) Extra Toppings -Nitamago (soft boil egg), for something soft in texture -Bamboo Shoots, for something crunchy in texture -Spinach, for something green -Corn, because I love corn in everything -Butter, because carbs  The real secret to amazing ramen is you MUST add the Black Garlic Oil, because my ramen can never have too much sodium. I'd get it on the side though, so you can add to your liking.

Qk8PzPen-3Q_uWcIgLWhow.text: I went for a tad bit spicy instead of mild for once and was please rly surprised. Very good bowl of noodles. Always stop where when I'm in town for work.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States

khqU1EELh6mGCdviWbGxrg.text: Decent ramen with decent price. Nothing outstanding that makes you want to go back. Lack of customer service. Anyway, can't complain too much. If you are looking for REAL Japanese ramen, this is not the choice. But if you are looking for some place that close to good ramen quality, this is the place for you!

qklYoZKFXB1b_6us1rcyoQ.text: (2.5 star) Came here on Wednesday at around 11:45 am, right after they opened. There were already about 10 people eating (wow!). I was exited to try their gravy like thick creamy Tonkotsu broth ramen. I ordered it mild. With extra chicken chashu(char siu), green onion and seaweed paper. When it came out, I saw red spicy oil floating in my soup. I specifically told the waitress I wanted it mild... so I told her I ordered it mild. She tells me "Oh, we have spicy oil right next to our soup pot, so we usually put a little in. I can bring you plain broth on the side so you can put it in your bowl." WTH!! If I was sensitive to spicy, I would've sent it back. (Luckily I was a spicy food lover) Tip... If you are sensitive to spicy food, tell them you want it "plain" instead of "mild". Their mild is like spice level 3 out of 10.  Usually Tonkotsu ramen comes with straight al dente noodles in decent ramen shops but theirs come with freshly made non straight noodles. I could tell their noodles were very fresh. I enjoyed it.  Though the soup was a little spicy, it was tasty and flavorful. I was expecting the soup to be much thicker but they probably over diluted my soup with hot water.  For some reason, my chicken chachu was ice cold like they just took it out from the fridge. I don't know if it was supposed to be cold?? but would've been better if it was warm or hot.  Location is convenient right off 215 but if I want Tonkotsu ramen, I would go to Monta.  Will not come back.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Side plain Tonkotsu broth.

177exP8XlQz7sGwaoDutGg.text: Very good Ramen! They were delicious, fresh, and fast. The fried rice is unreal!!!!!! I only wish they had more veggies you could add but other wise the menu is straight to the point and easy to read! Yum!!!

HQJKAiF8_zhxCO31xUh_dQ.text: Great ramen joint, I've been coming here pretty routinely for the past year. I've had a great experience up until my visit earlier this month. I used to love this place all due to their delicious pork chashu, which was creamy, full of flavor, and would fall apart at the attempt of picking it up with the chopsticks.   However, during my last 2 visits this month, the pork chashu was served cold, as if they just pulled it out of their fridge. The broth is hot and the meat is cold? (Wut?) Not only that, but it is now very tough and flavorless as well, almost to the point of needing other utensils to cut it.  I asked the servers what changed and they said nothing but I've been here enough to recognize the difference. I probably won't return.

4jOpkYDVBW3VkgerlWnM6g.text: Delicious Ramen made on site, the pork belly is perfection. I wish the hours were more accommodating throughout the day but other than that you will not be dissapointed.

ifculqXRYpc7XndB0zgkJg.text: I was very excited that a Japanese Ramen restaurant opened on the southwest area. I love Japanese ramen and haven't had the the kind of ramen I had in San Francisco Japan town. My husband and my 3 kids ordered shoyu original, tonkotchu hot, pork belly bowl, and fried rice. I was a little skeptical about this place because of the yelp review I read before we went. However,  surprisingly they were very tasty and not even fatty at all unlike the review said. The portion was good and the freshly made noodles were cooked just right. The broth had plenty of flavors and clean taste.  I thought they were as tasty or even better than the ramen I had in San Francisco Japan town. My kids loved the noodles and fried rice and asked me to come every day... :P

CmJ7rC2r81j30Oj0CpU-Dg.text: First time here and it's a very new place so I'll be a bit easy about it.  This is a small ramen spot by the west side.  I ordered a mild miso ramen with butter.  The ramen in general was good. The broth was a bit salty and too rich for my liking. I would skip the butter next time. The chashu was soft. I wish they added more bamboo shoots and bean sprouts   I was with 6 other people and 3 orders were messed up. Hence the star I'm knocking off.  There's room for improvement but this place is still new.  Edit: I was typing this last night while we were waiting for our check and I'm knocking another star off because two of the waitresses kept asking my friend about his one can of coke. One waitress kept asking if it was just "one coke" on his receipt about 3 times, arguing with the waitress about it. We were all so confused and annourf because we were all talking and getting interrupted by the SAME question. It's like they didn't believe us about only getting one can of coke.   So 3 stars for decent ramen but if you can't even keep track of one can of coke, there's some more training to be done.

sGKKBaJFWl8ysAK_aG5CSw.text: This place shocked me, the ramen is delicious, the broth made it's way to the right flavor, and the pork is melt in your mouth. TVlvgE8Hj_dhfFbL2YuK8w.text: Came to Kobo on their opening day for dinner. The restaurant was clean, and nicely decorated. When you walk in, there is a glass room where you can see the homemade noodles being made. A plus!  My boyfriend and I ordered the same Tonkotsu ramen with egg and corn. One of the bowls came out with the wrong broth, but they were happy to fix the order quickly.   I would get a medium spice for next time (we could barely taste the mild). The broth was a little creamier than expected, but non the less delicious.  The restaurant was fairly busy with a 15-20 minute wait. The staff was very friendly and helpful. Would come again :)  Great job on your opening day.. And welcome to the neighborhood!!!

ro0gxRErCrpJbkN0jmYGRg.text: Miso ramen medium spicy is real good better than nyc ramen places.  Mentaiko bowl was also good but too much rice vs mentaiko.

1zq3VIhih7H024S3kYg2Rg.text: Came here for lunch for the first time on a Monday afternoon. Located in the new center next to subway near Starbucks and EOS fitness, this is the new location by the highly known Monta Ramen/Sushi Mon group on the Southwest side of Vegas !   We met up at 1230 and instantly got a table. The store itself is small, length wise, similar to Monta in seating capacity. Decor is nice and simple, with long wooden boards oriented vertically  lined up the wall for a nice high feeling. Different from the usual Monta decor. Also, they make their own ramen, in house, in the glass room, facing the exterior of the restaurant ! Mmm love fresh noodles ! I dont care if its pasta or la mien or ramen or udon. So good ! This is the main reason why i came to try this place !   Service was quick and friendly. We were asked our drink orders as soon as we sat down, by 2 different people, in a spread of like 10 seconds. Lol   We had waited for our late friend before we had ordered our food.   ----------------------------------------------------  Their menu is very simple. If anything, its identical to Monta's except with the choice of a spicy level.   1. Pick Your Broth - Shoyu Ramen (Chicken Broth), Tonkotsu Ramen (Pork Broth), Miso Ramen (Pork & Chicken Broth), and Vege Ramen (Vegetable Broth). All priced at $8.95.   Shoyu, Tonkotsu, and Miso Ramen comes with 1 slice of Chashu Pork, Fried Garlic, Kikurage Black mushrooms, Bamboo Shoots, Fresh Green Chives, Ground Pork, Sesame Oil, and Shredded Red Pepper.   Vege Ramen comes with Fried Onion, Shredded Green Onion, Tofu, Spinach, Corn, Ginger, and Fresh Green Chives.   2. Pick Your Spicy Level. Original, Mild, Medium, Hot, Fire.   3. Pick Your EXTRA Topping (Prices Vary) - Chashu pork/chicken, Ground pork/chicken, Spicy Fish Roe (Mentaiko), Kikurage Black Mushroom, Shredded Green Onion, Soft Boiled Egg (Nitamago), Mustard Green (Takana), Spinach, Kimchi, Bamboo Shoots, Nira Chive, Roasted Seaweed (Nori), Black Garlic Oil, Bean Sprouts (Moyashi), Corn, Butter, and EXTRA NOODLE.   Also the usual side dishes available. Fried Rice, Kimchi Fried Rice, Pork Belly Bowl, Chashu Bowl, and Mini Mentaiko Bowl.   ----------------------------------------------------  I had ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen, FIRE, with a soft boiled egg. Normally if this was for dinner or something, id probably get extra noodles too, but i just woke up maybe an hour or so prior to this, so my stomach is like meh xD haha can't eat that much.   Fairly quick to deliver the food, after the table next too us got theirs.   Noodles are unique to this location. If you had ever had Monta previously, its more towards thick than thin. But not too thick. So in between the two. Noodles cooked very well. Al dente. Perfect chewiness. Best part of the meal ! I want more ! but i was full. xD   Broth is flavorful but still pretty heavy, like the usual tonkotsu. FIRE spicy level adds a pretty good kick to it all.   Fried garlic is something new. Though its more like a roasted garlic vs a fried garlic. But i cant complain since i LOVE garlic. Had to throw in another spoonful of garlic anyway hehe :P   At Monta, you'd normally receive i believe 2-3 slices of chashu pork. But at Kobo, you get 1 slice of chashu pork, but in return, you get a small mound of ground pork. Not too bad. Their chashu pork seems pretty similar to their sister locations. Fatty xD Ground pork not overcooked and rough. Fairly decent.   Nitamago was cooked nicely. Maybe a little over a perfect soft boiled. Still has a nice golden, rich, and creamy yolk.   Aside from the normal toppings, the chives was a nice touch. I am a HUGE fan of chives and love anything with them.   Overall, not bad. Close convenient location for the people who live in the SW or a teasing/torture style for those who walk out of the EOS gym. Nice to have more options now in the area. Would be nice to pick up some food after work from the hospital if i work late.

OlXCrWX4GtpQwLi84h2vCA.text: This is one of my favorite ramen spots in town. I always go for their Tonkatsu ramen with corn, egg and of course extra pork chashu! Having different levels of spiciness that you can choose from is nice too. Excellent service, staff are very attentive.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Original Tonkatsu Ramen with corn, egg and extra pork chasu on the side.

psMHmu7qQ14TwBepngqVlw.text: Oh wow. I'm in tears and my face is red. I had the Miso Ramen with Fire heat, and they are not lying. I've been to many ramen joints all of town who claim that they have spicy noodles, some even offer you a scale. But the highest portion of the scale is never actually spicy. I don't even have the highest spice tolerance, but most places just don't it. The next time I come here, I'll probably just order it hot. Unless I'm hungover and miserable of course because fire at this place would be the perfect cure.  The noodles were pretty damn awesome. They make them in house, and you can even watch them make them in a machine that's windowed off at the front. Sadly, our set of noodles in our ramen were overlooked, but the batch of extra noodles were al dente and had a great spongy quality. I'm going to give them the benefit of the doubt on the original set. Hopefully, it was a fluke.  The broth was fantastic. Along with the aforementioned spice, it was packed with flavor and all around excellent.  My partner even had the vegetable broth, and I usually dislike those greatly. Jinya has been the only place in town with decent vegetable broth. However, this wasn't just decent. It was actually excellent. I would not mind eating it at all.  One small gripe, besides the first batch of over cooked noodles, the Asahi mugs are tiny. They're worth the price, but they just feel tiny like I'm not actually getting a full beer. The ounces might be there, but they seem and feel small.  Can't wait to come back.

SB-2Z6RNfq6Op_iHUUYUOA.text: I highly recommend this place - by far our favorite in Las Vegas! Menu is simple and they mean business when it comes to their spicy ramen. Loved the flavors of the broth - both veggie flavor and spicy one. It's always great when amazing food can be served with great service. We will be definitely be back.

437M4Xh2-GmqhzQ9aEkseg.text: The waiter took forever to take our order and when we got our fried rice waited another 30 mins to find out they forgot our ramen. It wasn't even busy rush hour was over. So idk what happen there very disappointing. This place use to prompt and efficient *smh*

sp00r9oAkTjV3ZvOMTwuJg.text: So my verdict is in. I waited to write his review after my second visit, because I just wasn't sure on how I felt about their ramen. First, their ramen is mediocre at best, truthfully, the broth was very bland to me. Also the claim that they hand make their noodles is nice, but it definitely doesn't taste as good as places that don't hand make their noodles. I enjoyed their chashu fried rice and their service though. Ramen isn't really their strong suit in my opinion

-Wa6mXM-N2ymxKXc2aUySQ.text: The ramen is amazing!!! My favorite in LV. They make their own ramen in house, you can customize the spiciness of the broth, and add in other veggies. I get the veggie ramen.  Sooo delish!  My only complaint is that it is so small inside so we frequently order takeout.

jpSEfZ1LXVoEwmMduxO-FQ.text: I give this place its' props because when you order the spicy ramen, it is ACTUALLY spicy, unlike many other places I've been. I appreciate that the noodles are perfectly cooked with the perfect amount of bite to them. The broth has depth in flavor and overall, quite tasty.   I also had the pork belly bowl here which had a nice bbq/grill flavor to it, being nicely savory without being overly salty. The green onion in the bowl also adds some nice flavor to the dish.  The wait around 11:30am on a Sunday was not too bad- about 15 minutes. I would come back, but definitely need to try other ramen spots first!

YEfLZueR80cbjyU7ie6mtQ.text: Tried other ramen place but none compare to this place. Amazing quality and taste. Definitely my new go to spot for ramen.

66Geutlig-fRNe87By4rNA.text: I live in this area and I would say this is the go to ramen joint for my husband and I. It's the closest and also the cheapest. It's fairly small with about 4-5 tables and a bar that can seat about 8. Therefore if you have a party of 5+ then the wait may be longer. Usually I wait for about 10 minutes for a party of two.  The miso broth is great! And I like how they have the option of how spicy you can make your ramen. The mild to medium is how I enjoy mine while my husband goes for the spicy. One thing I thought odd was that the egg was an additional topping. All the other ramen place I've gone to had it in their ramen naturally and this place will add an additional 1.50$. However since this is the cheapest place I can't complain too much.  Service is good and friendly and my water is never empty. Probably because it's such a small place.

4kWvcSTH8Eudv5iubox64g.text: This is my first time being here and it was a very good idea! Veggie options AND the miso is goooood. They are SERIOUS with their spicy ness, my lips hurt. Anywyas awesome ramen!

K8EHTlYUv_5g2h-T8swa9Q.text: We ordered the shoyu ramen, tonkatsu ramen, fried rice, pork belly bowl and the chashu bowl. Excellent service.  I have never seen chives in ramen at any place in Japan or Okinawa. Let's say, for me, it doesn't jive. I prefer traditional green onions and refuse to pay $1.00 extra for it. The fried rice was okay. The ramen bowls were good. The pork belly and the chashu lacked flavor and did not wow me.  Although the establishment is clean and the experience was nice especially with the excellent service, I do not agree with a lot of the yelp reviews.

ciZw3uLBN9RSwoVl9q8noA.text: We didn't want to drive to our usual spot in Chinatown so we tried this place out. Parking may be difficult depeding on the time you go. As for wait time, we waited about 20 mins on a Thursday dinner rush. My wife got the tonkotsu original and she liked it. I got the tonkotsu mild and it was just the right amount of spiciness. I had great expectations for the pork belly bowl. I found it lacking in a lot of ways. I really wanted to like it but it was bland for my taste. Will be back for their ramen.

KJ2Jz1JWYKuquNJD6-HJcQ.text: It's never a bad day for ramen at Kobo. Similar to ramen at Monta, but without the hard parking and ridiculous wait times.   Ramen Kobo offers a few levels of spicy for those that love and dislike spicy food. Be warned though, I ordered medium and it was pretty spicy. Ramen at Kobo offers a nice experience because you get to see how the noodles are freshly made when you enter the restaurant. If you haven't had ramen, I would highly suggest trying out this place.   The location is small, so big parties be warned. Further, the whole party must be there in order to get seated. If you're looking for to-go they offer an easy way to order by yourself at the entrance, and are often very quick with getting your order completed.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States

VSCMui_JhfpBYImZLv_zpA.text: Who would have thought this would be a neighbor  spot walking distance from my home. It's small & cozy and reminds me of a type of restaurant you would see in San Francisco. It offers an open kitchen layout and clean, contemporary feel with wood & metal material throughout. There is a small room upfront where the noodles are made. Unfortunately I have yet to experience this but hopefully one day soon.  Now onto the good stuff...the food! Reminder: I was never a True fan of ramen until I came here. I have now dined in twice and take out once. 2/3 times I have tried something different; the basic shoyu and today consisted of the miso. Their spice level has a little more kick than what you may be use to. I recommend sticking with mild and kicking it up yourself with the chili oil & powder they have. I am not a fan of the ground meat that is standard in the ramen. It's definitely a consistency thing but so much better without it. The noodles are indescribable and cooked al dente and have yet to experience anything other.   The only problem I have...they do not deliver nor on post mates or uber eats! But then again ramen should be enjoyed at the restaurant. It's not the same experience when at home.   For any newbies, give yourself some time. Typically there is a slight wait but turnover is quick. Don't get impatient. You will not be disappointed!

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu - chicken broth

d3ZQH4Yk-ParxdxoJRKtlw.text: I am in love with noodles! I love this place. The food is incredible! I have been to their Chinatown location and Centennial location, I recommend each location also!

7rROsyjQbO7XABdpFtPyog.text: Wonderful and worth the wait! I had the Tonkatsu Ramen with black garlic oil and a soft boiled egg. It was delicious! Also tried the kimchi fried rice which was also very tasty. Highly recommend this restaurant to anyone looking for great ramen.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States

TmPtfmyVmHhIuYwmDZ4VGA.text: Been coming here for years since they open with my son and it's been good, but we show up today and they said I can't have the baby stroller, because of the fire safety.. I guess we have to look for the new place to go eat from now on..

ywQeRdH5NG3Wf1p5dzQZNg.text: I'd be pressed to say that the ramen here is even better than ramen you eat in Japan. Seriously!  Ramen KoBo is by the same makers of Monta Ramen and you can really see the similarities from the dinky dining area to the limited but extremely well executed options on the menu. Fancy seeing the noodles made in person? The kitchen area is open alongside an end which is divided by glass and you can see the chefs and cooks spinning up flour with their hands to make the noodles.  I love this place for two reasons: first reason. EDM all day, everyday. And I'm not just talking about the generic big room stuff. No, this place was blasting oldies but goodies like Tritonal's Now or Never and new tunes (as of 12/7) like Illenium, Borgeous and more. Whoever decided to play edm, GOOD edm here, kudos to you.  Ok for my second reason, the menu items like I mentioned is limited but it is very good. I had the miso ramen with extra pork and an order of the boiled eggs. But one little thing that made a WORLD of a difference for me here...you can adjust the spiciness here. If you're a spicy food lover like me, this is a game changer. Seriously, I never knew miso ramen tasted this good when you make it spicy (going for the hottest one next time).  Not only that, but the broth is not so fattening and you can clearly see how smooth it is once you are nearly done with your bowl. When all your noodles and veggies and things have been eaten away, your broth will either have fat bubbles floating around or it'll be clear. All clear here.  I absolutely love this place and the best part is that it's literally three minutes away from my new office now. Win win win.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso hot with eggs and extra pork

FrNzsKmwOHdHqjaQWEY8zw.text: My favorite ramen place in Las Vegas! This Truely felt like I was in japan again. Everything was absolutely amazing!

L-9OBbl0yaVMAjffM0Vpbw.text: Fresh noodle making machine is amazing. Thanks for the great food!!! I will be back for round two!

4eOIQwegCT7XTgWZfT3nRw.text: I've been checking out the different Ramen spots in Vegas and Ramen KoBo is my go to spot. The Ramen here is amazing! If you have a taste for ramen and your in the area don't hesitate to eat here.

KHszYnEzwAHC53HQcTfZhQ.text: Hands down one of my favorite ramen places in Las Vegas despite the fact that it is a bit of a drive for me. The customer service here has been consistently great the three times that I have eaten here. It is a smaller restaurant so there usually is a wait; however, we have never waited more than fifteen minutes (each time has been a party of three).   There are five levels of spices: original, mild, medium, hot, and fire. I'm a bit of a wimp when it comes to spices so medium was too hot for me the first time; however, mild has always been just right.   I don't eat red meat so it is always a struggle finding a ramen place that offers poultry or vegetable based broth; however, Ramen KoBo offers both! In addition, I like to add the extra topping of ground chicken with nori (roasted seaweed) with a seasoned egg.  Customer Service: 5/5 Environment: 5/5 Food: 5/5  Definitely a great place if you're craving ramen and don't feel the desire to drive out to Spring Mountain!

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Vegetable ramen with a seasoned egg, spinach, nori, and ground chicken.

xjLphmY2cojped5bQ-rApw.text: Amazing food!! Great customer service and very fast. I won't go anywhere else for ramen because nowhere can beat this place. I love love love it. I also get the fried rice and it's to die for. It is a little small inside but I don't mind since the food is amazing!

DYFobsEg8hOec95pqGRlXQ.text: Ramen KoBo is a small noodle joint with a significant wait time during prime lunch hours. We waited as a party of four for Saturday lunch for about 20-25 minutes before being seated. The service was great and friendly, so let's cut right to the ramen. We had the tonkatsu and miso ramen plus a small rice bowl with salmon roe. Everything was delicious. The tonkatsu broth is on point! I added black garlic oil for an additional $1.00 which made the broth a lot more earthy and savory. It is an intense flavor so I wouldn't recommend for those who prefer a lighter broth. You can add extra toppings for additional cost to what they already provide. The noodles had a great texture. BEWARE the spice level - I asked for mild and it felt like medium to me - if unsure you should just ask for the hot sauce on the side.  The only suggestion I would make is to give one more slice of meat for the standard ramen bowl. One thin slice is a bit stingy. But the rest of the food is great and if you like noodles (and don't care too much about meat) you will enjoy this place.

1R2PHlDCHf4dHKw7eZUKbw.text: They make their own noodles in the house! Believe the owner also owns Monta so you know what you're getting.   Service is always friendly. I only wish that they would have gyoza on the menu.   Aside from ramen, kimchi fried rice is a must try.

S3EkFIdjk-Unno3tMUu4Og.text: I love the fact that they have a healthy version of vegetable ramen, but you can always substitute the soup with tonkatsu soup if you feel like cheating.  Great ramen and nice ambiance, it feels like you are literally in Japan.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Vegetable Ramen

ONCIRjtGH9H8y3asIcCGJg.text: Location: The place is located one block from Rhodes Ranch, in the same plaza with the EOS gym, right next to Cafe Rio. There are plenty of parking spaces in the back if you happen to come on a busy day.   Decor: the restaurant is on the smaller size side. They have about 8 tables and bar. If you are in a hurry and don't have to sit at a large table,'I'd recommend to sit at the bar since you will have a better chance to sit on a busy day. All around is Japanese style ramen like in Tokyo. It's an open cooking space where you can see how they prep your meal. This is one of a good thing, you know they will be clean when someone is watching, haha.  Simple artistic decor and oh, the bathroom is clean.   Menu/ ingredients: once you walked into the restaurant, there is a noodle maker machine on side. All of their noodles are handmade at the location. With the exception of Tsukeme style ramen (soup on the side) which what I usually order since I believe those are ready to cook ones. It's probably due to different process required when it comes to yellow noodle. Tsukemen is more chewy compared to regular ramen noodle. I also ordered their house fried rice, very tasty and has pork belly in it! Yummm. Must try!   Service: Their service is always good and fast. They always make sure the have enough employees to cover all tables. But I can see the space is a challenge especially when it's super busy and they are trying to bus table and then deliver soups in that small hallway.   Price: a little higher compared to Monta in Chinatown. Portion is bigger though. And only mushroom, bamboo shoot, 2 slices of pork and green onion are included. Everything else are extras.   RecommendAtion: Tsukemen is my favorite! Love hpw you can adjust your spicy level and add extra toppings. I would recommend to include some of the extras. Eggs should be included in the price since one bowl is already $9-10.   Overall, I am satisfied and will be back. If they include more extra items in the price, then I will be back more often.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Noodle in the making
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States

8YQJCloqL5OUuH-DeyB0dQ.text: I'd recommend this ramen house. The tonkatsu broth with black garlic oil was great! I ordered extra chashu and it was plenty! The chashu was good too! Although I would have liked my broth to have been a little hotter. it wasn't cold... just not hot like soup ought to be.  Our whole family ordered different bowls and we were all full, fat, and happy!

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States

EjPZreunKbdBKzrvZqsfAg.text: I had low expectations going in, but I enjoyed my ramen bowls. I think it at least tastes better than Monta ramen. And since there are no ramen places on this side of town, beggars can't be choosers, right?  I pretty much get the same ramen every time and stick with their shoyu ramen. It's not overly fatty, but not super clean either. I like that it's simple. No need to choose noodles, and make things complicated.   Service is quite good. And they move fast from seating to exit.    Rating:  3.5 stars.

phea8ApJ7dra_OOA8qLt-w.text: Neither satisfied nor dissatisfied. I mean, it wasn't bad but it just wasn't what I remember.   But, what really stood out to me this time was something different... I'm not sure why I felt a little unsettled but the line cooks and servers were talking in Spanish and telling jokes. I speak fluent Spanish and they would not be saying the things they were out loud if people could hear them. I think most of the people there only speak English or Japanese so they might have assumed that no one else could understand but I've been a chef for 12 years and although my Spanish isn't perfect, I can usually get the jist of the conversation. The prep cooks in the back seemed to also understand because when they noticed me paying attention, they shook their head in disgust. Then, the main line cook (short, older woman) ran back to say something to them. At that moment, the jokes and laughing also ended so I'm assuming it was related. Even if it wasn't, it was unsettling to see as a customer. The prep cooks didn't seem to like what they were joking about but the short older woman didn't think anyone else would notice... I guess  Where I usually get a feeling of being content and satisfied after a hot bowl of Tonkotsu, I was left with an uneasy feeling so actually, I guess, it was not good. What is even worse is that I was now full from the meal. Which sucks because it was like I ate a bowl of rice but found out later it was actually maggots. It's already in your stomach so there isn't much you can do but throw it up. My stomach started turning after seeing and hearing the servers and front line cooks joking around like that.   Not only that but I find it very unprofessional to see the servers and cooks directly in front of customers telling jokes and snickering like that. It may be innocent but costumers don't know when they are speaking a foreign language and their body language during the jokes speak volumes from it. This is one thing that managers and owners would most likely be very upset with if they saw it going on. Jokes and personal things should not be shown to guests like that. It's just very unprofessional and this is the reason why. (Unless, it's something universally accepted,obviously) But, I felt like my stomach was turning after seeing that.   The food was good (even though it was plated very sloppy. Where the toppings are usually very precisely placed and neat, they were just thrown on top. Not exactly a reflection of the flavor but a reflection of the quality and attention put into the dish). So, it still gets 2 stars but if the flavor was anything less, it would be an easy 1 star.   I probably won't be back to let that happen though.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kind of sloppy plate presentation where its usually very neat and precise

7-EFCaLtakZ4v4ndJnEG5g.text: I believe this has been my 5th time here, the food is always good and the service is excellent. My server was really kind and genuine. I got seated really quick too even thought it was on a Friday night. Even though everything was great but the background music was really bothering me. The restaurant played Hardcore EDM which made me feel rushing to finish my food and leave. However, definitely a good place to try and you will like it.

FGevTKU6Q1TPm7FKUIZy8g.text: I really enjoyed their broth. It was the first time i had it taste like egg yolk and was also very creamy.

E4eaLjAP-N4jKRF2KwO4qg.text: My friend and I were starving and didn't feel like driving too far to get food. Ramen kobo was about 1 mile away !!   We got there around noon, and the restaurant was halfway full and getting fuller. I was starving so we ordered right away. The waitress took our order wrong and we ended up with an extra noodle which we gave back. I ordered a tonkotsu ramen extra spicy with a soft boiled egg, and we split a small fried rice.   The tonkotsu ramen was super tasty !!! The soft boiled egg was plain but it was nice and soft, I was hoping for an ajitsuke tamago egg. Ordering extra spicy was a good choice, it was pretty spicy and made my mouth tingle. The fried rice here is bomb!!!! It's super flavorful, next time I would order a large so I could have extra to go.  Food is decently priced as well, I would come here again if I was craving ramen.

ePd25q7YHUswQqZcKsFC2Q.text: Came here last night on a double date around 8... it is a small restaurant so be prepared to wait. We waited roughly about 10 mins and then we were seated. Compared to Monta Ramen off of spring mountain, this one has way more options to chose from. You have the option to make your broth spicy or not (I kept it the original) but the spicy one is good as well (from what my boyfriend told me). You can add multiple things in your ramen as well. I added the boiled egg and it was OK. I really didn't notice a difference. The ramen was still good! Very different from what I'm used to because the noodles are slightly thicker! The only thing is once our waitress dropped off our food she disappeared. Causing all of us to need refills with no one to be found. We had to wave someone down to get a refill, which is annoying. Other than that I will most likely be back to this ramen place !

SV468xyxTzsAtAkKoUzxSQ.text: I was excited to finally see a ramen place open up on the south west side of town! It does save me from having to drive all the way to Chinatown for a good bowl. Out of all the spots that are close by this is the only place that has solid bowl of ramen.   They make their noodles fresh. I like thicker chewy noodles but theirs are not bad at all. I like how you can pick your spice level. I always get the miso ramen with egg at medium spice. Perfect for a cold day.   Also, their pork belly bowl is a must if you have the room. They have a small bowl that you can get. It's also another alternative to the the pork belly bowl you can get at monta. It's not the same but just as good.

owRGkJlhvHen5nFIEAw96A.text: Amazing! The noodles were the best. Chose the Shoyu with Chashu pork, egg, chives, and black garlic oil. vNxwkSBfHGTy6VfDrPSEpw.text: I was excited to try this place since it is across the street from my boyfriend's apartment. I heard a lot of good things since the noodles are made fresh in house.  I had the pork tongkotsu. I love the eggs that come in ramen so I was quite disappointed when my bowl didn't include one. I added an egg but it was nowhere in my bowl when my food was delivered. I didn't care for the noodles, they didn't stand out for me. The broth was delicious. The pork chashu was too thin and not as flavorful as I like.  The service was good.  Bottom line: If you really want to try the noodles, try it but it's not worth the hype.

0QkZoLegAfNOcQz26D_Htg.text: Small restaurant but service moves quickly.   The ramen is awesome. They make it fresh in front of you. Right when you enter the restaurant, you can see the guy making the noodles behind the glass wall.  The menu is pretty basic. You build your own bowl - pick your broth, spicy level, and add any extras toppings if you want.   Had the shoyu ramen with medium spicy level and added the egg. Broth was light and flavorful but not spicy enough. Should've gotten hot spicy level. I think they might've mixed my bowl with my friend's, who had mild (but they were both the same red color).

6Uth7Ho-NdiAG_TSIJqLaQ.text: Service A+ Food Tasty Asahi on draft, Yes Vegan options! This place deserves at least 4 Stars. The ramen was really good. I bought shoyu like usual and paired it with draft beer. Their shoyu is made with creamy chicken broth that's rich and really hit the spot. I'll try a different broth next time with the asahi. Cute lil place worth it. :D  Review Edit: Gave the fifth star to the. Because a friendly gentleman that works there complimented my girlfriends Pokemon wallet and showed off his awesome Pokemon finger tattoos. GJ sir, I hope if you ever read this you keep living the dream. :)

3_AWofF98WbEZ9Q-RTBvDw.text: A killer spot for Ramen in which the male their own noodles in house... in my taste, I like the soups original, but others in my party had the heat turned up to medium... They all said it was too hot... Luv it

GVaINL3h7nt0caao_ERyUw.text: This is my go to ramen joint! The menu items here are all very tasty, and the tonkotsu is my favorite. They serve it with a wide variety of toppings and the broth is solid. I love the handmade noodles and miss it terrible when I'm away from home. I also really like the pork belly with rice, which is just pork belly with salt, oil, and rice and it's so bad for my health but so so tasty.  The only downside is that I've had some inconsistency with my chashu. At times it's delicious and melty and fatty, and other times it's been a bit lacking whether in flavor or just feeling like it was pulled out of a refrigerator like 2 seconds ago.  Overall, a really tasty and reliable place.

Xs3ePUOEtITfvBXeR9ynPQ.text: I have eaten a lot of ramen in my life, but this place was pretty horrible! We were excited to see that a ramen place was opening closer to home. When I read that this was created by the Monta team, I expected the same delicious food and had high expectations. Unfortunately, this was absolutely nothing like Monta.  The restaurant is super tiny and I felt uncomfortable being very close to the table next to us. I ordered the original Shoyu Ramen without any extra toppings. It's cool that they make their own noodles, but honestly there was nothing special about it. They were too thick for my liking and would definitely prefer the noodles that are served at Monta. The Shoyu broth was disgusting! There was no flavor at all and I honestly felt like I was eating noodles in a bowl of plain hot water. The one piece of Chasu was 100% fat and most of the ground pork sank to the bottom of the bowl, making it hard to eat. Just Eww. I hate to say this, but I think a $0.25 instant ramen from the grocery store would have been better than this!! They also screwed up on the spice levels for others at our table. My husband ordered mild, but he said it was pretty spicy. Our friend ordered hot, but it turned out to be on the mild side.   I am giving two stars because the staff was attentive, refilled our drinks quickly and took empty plates away as needed. I understand that they are new and still getting their act together, but I will not be back. The drive to Chinatown is worth it for good tasting ramen!

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The worst Shoyu Ramen ever!

SmI4hXENrn2D-vyYTHGTFg.text: We are so happy we took this advice from yelp and dined-in to this place. This place is awesome, I seriously felt like I was eating ramen in Japan. Freshly made noodles from scratch on my ramen, flavorful soup with fresh toppings, sesame oil flavor on their rice topped with pork belly. I thought the ramen here is the best ever. It cannot be better timing than having ramen on a freezing cold night in vegas. Wow I highly recommend this cozy place called ramen kobo. You cannot go wrong with your ramen cravings.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States

20q6NyzuA66a0wKj5ve0Rg.text: One of my favorite ramen shops on the southwest side of town! They are so nice despite how busy it usually is.

Ho4jeHc-aLv5KCP8gmZNHA.text: Ramen KoBo (Translated to Ramen Factory) is a new ramen shop that recently opened in the Southwest of Vegas near Ikea. Ramen Kobo being owned by Mon Restaurant Group, I had expected a higher quality considering their other successful shops like Monta and Monzo.  Ramen Kobo is a small shop with mainly bar seating to overlook their open kitchen, then 5-6 tables along the wall. Servers were extremely attentive but there was one cook in particular who looked pissed off and didn't want to be there. I would look up and see him giving me an ice-cold glare and I had noticed he was eavesdropping to our conversation the entire time which I did not feel comfortable. My personal suggestion is to avoid their bar seating.   I got to try their tonkotsu ramen and veggie ramen. Both were subpar in my opinion. Ramen were on the al dente side.   Tonkotsu: Extremely light, flavorless broth. If you took a sip of their broth blindfolded, you might guess that their broth is hot water with salt. Chashu was just one paper-thin slice of fat with no meat on it. Bean sprouts were under-cooked and made me feel icky. 2/5  Veggie: Broth was still bland but better than tonkotsu. Two slices of fried tofu to substitute the chashu but these tofu will make you feel like you are biting into a dish washing sponge. I would still recommend veggie ramen over tonkotsu. 2.5/5  Overall a very disappointing experience. They just opened so I'm sure they are still working out their kinks but I don't see myself coming back here again.

jjEZOO_zgsPSOhEJkSKElA.text: This is a cute little place. Not much room but good food. This is a typical noodle house with typical prices.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States

10ADVGUV6U4EE5eQkLotTQ.text: Best ramen place in Las Vegas hands down! Always such amazing food and service. One of my favorite places to go.

VdLSqRhgCZ_wFp4GTFf44w.text: Same owners as Monta that offers more of a spicy kick to ramen.  I had the Tonkotsu Ramen medium and it was tame. Noodles felt fresh as well as all the ingredients. Chashu for some reason is a lot better at Monta but the noodles at KoBo are slightly better....wierd how that is.  Ordered the kimchi fried rice and that shit tastes as good as Monta's.  Dope spot and a good addition to Southwest Vegas...

lPugCnOEU2VJOfT38HtR-Q.text: As you can expect, ramen comes out quick! Staff super attentative and friendly. But about the ramen...  I had the hot miso ramen. It is excellent. The noodles are fresh made and have a viewing window to watch them. Fresh is key!   The fried rice comes in two size portjons which os great. Nothing to not like in taste.   The food was really good my only wish is that the menu gets bigger because it was so good. But we came for ramen so maybe asking too much.

N2ptnF2VISUQ6O2Vm82uRg.text: From reading the reviews posted here on Yelp; maybe I was expecting more than I got. Went for a weekend dinner, sat at the bar since the tables were full.  Had the miso ramen & a side of fried rice.    The Miso Ramen was OK.  It lacked depth in the flavor.  The house made noodles were the straight variety, so it wasn't able to pick up lots of the broth like a wavy noodle would.  Overall, was just OK.  Not as expected.  Was able to taste the Tonkatsu Ramen.  The broth had more depth, but didn't knock my socks off.  Just OK.  The fried rice lacked pizzazz. Was just content.  Another OK vote.  This location is very small.  Maybe 7 tables (2 to 4 people) and about 10 bar spaces.

QU-MvgBIB8CXlCtbnsjchQ.text: One of my favorite ramen spots in las vegas!  I can always count on this place for my ramen fix. I really like that their ramen is made in house and cooked perfectly to a right biting texture. They recently added tsukemen ramen which i got to try and it was delicious. the soup base was flavorful and not too salty.  Their miso broth (pork and Chicken) for their standard ramen is also very tasty and that is what i usually get here and i would add corn to it. The service here is great and fast. I will for sure be back here whenever I am craving ramen.

kbCszXKsogMMSoVdTfsGAw.text: Always a pleasure to come here! My "Go to" place for my ramen cravings. Great customer service and enthusiasm from Rachel (look for the blonde hair girl with big glasses) and Angel. Accommodation at it's finest   Tip: I call it, "Karl with a K special": Pork belly bowl with fried chasu and sliced eggs on top. Let Rachel or Angel know and they'll be happy to make it for you!

ffIaE6xlfyj24OZVKgi0WQ.text: I took my gf here on her lunch break. We got there right as they opened at 1130 AM. Only 1 other customer was there.  I wanted to sit next to my gf on the booth side of the table instead of the hard chair  Our server Rachel, the Japanese girl w/ blonde hair, wouldn't let us sit where we wanted saying the tables are for parties of 4 (there were 2 of these tables)  She told us to sit at the bar if we wanted to sit next to each other  Not gonna comment on the food because I already had a bad taste in my mouth  Horrible customer service!!! Go to Monta instead

2RQ0zKvadowr_oHDKmbZjA.text: Yup! This place is now a favorite! Super friendly staff, really nice decor inside and best part is amazing food!  I got the tonkatsu ramen with a medium spicy. I added egg, corn and nori as well as a side of kimchi fried rice.   The spicy level was pretty decent. My nose was running a little by the end. They say the low spicy level is like a 4/10, so mine was probably like a 6/10. The noodles are handmade which makes a huge difference. The kimchi fried rice is great for a little appetizer to share with someone.   I'll definitely be back soon!

wwbiDh53ruY_TM6oTbmxOw.text: Found his little gem while waiting to have a tire changed across the street at Discount Tire. Must say it was really very good. Not the biggest place inside so although I didn't wait I imagine at busier times there may be a wait. Had the chicken base noodles medium spice and it was absolutely perfect! Portion was perfect and felt completely satisfy when we were done. Also had the fried rice which was also very good. Will surely have to return when back in town!

3bbFODQNGrpbwE4SDyItIg.text: Small restaurant in south west. It was for me the first time  to try ramen.  The service was quick. I tried pork belly bowl + a pork ramen with some extra toppings ( corn , boiled eggs, chashu pork ). And it was great. Price is super affordable. I will definitely come back.  Just remember the restaurant is small and you might need to wait before getting seated.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork belly bowl

ATpE2g8T-Ew381IZS1nmMQ.text: I always order the Miso medium add extra mushrooms. The medium is spicy but tolerable. Their fried rice is the best I've ever had and this is what we order for our 18 mo old son. Even with all the veggies in it, he will almost finish all of it. The broth is delicious,  I love that they add roasted garlic and those (bamboo?) shoots and the Ramen is freshly made! They make it onsite. They have a variety of other ingredients that you can add for extra $$$ which if you're eyes are bigger than your stomach you may just end up spending $15+ on a bowl- but really- even without the extras- it is write home about good! Staff is always so welcoming and on top of it! This place is tiny, so just know you may experience somewhat of a wait. No worries- watch them make Ramen. Well worth it! My family and I love coming here.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso Broth, add soft boiled egg, butter and extra mushrooms:)

bQ9v3ed6MoHFn5J5Q6fIFA.text: This is probably my favorite place for ramen noodles. It is so amazing that every time I go there, there is a long line. It is a very small place with limited seating, but let me tell you, you won't be disappointed!

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States

BfdS9xbrhBE0hTw9zSDW6g.text: I highly recommended this place if you are craving for a good Ramen..prices are reasonable. Location is perfect and the most important the service is fast and very good! I only wish they can expend the restaurant little bigger, so they can accommodate more of us instead of sometime getting hustle with the wait. Overall, this is one of the best Ramen in the Southwest area.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States

_9PYEAbMQGHYAiX8Aen5bQ.text: By far the best Ramen. Hand made noodles, great flavor... you can't go wrong. Just what the doctor ordered for anyone under the weather and the perfect meal on a rainy day. If you're in the area, go! Check this place out!

7MayTZB2skFOs9mSlbB3ig.text: I give them 5 stars they are excellent the broth was tasty the portion perfect the add ins delicious and the service excellent. I will always love monta but here you get their great food and a more relaxed atmosphere no lines lol at least not yet but they will come this ramen house is a winner all around and close to home you can't beat that.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkatsu ramen and pork belly bowl delicious

ZCN1mBmP4olXwAYjXN5jvw.text: I absolutely enjoy this place. I have been to a few ramen joints in the surrounding area and this is my favorite. I took my mom, who is in town to visit her granddaughter, for her first bowl of legit ramen and she loved it. I wholeheartedly recommend the kimchi and black garlic oil with any dish. Definitely grab the extra noodles because there will be enough broth leftover for a takeout. Don't forget to add a soft boiled egg. Something so simple adds an exceptional amount of flavor.

Iwt8Phj8UP8URxEwYbCJnQ.text: The ramen is oyisi!!! So delicious. I love their charsew n the egg. Cook to the perfection.  I try 1 of their rice bowl. It was ok. It's good too.  The price is a little pricey for me but I don't mind as long as the food is good.  One thing that they don't have, appetizer.  Service was ok. No complain. I'll b back.

8hmQhQhbb4wrlgA-Opc9kA.text: Wow. What a wonderful place. Small and clean. Great service. The food was excellent. The pork broth was on point. Noddles was fresh!!!

QzhIyrLOQ39E40CJWf3OuQ.text: There's this plethora of happiness inside of me knowing that such a solid ramen shop is (somewhat) close to me. Well at least, closer than all the ones at Spring Mountain.   Here lies Ramen KoBo, sister to Monta Ramen, and a small, petite, homemade ramen noodle shop. As others have already mentioned, their noodles are always made in fresh batches, so you don't have to worry about that funky, stiff chewiness you get at some ramen places when you know they don't serve their ingredients fresh.   The ramen itself is solid. I personally like my miso with a lot of sodium, as it's already unhealthful in the first place. I think if that's what you are looking for, a heavy broth similar to that of Ramen Sora, then you will find that here. One thing in particular that I found unique was that they added ground pork to the ramen bowl. Never seen that before, but that's just me.   I do believe that the toppings are more on the overpriced side. Every topping is a dollar or more, and I'm used to seeing it and 75 cents or less. I'd also be much more pleased with my time here if they had a larger appetizer menu to choose from. I usually like to start off with some takoyaki or gyoza, and it was a shame to see that they didn't have either of the two. Although, I did like their kimchi fried rice; it was very flavorful in comparison to what I get sometimes at Monta.   I know that seating is very limited at this location. I'll be bold to suggest that seating should be even more limited. When you walk inside, you know that of course, the establishment is very small itself. However, it doesn't mean that one should cram as many tables inside as one possibly can. I would've enjoyed my meal much more, without having to hear every single word of the conversation next to me, and feeling as if the couples in my vicinity were breathing right beside my neck. I had to move to the bar area in order to feel relaxed once again.   Albeit this place has its downsides, the ramen itself, I feel, is a good enough reason to come back here, especially when I'm too lazy to drive all the way to Chinatown.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Love how you can adjust the spice level
Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Solid!

H84Q3Cc6h-i4UaiEQ3VALA.text: I had the Tonkonsu Ramen Mild Spicy, added egg, flying fish roe and black garlic oil. The Ramen and the soup taste really good. It's my first time there and I love it. Service is great. Will definitely go back next time.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States

Aq4dDbVYA7kDlyI2dn_iPA.text: This is my favorite ramen place in Vegas besides Monta Ramen (same owners, btw, but different style of noodle). I recommend the Tonkotsu (pork) broth. You can also ask for whatever spicy level on the side so you can add it yourself. I always get mine with Tamago (egg) & sometimes butter

sLFi2mp791cGQaknva6h3g.text: I just moved here from Los Angeles so I have been trying out a bunch of restaurants  in my area. I'm glad I tried Ramen KoBo! The tonkotsu broth was de-li-cious! The broth had an intense pork flavor that was rich and buttery. The freshly made noodles were perfectly cooked. The cha-siu pork was so tender it literally melted in my mouth! I have frequented a lot of ramen places in LA, OC and now Las Vegas and Ramen KoBo is easily one of my top ramen restaurants.   P.S. My fiance who is not a ramen fan at all ended up loving this place. It's just that good!

bmH928iGhxQEF_q_jELYeg.text: Came to Ramen KoBo with some friends after work because they raves about it.  I'm not a huge ramen fan, but I think that's changed now.  This place has the best ramen and their noodles are sooooo good.  I would highly recommend getting the black garlic oil with any bowl of ramen you order.  Service was good but had to keep asking for refills of water.  Overall, great experience and I'll definitely be back

u-ZXPFVWWLrzv40bfDq4fw.text: This is my third time here, and I love that they are consistent.  The pork broth ramen with medium spice is my favorite. With a side of fried rice you just can't go wrong.   The service is great and everyone is so friendly.  Tu better believe I'll be back!

4sYcRO-pEGC_SmXrUziooQ.text: My family and I came here to eat for the first time and it was extremely crowded with little to no space inside, very small restaurant so I recommend not going during peak hours unless you have the patience to wait (dining in or to go). We decided to order to go and the process was really simple submitting the order on the iPad they have at the counter and took about 20 minutes for us to receive our food due to how busy they were. Everything was packaged very well.  Be careful with how hot you go. I warned my Grandma to get medium instead of hot just to be safe but she insisted and even though she really enjoyed it, it was a little too spicy for her. I was super excited to try this place because of the good reviews and with how crowded it was made me think I was going to love it. I ordered the shoyu (chicken) ramen and unfortunately wasn't thrilled at all. I didn't enjoy the flavor the only reason I think about giving it a second chance is because of how much my family enjoyed it.

bVouoxLoAJ7Nhe1zyhOmvw.text: I have been here 3 times. Food is delicious. The broth very flavorful and noodles fresh. Small dining room with a few tables and bar seating. There's always a little bit of a wait. The food and service is fast so you don't have to wait long. I would say it's comparable to Monta Ramen and Jinya. Love that it's on the Southwest side of town and fairly close to my house. I will definitely be back.

FqmUZd508dgQIQgCvezewA.text: Cashu bowl is good. But a short hair comes out from ramen. And the server never apologized, and even asked me if it's my hair. Well.. Since I have a long hair, definitely was not mine. :( Additionally, i ordered mild miso ramen, and it's no flavored and too watery. So i asked for chili spice and they bring me chili oil. But it was not even spicy! They brought me A REGULAR SESAME OIL!!!!!!!!!!! HOW AWEFUL.  I will never go there again.

Photo of Ramen Kobo - Las Vegas, NV, United States

zLBm0je-L-nEkU1Lh-IjSw.text: I've been here several times. Always good ramen. Noodles are tasty. Good noodle to broth ratio. I get medium and it definitely has plenty of heat for someone who likes spice. Staff is very nice and fast to turn tables. Good selection of add ins at decent prices. It's kind of annoying though that they close for a little while in the afternoon on weekdays. There have been a few times I ended up going to another restaurant because they were closed and I couldn't wait.
